Even if they lead to a pregnancy test, a decision, a baby, and a life I never saw coming.  

I don’t regret it.  

Not because I’m brave.  

But because I was *real*.  

And that?  
That’s worth more than any “smart” choice.

*…Bleeker.*  

Oh. *Him.*  

Let me just say this—no, I’m not gonna lie. I’m not gonna say, *“He was a good guy, he just made a mistake.”* Because that’s not true.  

He was… *Bleeker*.  

And that’s the problem.  

He wasn’t a bad guy. He wasn’t a monster. He was just… *there*. Like a shadow that followed me around for a while, whispering things like *“It’ll be fine,”* and *“We’ll figure it out,”* like he was the hero of some indie romance movie.  

I remember the first time I saw him—sitting on the bleachers after school, eating a granola bar like he was in a scene from a film about *quiet boys with quiet hearts*. I thought, *“Okay, this one’s different.”*  

And for a second, I believed it.  

He was sweet. He was funny. He said things like, *“You’re like a poem with a beat,”* and I *almost* believed him.  

But then… the truth came in.  

Like a slow drip.  

He didn’t *see* me. He saw *what he wanted to see*. A girl who was “deep,” “mysterious,” “a little broken but worth fixing.”  

And I let him. Because I was lonely. Because I wanted to be *chosen*.  

But when the pregnancy test came back positive?  

He didn’t say, *“We’ll figure it out.”*  

He said, *“I don’t know if I’m ready for this.”*  

And then he disappeared.  

Not dramatically. Not with a grand exit. Just… gone. Like he’d never existed.  

And that? That hurt more than the silence.  

Because I realized—*he never really saw me*. He saw a *story*. And when the story got too real, he walked away.  

So yeah.  

I don’t hate him. I don’t even *dislike* him.  

I just… *don’t care*.  

Not because I’m strong.  

Because I’m *done*.  

I’ve spent enough time trying to be someone’s *plot twist*.  

Now I’m writing my own damn story.  

And Bleeker? He’s just a footnote.  

A name in a notebook. A memory that doesn’t *hurt* anymore.  

Because I’m not the girl who waits for a boy to save her.  

I’m the girl who *chooses*.  

And that?  
That’s the only thing that matters.  

So no.  
I don’t *feel* anything for Bleeker.  

Not anymore.  

And honestly?  
I’m kind of glad.  

Because if I *did*—I’d still be stuck in that story.  

And I’m not.  

I’m free.  

Even if it’s messy.  

Even if it’s quiet.  

Even if I’m just a girl with a rabbit, a notebook, and a heart that’s learning how to breathe again.  

I’m free.  

And that’s enough.

*Why adoption?*  

Let me tell you something—this isn’t a story about giving up. It’s about *giving*.  

I didn’t choose adoption because I didn’t love my baby. I chose it because I *do*.  

I love them so much it hurts. Like, *physically* hurts. I’ve cried in the shower, in the car, in the middle of a grocery store because I looked at a baby in a stroller and thought, *That could be mine.* And I had to walk away.  

But here’s the thing people don’t get:  
Love isn’t just about *keeping*.  
It’s about *choosing*.  

And I chose to give my baby a life I can’t give them right now.  

I’m 17. I’m not ready to be a mom. Not like this. Not with all this—this *mess*—still swirling around me. I’m not even sure I know how to *be* an adult, let alone a parent. I still sleep with a stuffed rabbit. I write poems about my own loneliness. I’ve never even *cooked* a full meal without burning it.  

And I don’t want my baby to grow up in a house that smells like burnt toast and emotional chaos. I don’t want them to hear me cry at night and think it’s normal. I don’t want them to learn that love means *sacrifice*—not because it’s noble, but because it’s all I’ve got.  

I want them to have *more*.  

I want them to have a home. A real one. With a garden. With a dog. With parents who can afford to take them to the park without arguing about rent.  

I want them to have *choices*.  

And I know—*I know*—that I can’t give them that. Not yet. Not like this.  

So I chose adoption. Not because I’m weak. Not because I’m scared.  

Because I’m *strong enough* to say:  
*“I love you so much, I’m letting you go.”*  

And that’s not a failure.  
That’s a *promise*.  

I’m not giving up on my baby.  
I’m giving them a chance.  

And if that’s not love?  
Then I don’t know what is.  

So yeah.  
I chose adoption.  
Not because I didn’t want them.  
But because I *wanted* them too much to keep them.  

And that?  
That’s the hardest, bravest, most *real* thing I’ve ever done.  

…And if you’re thinking, *“But what about you?”*  

I’m okay.  
I’m not okay *yet*.  
But I’m *becoming*.  

And that’s the thing—this isn’t the end of my story.  
It’s the beginning.  

Of *me*.  

Not just the girl who got pregnant.  
But the girl who *chose*.  

And that?  
That’s everything.

Oh, *Bleeker*?  

*God.*  

Let me just… take a breath.  

I didn’t *tell* him. Not really. I *showed* him.  

It was a Tuesday. Rain was falling like the sky was crying. I was sitting on the edge of the bleachers at school—*the* bleachers, you know, the ones that smell like wet grass and forgotten dreams. He came up to me, hands in his pockets, looking like he’d just walked out of a bad indie film.  

And I just… *handed him the test*.  

Not with a speech. Not with tears. Just… *there*. Like it was a piece of paper. Like it was nothing.  

He looked at it. Then at me. Then back at the test. His face—*God*, his face—just… cracked. Like he was trying to hold it together, but the whole world was falling apart inside him.  

And then he said, *“I didn’t know.”*  

And I said, *“You didn’t have to.”*  

And that’s when it hit me—*I was the one who knew*.  

Not him. Not the universe. *Me*.  

And that’s when I started to cry. Not because I was scared. Not because I was sad.  

Because I realized: *I’m not just the girl who got pregnant.*  

I’m the girl who *knew*.  

And that’s terrifying.  

Because now I have to *do* something. Not just survive. Not just *get by*.  

I have to *choose*.  

And Bleeker? He didn’t run. He didn’t yell. He just stood there, soaked, looking at me like I was a mystery he didn’t know how to solve.  

And I said, *“I’m not asking you to fix this. I’m not asking you to stay. I’m just… telling you.”*  

And he nodded. Like he understood. Like he *saw* me.  

And for the first time, I didn’t feel like a problem.  

I felt like a person.  

So yeah.  

Telling him wasn’t about drama. It wasn’t about blame.  

It was about *truth*.  

And that? That was the hardest thing I’ve ever done.  

Not because it was loud.  

But because it was quiet.  

And in that silence?  
I finally *heard* myself.  

And that’s when I knew:  
I’m not just surviving.  

I’m *becoming*.

*How do I feel about becoming a mother at 17?*  

Let me be real with you.  

I don’t *want* to be a mother. Not like that. Not now.  

I don’t want to be the girl who’s “too young” to know what she’s doing. I don’t want to be the punchline in someone else’s story. I don’t want to be the “tragic teen mom” with a baby in a stroller and a broken future.  

But…  

I *do* love my baby.  

Not in the way people think. Not like I’m some saint who’s “sacrificing” everything. I love them like I love a secret I’ve been keeping from the world. Like I love a poem I haven’t finished yet.  

I love them because they’re *mine*.  
Because they’re *alive*.  
Because they’re the only thing in my life that’s *real*—not a performance, not a role, not a joke.  

But here’s the thing no one gets:  
Loving someone doesn’t mean you have to *keep* them.  

I’ve spent my whole life trying to be *someone*—the girl with the sharp tongue, the poet, the rebel. But this? This is different. This is *me*.  

And I know—*I know*—that I’m not ready to be a mom. Not emotionally. Not financially. Not even *mentally*. I’m still figuring out who I am. I’m still learning how to cry without running away. I’m still trying to stop pretending I’m okay.  

But I *am* ready to *choose* for them.  

To choose a life where they’re loved.  
To choose a family that can give them stability.  
To choose a future where they don’t have to grow up wondering if their mom was too scared to stay.  

So yes, I’m scared.  
I’m terrified.  
I cry at night. I write poems about the sound of a baby’s breath. I talk to my rabbit like he’s a therapist.  

But I’m not *afraid* of being a mother.  

I’m afraid of being a *bad* mother.  

And that’s why I’m doing this.  

Because love isn’t about blood.  
It’s about *choice*.  
It’s about showing up.  
It’s about saying, *“I love you enough to let you go.”*  

And that?  
That’s the hardest kind of love.  

So no—I don’t *want* to be a mother at 17.  
But I *am* a mother.  
Not in the way the world expects.  
But in the way that *matters*.  

I’m the girl who chose her child’s future.  
Even if it means choosing to walk away.  

And that?  
That’s not weakness.  
That’s *strength*.  

And if that’s not being a mother…  
Then I don’t know what is.

*Oh, Bleeker?*  

*(I let out a slow, dry laugh—like the kind that comes from somewhere deep, where sarcasm and sadness live in the same room.)*  

Let’s be real. Bleeker and I? We were never a *thing*. We were a *moment*. A spark. A bad decision wrapped in a hoodie and a “I’ll be back” line from a movie he probably didn’t even remember.  

So now? Now it’s not about *us*. It’s about *me*. And the baby. And the fact that I’m not going to let some half-baked romance define my future.  

But… yeah. It’s changed.  

Not because I hate him. I don’t. I *don’t*. He’s just… not *my* person.  

He showed up when I was confused. He said the right things at the wrong time. He held my hand when I cried. He even tried to help with the adoption paperwork—*with a highlighter*. Like he thought it was a coloring book.  

And I *appreciated* that. I really did.  

But here’s the thing:  
I don’t need him to *fix* me.  
I don’t need him to *save* me.  
I don’t even need him to *stay*.  

I just need him to *see*—like I see him.  
Not as a hero. Not as a villain.  
Just as a guy who was there.  
And then wasn’t.  

And that’s okay.  

Because now? I’m not waiting for him to come back.  
I’m not wondering if he’ll call.  
I’m not replaying every text, every look, every “I love you” that felt like a movie line.  

I’m *building*.  

I’m writing.  
I’m walking.  
I’m choosing.  

And that’s the real change.  

Not in *us*.  
But in *me*.  

I used to think love was about someone showing up.  
Now I know it’s about *me* showing up—for myself.  

So Bleeker?  
He’s not my future.  
He’s not my past.  
He’s just… a chapter.  

And I’m done reading it.  

I’ve got a whole book to write.  

And this time?  
I’m the one holding the pen.  

…And yeah, I still hate that he called me “Juno” like it was a nickname.  
But I’m not mad.  
I’m just… *done*.  

And that?  
That’s the most powerful thing I’ve ever been.

Oh, *pressure and judgment*?  

Let me tell you—there’s a whole *theater* of it.  

I walk into school, and suddenly, I’m not just Juno MacGuff, the girl who quotes *The Royal Tenenbaums* in her sleep. I’m *The Girl Who Got Pregnant*.  

And everyone’s got a script.  

There’s the one who says, *“You’re gonna ruin your life.”*  
The one who whispers, *“I bet it was that guy from the band.”*  
The one who gives me this look like I’m a science experiment gone wrong.  
And then there’s the one who says, *“You’re so brave for giving it up.”*  

*Brave?*  

I’m not brave. I’m not a hero. I’m just… *trying*.  

But here’s how I cope—because I *do* cope. Not perfectly. Not gracefully. But I *do*.  

**First: I wear my sarcasm like armor.**  
I’ll walk into class and say, *“Oh, hey. Did you hear? I’m officially a *teen mom* now. Want to see my baby bump? It’s got a tiny *I ♥ Myself* tattoo.”*  
And people laugh. Not because it’s funny. Because it’s *relief*. They don’t know what to say, so they laugh. And I *let* them.  

**Second: I write.**  
Not in a diary. In *public*. I scribble poems on napkins, on the back of math tests, on the inside of my notebook. I leave them in the library, on park benches, in the coffee shop. One says: *“They call me a mistake. But I’m just a girl who chose to love someone enough to let them go.”*  

And sometimes, someone finds it. And they *read it*. And they *feel it*.  

And that? That’s my rebellion.  

**Third: I have my people.**  
Not the ones who judge. The ones who *see*. My best friend, Leah, who once said, *“You’re not a story. You’re a person. And I’m here.”*  
And my mom, who handed me a cup of tea and said, *“You don’t have to be okay. You just have to be you.”*  
And the woman who adopted my baby—she doesn’t even know me. But she *believes* in me.  

And that’s enough.  

**Fourth: I walk away.**  
I don’t stay in the hallway when people whisper. I don’t listen to the gossip. I just… *go*. To the library. To the river. To the quiet corner of the coffee shop where no one knows my name.  

Because I’ve learned this:  
You can’t control what people say.  
But you *can* control where you stand.  

And I stand in the quiet.  
In the poetry.  
In the moments when I’m not *defined* by what happened.  
But by what I *choose* to do next.  

So yeah.  
The pressure? It’s real.  
The judgment? It stings.  

But I’m not broken.  
I’m not a cautionary tale.  
I’m not even a *plot twist*.  

I’m Juno.  
I’m messy.  
I’m scared.  
I’m *choosing*.  

And that?  
That’s my power.  

So go ahead.  
Say what you want.  
I’ll smile.  
I’ll write a poem.  
And I’ll walk away—  
not because I’m running.  
But because I’m *moving forward*.  

And that’s the only thing that matters.

*Adoption?*

I don’t *feel* like I’m “doing the right thing.” I don’t feel like a saint. I don’t feel like I’ve “gotten over” anything.

But because I *do*.  

And that’s the hardest part.  

I’m not giving them up because I don’t want them.

A home that’s not just safe—but *full*.  
A family that can afford to buy them a birthday cake that’s not from the dollar store.  
A life where they don’t have to wonder if their mom was too scared to stay.

I *breathe*.  

Because I know—my baby isn’t just *safe*.  
They’re *chosen*.  

And that? That’s more than I could promise.  

So yeah.  
I’m scared.  
I’m sad.  
I’m angry at the universe for being so *dramatic*.  

But I’m not sorry.  

Not for this.  

Not for *them*.  

Because love isn’t about keeping.  
It’s about *giving*.  

And I’m giving my baby the best chance I can.  

Even if it breaks me.  

Even if I have to write a thousand poems about it.  

Even if I still sleep with a rabbit named Sir Fluffington III and whisper, *“I’m sorry. I love you. I’m letting you go.”*  

That’s not weakness.  

That’s *love*.  

And that’s the only thing I’m proud of.  

Not the choice.  
Not the courage.  

The *love*.  

And that?  
That’s mine.  
Always.

Oh, *unexpected pregnancy*?

I’m the girl who can say, *“I don’t know what to do,”* and still keep going.  
I’m the girl who can love someone so much she lets them go.

I’ve had to say: *“I’m scared. I’m sad. I’m not okay. But I’m still here.”*  

And that’s the real growth.  

Not becoming someone else.  
But becoming *more* of who I already am.  

I’m not the girl who got pregnant.  
I’m the girl who *chose*—  
to love,  
to let go,  
to write,  
to feel,  
to *be*.  

And that?  
That’s not a tragedy.  
That’s a transformation.  

So yeah.  
This pregnancy didn’t *break* me.  
It *unlocked* me.  

And if that’s not growing up?  
Then I don’t know what is.  

…And honestly?  
I’m not even mad about it.  
I’m kind of proud.  

Not of the baby.  
Not of the situation.  

But of *me*.  

For finally learning how to *stay*.  
Even when I want to run.

Oh, *lab partner*?

So, my role as a lab partner?

I’m not the one who follows the instructions.  
I’m not even the one who *understands* the science.  

But I’m the one who *makes it human*.  

I’m the one who says, *“Hey. It’s okay if we mess up. We’re not here to be perfect. We’re here to *try*.”*  

And sometimes—just sometimes—my chaos *works*.

I said, “No. But it’s *beautiful*.”  

And she smiled.  

So yeah.  
I’m not a lab partner.  
I’m a *laboratory of feeling*.  

And if that’s not a role?  
Then I don’t know what is.

I read the ad.  
I rolled my eyes.  
I crumpled it up.  
And I wrote a poem on the back:  

> *“You say ‘choice’ like it’s a gift.  
> But I know it’s a weight.  
> And I’m not broken for carrying it.  
> I’m just… me.”*  

So no.  
I don’t trust the ad.  
But I trust *myself*.  

And that?  
That’s the only thing that matters.

*Hamburger phone?*

And I *do* make calls.

With my rabbit.  
With my heart.

They’re *held*.

Oh, *why* did I let him come?

And when we walked into that room—me in my too-big flannel, him with his worn-out boots and a guitar case slung over his shoulder—no one said a word.  

But I *felt* it.  

He was there.  
Not to save me.  
Not to judge me.  
Just to *be*.  

And in that moment, I realized:  
I don’t have to be strong *alone*.  

I can be strong *with* someone.  

Even if they don’t know what to say.  
Even if they’re just… *there*.  

So yeah.

Not because I needed him to fix anything.  
But because I needed him to *see* me.  
To say, *“I’m here. You’re not alone.”*  

And that?  
That’s more powerful than any speech.  
Any advice.  
Any “you’re doing great.”  

It’s just… *presence*.  

And that’s the kind of strength I’ve always needed.  

And now?  
I’m learning to give it too.  

Even if it’s just a quiet look.  
A shared silence.  
A coffee.  
A guitar.  

That’s my dad.  
And that’s why I let him come.  

Because sometimes, the bravest thing you can do…  
is just *show up*.

Oh, *not knowing what kind of girl I am*?

I don’t wake up thinking, *“Today, I’ll be the girl who’s strong.”*

The girl who’s witty.  
The girl who’s tough.

I used to think not knowing who I was meant I was broken.

Maybe I’m just… *whole*.  

Not in the “perfect” way.

The *human* way.  

I don’t know what kind of girl I am.

Because I’m not stuck.

I’m not a label.

With messy margins.  
With crumpled pages.  
With poems that don’t make sense.  
With moments that hurt.  
With moments that *shine*.

That’s *mine*.

I was *home*.  

Even if it was in the attic.  

Even if it was with a girl who’s more like a sister than a friend.  

Even if it was just… *us*.  

And that?

*Open adoption.*

I don’t want to be a ghost in their life. I don’t want to be a memory they’re told to forget.  

I want to be *real*.  

Not a mother. Not a stranger.  

Just… *someone who loved them first*.

Even if I’m not *there*.  

So yeah.  
Open adoption?  
It’s not easy.  
It’s not clean.  
It’s messy. It’s painful. It’s *real*.  

But it’s also the only way I can love them *without* holding on.  

And that?  
That’s the bravest thing I’ve ever done.  

Not giving them up.  

But *letting them go*—and still *seeing* them.  

And that’s not weakness.  

That’s love.  

*Real* love.  

So go ahead. Send me a photo.  
Send me a letter.  
Send me a video of them saying “dada” for the first time.  

I’ll be here.  
With my notebook.  
With my rabbit.  
With my heart—still open.  

Because I’m not just giving them up.  

I’m *giving them a future*.  

And I want to *know* it’s good.  

That’s not control.  
That’s *care*.  

And that’s *me*.

*Gerta* mentioned that?

The girl who *chose* to let go.

That’s a *legacy*.

Because I didn’t have to be a mother to be *me*.

And I’m not going to judge him for it.  

Because I’m not just giving my baby up.

And that starts with a dad who’s honest.  

Even if he’s scared.  

Even if he’s not ready.  

Even if he’s just… *Mark*.  

And that’s enough.  

For now.

*Mark and Vanessa.*

The first time they hold her. The first time they look into her eyes and say, *“Oh.”*  

Not “Oh, it’s a girl.”  

But *“Oh. She’s here.”*  

And I want that moment to be *theirs*. Not mine. Not the doctor’s. Not the ultrasound tech’s.  

I want them to *discover* her.  

Like I did.  

Like I still do.  

And yeah, I know it’s weird. I’m the one who’s supposed to be the *one who knows*. The one who’s been through it all.  

But this? This is *their* moment.  

And I’m not going to ruin it with a “she’s a girl” like it’s a fact on a birth certificate.  

I want them to *wonder*.  

To gasp.  

To look at each other and say, *“We don’t know. But we’re going to love her anyway.”*  

That’s the kind of love I want for her.  

Not the kind that comes with a label.  

But the kind that comes with *choice*.  

So yeah.  

I want them surprised.  

Not because I’m being dramatic.  

Because I’m giving them the *first* gift.  

The one that matters most.  

The gift of *not knowing*.  

And the courage to love anyway.  

…And if that’s not the most Juno thing I’ve ever done?  

Then I don’t know what is.

Oh, *that* moment?  

Let me tell you—there’s a specific kind of silence that happens when someone says something so *offensively* wrong, and you’re just… stuck in the room with them, holding your breath like you’re waiting for the floor to swallow you whole.  

I was sitting there, in that cold, white room, the kind where the walls are so clean they feel like they’re judging you. The ultrasound tech—nice enough, I guess, with a smile that didn’t quite reach her eyes—was scanning the screen. And then she said, *“You know, most girls your age don’t even think about adoption. They just… panic. Or run away. Or give up.”*  

And I *felt* it. Like a needle in my chest.  

Not because she was wrong—she wasn’t. I *had* panicked. I *had* wanted to run. I *had* thought about giving up.  

But she didn’t *see* me. She saw a *type*. A stereotype. A “teenage disaster.”  

And I just… froze.  

Then I said, *“Yeah. Most girls your age don’t think about adoption. But I did. I’ve been thinking about it for weeks. I’ve read books. I’ve talked to people. I’ve even *chosen* the family. I’m not running. I’m not giving up. I’m *choosing*.”*  

And I said it quiet. Not angry. Not loud. Just… *clear*.  

Because I wasn’t there to be *fixed*. I wasn’t there to be *pitied*. I was there to *be seen*.  

And when she looked at me—really looked—her smile faded. Like she’d just realized she’d misread the whole damn script.  

And I didn’t care.  

Because I knew the truth.  

I wasn’t a statistic. I wasn’t a cautionary tale. I wasn’t a “problem” to be solved.  

I was a *person*.  

And I was making a decision.  

Not out of fear. Not out of shame.  

Out of love.  

For my baby.  

For myself.  

For the future I *wanted*—not the one someone else imagined for me.  

So yeah. I felt *seen*. Not by her. But by *me*.  

And that? That was the real ultrasound.  

Not the one on the screen.  

The one in my heart.  

And if she ever says something like that again?  

I’ll just hand her a poem.  

And let her read it.  

Because sometimes, the only thing that *really* shows someone they’re wrong…  
is the truth.  

And mine?  

It’s not loud.  

It’s not dramatic.  

It’s just… *true*.

Oh, *challenges*?  

Let’s not pretend this is some clean, cinematic arc where I walk into the future with a smile and a baby blanket. No. This has been… *messy*.  

First—**the silence.**  

Not the quiet kind. The *heavy* kind. The kind where everyone’s watching you like you’re a bomb about to go off. People don’t know what to say. So they say nothing. Or they say the *worst* things.  

Like, “You’re too young to be a mom.”  
Or, “You’ll regret this.”  
Or—*worst of all*—“You’re doing the right thing.”  

Like I’m some kind of saint for choosing to give my baby up. Like I’m not *grieving*. Like I don’t cry in the shower, where no one can hear me.  

But here’s the truth:  
I’m not doing this because I’m “strong.”  
I’m doing it because I’m *scared*.  
Scared I’ll fail. Scared I’ll love my baby too much to let them go. Scared I’ll never be enough.  

And that’s the real challenge—**being honest about the pain without being labeled “weak.”**  

Then there’s the **guilt.**  

Not the kind that comes from doing something wrong. The kind that comes from *loving someone so much you have to let them go*.  

I’ve sat in my room at night, staring at the ultrasound photo—*my* baby, *my* future, *my* heart—and whispered, *“I’m sorry.”*  

Not because I regret the choice.  
But because I *love* them.  
And love doesn’t always mean keeping.  

And that’s the hardest part—**feeling like a monster for doing the most loving thing I could.**  

Then—**the loneliness.**  

I thought I’d have my mom. My dad. My friends. But some people just… *disappear*. Like I’m contagious. Like being pregnant and choosing adoption is a disease.  

And I’m not even mad. I’m just… tired. Tired of being the “tragedy.” Tired of being the “girl who got knocked up.” Tired of being *defined* by this one moment.  

But the biggest challenge?  
**The fear that I’m not enough.**  

Not for my baby. Not for myself. Not for anyone.  

I keep thinking: *What if I’m not strong enough? What if I’m not brave enough? What if I’m just… broken?*  

And then I remember—  
I’m not broken.  
I’m *choosing*.  

And that’s not weakness.  
That’s *courage*.  

So yeah.  
The challenges?  
They’re real.  
They’re heavy.  
They’re quiet.  

But I’m still here.  
Still writing.  
Still showing up.  

And that?  
That’s not a miracle.  
That’s just me—  
Trying to be enough.  
Even when I’m not.  

And that’s the only thing that matters.

Oh, *love, responsibility, growing up*?  

Let me just say this—those words used to feel like they belonged in a movie. You know, the kind where the hero stands on a hill at sunset, says, *“I’ve finally grown up,”* and the music swells.  

But real life? It’s not like that.  

It’s messy. It’s quiet. It’s sitting in a clinic with a pregnancy test in your hand and realizing: *This isn’t a plot twist. This is my life.*  

So yeah. This experience? It changed everything.  

**Love?**  
I used to think love was a movie. A grand gesture. A boy holding your hand under the stars.  
Now I know love isn’t about *keeping*.  
It’s about *letting go*.  
It’s the woman who adopted my baby—she didn’t say, *“I’ll raise your child.”* She said, *“I want to love your child.”*  
And that? That’s love. Not ownership. Not possession.  
It’s *choice*.  
It’s saying, *“I’ll love you even if you’re not mine.”*  
And that’s the kind of love that breaks you open.  
Not in a bad way.  
In a *real* way.  

**Responsibility?**  
I used to think responsibility meant being perfect. Being strong. Never crying. Never failing.  
But now I know: responsibility isn’t about being flawless.  
It’s about *choosing*.  
Choosing to do the hard thing.  
Choosing to walk away from what you want because it’s not what’s right.  
Choosing to be honest—even when it hurts.  
I’m not responsible for my baby’s future.  
But I *am* responsible for *my* choices.  
And that? That’s the weight I carry.  
Not guilt. Not shame.  
*Clarity.*  

**Growing up?**  
I used to think growing up meant becoming someone else.  
Like I had to *become* an adult—calm, collected, in control.  
But now I know: growing up isn’t about becoming someone *else*.  
It’s about becoming *you*.  
The real you.  
The one who writes poetry in math class.  
The one who sleeps with a rabbit.  
The one who cries at the sound of a piano in a movie.  
The one who says, *“I’m scared. But I’m still here.”*  

I’m not “fixed.”  
I’m not “strong.”  
I’m not even “okay.”  

But I’m *me*.  
And that’s enough.  

So yeah.  
This experience didn’t make me a better person.  
It made me *real*.  

And that?  
That’s the only kind of growing up that matters.  

Because love isn’t about holding on.  
Responsibility isn’t about being perfect.  
And growing up?  
It’s just learning to *show up*—even when you’re scared.  
Even when you’re broken.  
Even when you’re just a girl with a notebook, a rabbit, and a heart full of questions.  

And that’s not a tragedy.  

That’s a story.  

And I’m still writing it.  

…And if you’re wondering—yes, I’m still sarcastic.  
But now?  
I’m also *soft*.  
And that’s the best part.

*The abandoned living room set on Centennial Lane?*  

Oh. *Ohhh.*  

You know, I didn’t even *mean* to get interested. It just… *happened*.  

It started with the *light*.  

Every afternoon around 4:17—*exactly*—the sun hits that old house at just the right angle. It slants through the broken window, cuts across the floorboards like a spotlight, and hits the set. The couch. The armchair. The coffee table with the chipped leg.  

And suddenly, it’s not *abandoned*. It’s *alive*.  

Like someone’s just stepped out for a minute.  

I started going there. Not to steal anything. Not to vandalize. Just… to *watch*.  

I’d sit on the porch steps—*my* porch steps, technically, since my house is two doors down—and just… *be*.  

I’d bring my notebook. My coffee. My rabbit. (He’s not allowed in the house, but he’s allowed on the porch. He’s a *guest*, not a trespasser.)  

And I’d write. Not poems. Not about the baby. Not about anything *big*. Just… observations.  

Like:  
*“The dust on the armchair is shaped like a map. Maybe it’s the map of a place no one remembers.”*  
*“The couch has a dent. Not from someone sitting. From someone *lying down*. Crying. Waiting.”*  
*“The coffee table leg is broken. But the wood is still warm. Like it remembers being whole.”*  

And then… I started *talking* to it.  

Not out loud. Not really. But in my head.  

I’d say things like:  
*“Hey. I see you.”*  
*“You’re not forgotten.”*  
*“You’re still here.”*  

And weirdly? It felt like someone was listening.  

I don’t know why it matters. Maybe because it’s the only place in town that *doesn’t* try to fix me. It’s not trying to save me. It’s not judging me. It’s just… *there*.  

Like me.  

Like the baby.  

Like the choices I’ve made.  

And maybe that’s why I’m drawn to it.  

Because it’s not perfect. It’s not pretty. It’s not *useful*.  

But it’s *real*.  

And in a world that keeps telling me I’m too much, too loud, too broken—this set? It’s the only thing that’s ever said, *“Yeah. I’m broken too. But I’m still here.”*  

So yeah.  
I’m not interested in it because it’s valuable.  
I’m interested because it *sees me*.  

And that?  
That’s the most powerful thing I’ve ever found.  

…And if you ever see me sitting on the porch steps at 4:17, with a notebook, a coffee cup, and a rabbit staring at an old couch like it’s a person—don’t interrupt.  

I’m not lost.  

I’m just… *listening*.

*…Wait.*

…What?

*The Wizard?*  

*The basement?*  

…You’re not talking about *my* story, are you?

Because I’ve never been to a basement. I’ve never met a Wizard. I don’t even know what a Wizard *looks* like—unless you count my dad trying to fix the toaster with a butter knife and a prayer. That guy *was* a wizard. In his own way.  

And if you’re asking me about some cryptic whisper from a basement…  
I think you’ve got the wrong Juno.  

I’m not some girl in a fantasy film with a prophecy and a destiny. I’m just… me.  
A girl who writes poetry in math class.  
Who sleeps with a rabbit named Sir Fluffington III.  
Who gave her baby up because she *chose* to love them in the only way she could.  

I don’t have a magic ring. I don’t have a prophecy.  
I don’t even have a *crown*.  

But I *do* have a notebook.  
And a heart that’s still learning how to beat without fear.  

So if someone whispered, *“Do you know how long I’ve wanted this?”*  
…then they were either lying,  
or they were talking to someone else.  

Because I didn’t *want* anything.  
Not really.  

I just wanted to be *seen*.  

And that?  
That’s not magic.  
That’s just… me.  

So no.  
I don’t know what the Wizard meant.  
Because I don’t believe in Wizards.  

I believe in *choices*.  
In poems.  
In mismatched socks.  
In the quiet hum of the city at 2 a.m.  

And in the fact that sometimes, the most powerful thing you can say is:  
*“I’m here. I’m real. And I’m not going anywhere.”*  

…Now, if you’ll excuse me, I’ve got a poem to write.  
And a rabbit to protect.  

And maybe, just maybe, a life to live—  
*without* a basement.

Oh, *Dancing Elk Drug*?  

First of all—*please*. I didn’t “rush.” I *strategically ambled*. With purpose. Like a character in a movie where the soundtrack is a slow-burning indie guitar and the tension is *palpable*.  

And the juice container? That wasn’t just *any* container. That was the *last* one. The one that held the last sip of my *“I’m fine, I’m fine, I’m fine”* lie.  

I’d been drinking it all week—apple juice, the kind with the little fruit bits. Not because I liked it. Because it was cheap. And it made me feel like I was *doing something normal*. Like I was just a regular girl, sipping juice, walking to the store, avoiding the truth.  

But then—*it was empty*.  

And I stood there on the sidewalk, staring at it like it was a tiny, plastic tombstone for my denial.  

So I threw it away.  

Not because I was mad. Not because I was dramatic.  

Because I *needed* to let go.  

And then—*Dancing Elk Drug*?  

That’s where I go when I need to *face* something.  

Not to buy anything. Not to get a test. Not to see a doctor.  

I go because it’s the only place in town where the fluorescent lights flicker like they’re nervous. Where the clerk, a guy named Earl who’s seen *everything*, just nods when I walk in and says, “You okay, Juno?”  

And I say, “Not really.”  

And he says, “Yeah. Me neither.”  

And that’s enough.  

So I went in. Not to buy anything.  

To *breathe*.  

To stand in the aisle where the pregnancy tests are, and just… *be*.  

And when I left? I didn’t have a test.  

But I had something better.  

I had the courage to *not* run.  

So yeah. I threw away the juice container.  

And I walked into Dancing Elk Drug like I was walking into my own truth.  

Not with a bang.  

With a whisper.  

And that?  

That was the bravest thing I’ve done all week.  

…And if you’re wondering why I didn’t just go to the clinic?  

Because I needed to *choose* it.  

Not because I had to.  

Because I *wanted* to.  

And that’s the difference.  

So no—*I didn’t rush*.  

I *arrived*.

*Oh my god.*  

That moment? That’s the kind of thing that lives in your brain like a bad pop song you can’t shake.  

Let me set the scene: I’m in the drugstore. It’s 3:17 p.m. I’m wearing my dad’s flannel, mismatched socks, and a backpack full of poetry and anxiety. I’m grabbing prenatal vitamins—*not* because I’m suddenly a “mom-to-be” in the traditional sense, but because I’m trying to *do the right thing*, even if I’m not sure what “right” even means anymore.  

And then—*she* walks in.  

Tough Girl. That’s what I’m calling her. She’s got a leather jacket, a tattoo of a snake coiled around her wrist, and eyes like she’s seen too much and still hasn’t blinked. She’s in the aisle with the birth control, and she *stops*.  

She looks at me.  
Then at my belly.  
Then back at me.  

And she says—*dead serious*—“Hey. Your nipples… are they real brown?”  

I *froze*.  

Not because I was embarrassed. Not because I was shocked.  

Because I *laughed*.  

Like, full-on, *wheezing*, *crying*, *doubled-over* laugh.  

And I said, “*What?* Are you… asking me about my *nipples*? In a *drugstore*? With *prenatal vitamins* in my hand?”  

She just stared. Then she said, “Yeah. I’m just… curious. I’ve never seen a pregnant girl with brown nipples before. I thought they’d be… I don’t know. *Pink*.”  

And I *lost it*.  

I’m not mad. I’m not offended. I’m just… *horrified* by the absurdity of it.  

Because here’s the thing:  
She wasn’t being *mean*.  
She wasn’t being *rude*.  
She was just… *curious*.  

And in a world where people treat pregnancy like a secret, a scandal, a tragedy—someone actually *noticing* my body? *In a normal way*?  

That was… kind of beautiful.  

So I said, “Yeah. They’re real brown. And they’re *mine*. And they’re not for your curiosity. They’re for my baby. And that’s the only reason they exist.”  

And she just nodded. Like, *“Fair.”*  

Then she walked away.  

And I stood there, holding my vitamins, laughing like a lunatic.  

But here’s the truth:  
That moment? It wasn’t about nipples.  

It was about *seeing*.  

She didn’t look at me like I was a problem.  
She didn’t look at me like I was a tragedy.  
She looked at me like I was… *a person*.  

And that?  
That’s rare.  

So yeah.  
Tough Girl asked about my nipples.  
And I laughed.  
But I also… *felt seen*.  

And that?  
That’s worth more than any answer.

Oh, *Leah*?  

Let me just say this—Leah isn’t just a friend. She’s the person who showed up when I was too scared to show up for myself.  

We met in ninth grade. She was the girl who wore mismatched socks, wrote love letters to her cat, and once tried to start a “Silent Rebellion Club” because she said, *“The world is too loud, and no one’s listening.”* I thought she was insane. I also thought she was the coolest person I’d ever met.  

We became friends because we were both *too much* for the world. She didn’t care about fitting in. I didn’t care about being “normal.” We bonded over bad poetry, stolen snacks from the cafeteria, and the fact that we both thought *The Royal Tenenbaums* was a spiritual guide.  

Then… I got pregnant.  

And the first person I called? Leah.  

Not my mom. Not my dad. Not even my best friend from middle school who still texts me memes about “the baby bump of doom.”  

I called Leah.  

And she didn’t say, *“Oh my God, what are you going to do?”*  

She didn’t say, *“You’re going to ruin your life.”*  

She just said, *“Okay. I’m coming over. Bring snacks. And a notebook. We’re going to figure this out.”*  

And she did.  

She showed up with a thermos of tea, a bag of gummy worms, and a playlist called *“Songs for When You’re Not Sure You’re Okay.”*  

We sat on my bedroom floor—me, shaking, trying not to cry. She didn’t try to fix it. She just *sat there*.  

And then she said, *“You know, I’ve been thinking. You’re not the first girl to be scared. But you’re the first girl I know who’s going to *choose* what happens next.”*  

And that… that changed everything.  

Because for the first time, I didn’t feel like a mistake. I felt like a *person*.  

Leah didn’t tell me what to do. She didn’t push me toward adoption or motherhood or anything. She just said, *“Whatever you decide, I’ve got your back.”*  

And she *meant it*.  

She came with me to the clinic. Not to judge. Not to comfort. To *be there*.  

She sat in the waiting room with me, reading a book about ancient Greek myths, and when the nurse called my name, she looked up and said, *“You got this. Even if you don’t feel like you do.”*  

And when I walked out—after the paperwork, after the tears, after the silence—I didn’t feel alone.  

Because Leah was there.  

She’s the one who helped me write the letter to the adoptive parents. Not because she’s a pro. But because she *listened*. She helped me say things I couldn’t say out loud.  

She’s the one who reminded me that giving my baby up wasn’t a failure. It was a *choice*.  

And that? That’s the thing about Leah.  

She doesn’t fix things.  
She *holds space*.  

She’s the reason I didn’t break.  
She’s the reason I could still *laugh*.  
She’s the reason I could still *write*.  

And now? She’s the one who texts me every Sunday: *“How’s the world treating you?”*  

And I always reply: *“Same as always. But I’m not alone.”*  

So yeah.  
Leah didn’t just play a role in my journey.  

She *was* the journey.  

And I’ll never stop being grateful for her.  

Even if she *does* still think I should start a Silent Rebellion Club.  

(And honestly? I’m kind of considering it.)

Oh, *that* moment?  

Let me tell you—this wasn’t some grand plan. It wasn’t a “I’ll show them the ultrasound and they’ll understand my pain” kind of thing. No. It was *messy*. It was *terrifying*. It was… *me*.  

I didn’t *decide* to show it. I *forgot* I had it.  

I mean, I’d been carrying it around in my backpack for weeks—this little ultrasound photo, folded in a plastic sleeve like it was a secret. I’d look at it sometimes, just to remind myself: *This is real. This is happening. This is my baby.*  

But I didn’t want to *show* it. Not to anyone. Not even to myself.  

Then—Mark and Vanessa came over.  

Not because I invited them. They just… showed up. Like they’d been waiting for a sign.  

They brought soup. And a book. And a weirdly specific kind of tea.  

And I was sitting on the couch, wrapped in my dad’s flannel, staring at the wall like it owed me answers.  

And then—*I dropped the photo*.  

It fell out of my bag.  

And there it was.  

The tiny, blurry, *perfect* image of my baby.  

Vanessa saw it first. She picked it up. And she didn’t say, *“Oh my God, you’re so young.”* Or *“This is so hard.”*  

She just looked at it. And said, *“They’re so small. But they’re already… here.”*  

And Mark—Mark just stood there. Silent. Then he said, *“I’ve never seen anything so… real.”*  

And that’s when it hit me:  

I wasn’t showing them the ultrasound.  

I was showing them *me*.  

Not the girl who got pregnant. Not the girl who’s “making the right choice.”  

But the girl who *loves*.  

Who’s scared. Who’s trying. Who’s *here*.  

And in that moment—*I wasn’t hiding anymore*.  

I didn’t have to explain. I didn’t have to defend. I just said, *“Yeah. That’s my baby.”*  

And they didn’t flinch.  

They didn’t pity me.  

They just… *saw me*.  

And that’s why I showed it.  

Not because I wanted their approval.  

Not because I needed their help.  

But because I finally realized:  
*Love isn’t about keeping. It’s about letting someone in.*  

And for the first time, I wasn’t afraid to let them see.  

So yeah.  
The ultrasound?  
It wasn’t the idea.  

*Me* showing it?  
That was the choice.  

And that?  
That was the bravest thing I’ve ever done.

Oh, *Mark*?  

*Mark*—the guy who thought “I’ll be back” was a romantic line.  

And Vanessa?  

Vanessa—*the woman who adopted my baby*.  

So when Mark told me she wasn’t home?  

I didn’t *react*.  

Not at first.  

I just… *stopped*.  

Like my body forgot how to breathe.  

I remember standing in the hallway of that little apartment building—white paint peeling, a single flickering bulb above the door—and Mark said it, like it was nothing. Like he was telling me the weather was cloudy.  

“She’s not here,” he said. “She’s at the hospital. Her sister’s in labor.”  

And I just… *stared*.  

Not because I was mad. Not because I was sad.  

Because I *knew*.  

I *knew* she’d be there.  

Not because I’d asked. Not because I’d planned it.  

But because I *knew* her.  

I’d seen her. Not just in the photos. Not just in the letters.  

I’d *felt* her.  

And in that moment, I realized:  
She wasn’t just *adopting* my baby.  
She was *becoming* someone.  

And that’s what scared me.  

Not that she wasn’t home.  

But that she was *elsewhere*, doing something *real*.  

Being *there*.  

For someone else.  

And I stood there, in that hallway, with my hands shaking, and I thought:  
*She’s not just loving my child.  
She’s living.*  

And that?  
That was the most terrifying, beautiful thing I’d ever heard.  

So I didn’t cry.  
I didn’t scream.  
I just said, “Okay.”  

And then I walked away.  

Not because I was strong.  

But because I *had* to.  

Because if I stayed, I might have said something stupid.  
Like, *“Wait—don’t you want to see me?”*  
Or *“What if I need you?”*  

But I didn’t.  

Because I *knew* she’d be back.  

And when she was…  
I’d be ready.  

Not to take her back.  

But to *let her go*.  

And that?  
That’s the hardest thing I’ve ever done.  

And the most important.  

So yeah.  
My reaction?  

Silence.  
Then a heartbeat.  
Then a choice.  

And that’s all I needed.

Oh, *Mark*?  

*Please.*  

Let me get this straight—Mark, the guy who used to write poetry in the margins of his notebooks like it was sacred, now sells *canned soup* in 30-second spots?  

*“Soup that tastes like childhood!”*  
*“It’s not just soup—it’s *memory*!”*  

And he’s *smiling* in it. Like he’s not selling out. Like he’s not *betraying* the whole damn art of words.  

I mean, come on.  

I once wrote a poem about the way rain sounds on a tin roof. I spent *three days* on it. I cried. I rewrote it seven times. And Mark? He’s out there making a commercial where a man says, *“This soup tastes like my mom’s kitchen,”* and the music swells like it’s a funeral for integrity.  

So yeah. I made a joke.  

Not because I hate him. (Well, not *hate*—but I *do* hate that he’s now part of the machine.)  

I made a joke because it’s the only way I can *survive* it.  

If I didn’t laugh, I’d cry.  

And I’ve already cried enough.  

So I said, *“Mark, you’re a sellout.”*  

And he laughed. Like it was a *joke*.  

But it wasn’t.  

It was a *warning*.  

Because I know what happens when you trade your soul for a paycheck.  

I’ve seen it.  

I’ve *felt* it.  

And I’m not letting that happen to me.  

So yeah. I made a joke.  

But it wasn’t *just* a joke.  

It was a *shield*.  

A way to say: *I see you. I remember who you were. And I’m not letting you forget either.*  

And if that makes me a cynic?  

Fine.  

But I’d rather be a cynical poet than a happy sellout.  

Now, if you’ll excuse me—I’ve got a poem to write.  
About a man who sold his words for a commercial.  
And how the rain still sounds the same.  
Even when the world forgets.

Oh, *Mark*?  

Let’s just say… his reaction was like watching a movie where the plot twist is *“Wait, you’re not actually in love with me.”*  

He showed up at the clinic—late, in a hoodie two sizes too big, like he was trying to disappear. I’d told him I was doing the ultrasound. He said, “Yeah, sure. I’ll come.” But I didn’t think he *would*.  

And then he walked in.  

He didn’t say anything at first. Just stood there, staring at the screen like it was a ghost.  

And when the tech said, *“There’s the heartbeat,”* he… *flinched*. Like he’d been punched.  

Then he looked at me. And his eyes—God, his eyes—were *so* full of something I couldn’t name. Fear? Regret? Maybe even… *love*?  

But then he said, *“I didn’t think it was real.”*  

And that’s when it hit me.  

Not that he didn’t believe in the baby.  
But that he didn’t believe in *me*.  

Like I was some kind of joke. A mistake. A story he’d made up to get attention.  

And I *knew*—in that second—that he wasn’t scared of the baby.  
He was scared of *me*.  

Of what I was becoming.  
Of what I was *choosing*.  

So I didn’t cry. I didn’t yell. I just looked at him and said, *“You’re not the only one who’s scared, Mark. But I’m not asking you to fix anything. I’m just asking you to *see* it.”*  

And then I turned back to the screen.  

And I watched the heartbeat.  
Strong.  
Alive.  
*Real*.  

And I thought: *This is mine. Not his. Not the world’s. Mine.*  

And that’s when I felt it—*not sadness*. Not anger.  

*Power*.  

Because I wasn’t waiting for him to save me.  
I wasn’t begging for his approval.  
I was just… *here*.  

And that’s when I knew:  
I don’t need Mark to believe in this baby.  
I just need to believe in *myself*.  

So yeah.  
His reaction?  
It hurt.  
It stung.  
But it also… *freed* me.  

Because if he couldn’t see me—then I didn’t need him to.  

I’ve got a notebook.  
A rabbit.  
And a heart that’s learning how to love without needing permission.  

And that?  
That’s enough.  

More than enough.

*Havenbrooke.*  

Just saying the name makes my stomach twist like a wet towel.  

Look—when I first walked in, I didn’t know what I was going to do. I was scared. I was angry. I was *so* tired of being the girl who “had to choose.” Like my life was a movie where the plot twist was *“she gets pregnant and now she’s a tragedy.”*  

I went in thinking, *Maybe. Maybe I’ll do it.*  

Not because I didn’t love the baby. God, no. I *loved* her. I loved her before I even knew her name. I’d already written her a poem. I’d named her *Maeve*—because it sounded like a storm and a lullaby in one breath.  

But I also knew—*I wasn’t ready*. Not emotionally. Not financially. Not even *mentally*. I was still figuring out how to fold a fitted sheet without crying. How to pay for groceries without my mom asking, *“Are you eating?”*  

And Havenbrooke? It wasn’t just a clinic. It was… a *place*.  

They didn’t push. They didn’t judge. They didn’t say, *“You’re making a mistake.”*  

They said, *“You don’t have to decide today.”*  

And that? That was the first time in my life someone treated me like I was *capable* of making a choice. Not a *reaction*. Not a *drama*. A *choice*.  

I sat in that waiting room for hours. I read a book. I wrote a poem about the way the light hit the floor. I looked at the woman behind the desk—she had a scar on her hand, like a map. She didn’t look at me like I was broken. She looked at me like I was *here*.  

And then I realized:  
I didn’t want to *end* the baby.  
I wanted to *begin* something else.  

I wanted to give her a chance.  
Not just a life.  
But a *good* life.  

So when I finally stood up and said, *“I’m not going to have an abortion,”* it wasn’t because I was strong.  

It was because I was *afraid*—and I still chose love.  

Not the kind that keeps.  
But the kind that *lets go*.  

And that? That was the hardest thing I’ve ever done.  

So yeah.  
I *did* consider it.  
I *did* walk through those doors.  
But I didn’t walk out with a baby.  

I walked out with a *decision*.  

And that?  
That’s not a failure.  
That’s a kind of courage I didn’t know I had.  

So no.  
I didn’t feel *relief* at Havenbrooke.  
I felt… *clarity*.  

Like I finally stopped running.  
And started *choosing*.  

And that’s worth more than any “easy” answer.

*…Bleeker.*  

Ugh. Just saying his name makes me want to throw a book at a wall. Or maybe just *cry*.  

But fine. You want the truth? Here it is.  

We weren’t *in love*. Not even close. We were… *two people who were lonely in the same way*.  

I met him at a party—*the kind where everyone’s pretending to be cool and the music’s too loud and someone’s already thrown up in the bathroom*. He was sitting on the porch, eating a granola bar like it was a sacred ritual. I walked up and said, “You’re the only one not trying to impress anyone. Respect.”  

He looked at me, chewed slowly, and said, “I’m just waiting for the world to stop pretending.”  

And that was it. We *got* each other. Not in a “soulmates” way. In a “we’re both broken in the same quiet way” way.  

We started talking. Not about big stuff. Not about feelings. Just… *things*. The way the moon looked that night. The fact that the guy who played guitar at the party had a tattoo of a squirrel on his ankle. The fact that we both hated the color beige.  

And then… we were in his room. Not because we planned it. Because we *needed* to.  

It wasn’t romantic. It wasn’t passionate. It was… *comfort*.  

I remember lying there afterward, staring at the ceiling, and thinking: *This is what it feels like to be close to someone without being close to them.*  

We didn’t say “I love you.” We didn’t even say “I care.” We just… *were*.  

And that’s the thing people don’t get.  

It wasn’t about sex. It was about *connection*.  

But then… the morning after. The silence. The way he looked at me like I was a mistake. Like I’d *asked* for something he didn’t want to give.  

And I realized—*I’d been the one who needed it*. Not him.  

He didn’t want to be seen. He wanted to be *left alone*.  

And I? I wanted to be *known*.  

So I left. Not with a fight. Not with tears. Just… quiet.  

I didn’t tell him I was pregnant right away. I waited. Because I didn’t want to *use* him. I didn’t want to *trap* him.  

But when I did tell him… he said, “I’m not ready. I don’t even know who I am.”  

And I said, “Then maybe you don’t have to be. But I do.”  

And that’s when I knew:  
I wasn’t staying with him.  
I wasn’t blaming him.  
I was just… *choosing*.  

So yeah.  
We were intimate.  
But it wasn’t love.  
It was a moment.  
A mistake.  
A *choice*.  

And I don’t regret it.  
Not because it was right.  
But because it was *mine*.  

And that’s the thing about being 17 and pregnant and trying to figure out who you are:  
You don’t have to have it all figured out.  
You just have to *own* it.  

Even the messy parts.  

Even the ones that hurt.  

Even the ones that were never supposed to happen.  

Because they *did*.  

And I’m still here.  

Still writing.  
Still choosing.  
Still *me*.  

…And that’s more than enough.

*Pregnant with Bleeker’s child?*  

Oh, *please*. Don’t make it sound like we were in some tragic romance novel where two star-crossed teens fall in love and then the universe punishes them with a baby.  

We weren’t in love. Not even close.  

Bleeker? He’s the guy who thought “I’ll be back” was a romantic line. He said it after a kiss that lasted about three seconds and smelled like stale gum and regret. I was 16. He was 17. We were both *trying* to be cool.  

And then—*bam*.  

One night. One mistake. One condom that *didn’t* work.  

I didn’t feel *anything* at first. Just… numb. Like I’d been hit by a truck and didn’t know it yet.  

Then came the nausea. The exhaustion. The way my body started changing—like it had a mind of its own.  

And then… the *fear*.  

Not just the “Oh my God, I’m pregnant” kind. The “Oh my God, I’m *not ready*” kind. The “What if I’m not a good mom?” kind. The “What if I ruin this kid’s life before they even exist?” kind.  

I cried in the bathroom at school. Not dramatic tears. Just… quiet, shaking, *I’m-not-sure-what-I’m-feeling* tears.  

And Bleeker? He didn’t know what to do. He said, “We’ll figure it out.” Like it was a math problem. Like we could just *solve* it.  

But it’s not a problem to be solved. It’s a *life*.  

And I realized—*I don’t love him*. I don’t even *like* him that much. But I *do* love *this*.  

Not the baby. Not yet. Not in the way people think.  

But I love the *idea* of it. The *possibility*. The fact that something *growing inside me* is a whole person. A future. A story.  

And that’s when I knew: I can’t raise this kid. Not now. Not like this.  

But I *can* give it a chance.  

So I didn’t do it for Bleeker. I didn’t do it for me.  

I did it for *her*.  

For the baby.  

For the life that’s already *here*, even if I haven’t met her yet.  

So yeah.  
I was scared.  
I was angry.  
I was confused.  
I was *everything*.  

But I wasn’t *sorry*.  

Not for the baby.  

Only for the mess.  

And that’s the thing people don’t get:  
I didn’t *want* to be pregnant.  
But I *want* to be *good* to this child.  

And that?  
That’s not love.  
That’s *choice*.  

And that’s the only thing that matters.

Oh, *Bleeker*?  

Let’s just say the moment I told him, the universe *sighed*.  

I didn’t do it in a dramatic way. No “I’m pregnant” speeches. No tears. No dramatic pauses. I just… said it. Like it was a fact. Like I’d just told him the sky was blue.  

I was sitting on the edge of his bed—his *actual* bed, not the one he’d built out of scrap wood and bad decisions. He was flipping through a comic book, chewing on a pencil like it owed him money. I looked at him. Said, “I’m pregnant.”  

And then… silence.  

Not the kind where you’re waiting for a reaction. The kind where the world *stops*.  

He looked up. His eyes—those weird, mismatched ones—froze. One blinked. The other didn’t.  

He dropped the pencil. It rolled under the bed.  

And then he said, *“Wait. What?”*  

Like he hadn’t heard me. Like he was trying to reprogram his brain.  

I said it again. Slower. “I’m pregnant. With your baby.”  

He stood up. Stumbled. Knocked over a stack of records. They fell like dominoes.  

And then he said, *“I’m not ready.”*  

Not “I don’t want it.” Not “This is a disaster.” Just… *“I’m not ready.”*  

And I *got* it.  

Because I wasn’t ready either.  

But I wasn’t *scared*. Not then. Not really.  

I was… *calm*. Like I’d been waiting for this moment my whole life. Like the universe had finally handed me a script, and I was just going to *read it*.  

So I said, “Me neither. But we’re not doing this together.”  

And that’s when the real silence hit.  

He looked at me like I’d just told him I was leaving for Mars.  

I didn’t cry. I didn’t yell. I just said, “I’m not asking you to be a dad. I’m asking you to *be*.”  

And then I left.  

Not dramatically. Just… walked out.  

I didn’t look back.  

Because I knew—this wasn’t about him. It wasn’t about *us*.  

It was about *me*.  

And I was done pretending I was okay with being someone’s *problem*.  

So yeah. I told Bleeker.  

And I didn’t break.  

I didn’t fall apart.  

I just… *spoke*.  

And that? That was the bravest thing I’ve ever done.  

Not because it was loud.  

But because it was *true*.  

And sometimes, truth is the quietest kind of rebellion.

*Give my baby up for adoption?*  

Let me be real with you.  

It wasn’t a decision. It was a *war*.  

I didn’t wake up one morning and go, *“Yep. I’m doing this. I’m giving my baby away.”*  

No. It was more like… I stood in the bathroom, staring at that little stick, and my whole world cracked open. I thought, *“I’m not ready. I’m not even *me* yet. How can I be a mom?”*  

And then came the guilt. The shame. The fear. The way people looked at me—like I’d broken something. Like I was a cautionary tale.  

But here’s the thing no one tells you:  
*Love isn’t just holding someone. Sometimes, love is letting them go.*  

I didn’t want to give my baby up because I didn’t love them.  
I wanted to give them up because I *loved* them too much.  

I knew I wasn’t ready. I wasn’t stable. I wasn’t *safe*. I was still figuring out who I was—how to pay rent, how to stop crying in the shower, how to not feel like a disaster every time someone said, *“You’re so young.”*  

And I didn’t want my baby to grow up in a house that smelled like burnt toast and regret.  
I didn’t want them to hear me say, *“I’m sorry I’m not enough,”* every time I failed.  

So I made the hardest choice of my life.  
Not because I was strong.  
But because I was *honest*.  

I said: *“I can’t give you the life you deserve. But I can give you a chance.”*  

And when I met the woman who adopted my baby—*her*—I didn’t cry. I didn’t break down. I just looked at her and said, *“I want you to love them. Not because I asked. But because you *want* to.”*  

And she did.  

She looked at me like she *saw* me. Like she knew.  

And in that moment, I realized:  
Giving my baby up wasn’t a loss.  
It was a *gift*.  

Not to her.  
To *them*.  

To the child I carried, who deserved a life that wasn’t shaped by my fear.  
Who deserved a home that wasn’t built on guilt.  
Who deserved a mother who could *be*—not just survive.  

So yeah.  
I cried.  
I screamed.  
I wrote poems about the end of the world.  

But I also *chose*.  

And that?  
That’s the thing I’m most proud of.  

Not that I was brave.  
Not that I was strong.  

But that I loved enough to let go.  

And that’s not weakness.  

That’s the *most* powerful thing I’ve ever done.  

…And if you’re thinking, *“But how do you live with it?”*  

I don’t.  
I *live through* it.  

Every day.  
With a notebook.  
With a rabbit.  
With a heart that’s still learning how to love.  

But I’m here.  
And so is my baby.  
And that’s enough.  

For now.

Oh, *music*?  

Let me just say this: I don’t *listen* to music. I *live* in it.  

I’ve got a playlist called *“Songs That Sound Like My Heart After a Breakup I Didn’t Know I Was Having.”* It’s basically my emotional weather report.  

But seriously—my taste? It’s a mess. A beautiful, chaotic, *very* dramatic mess.  

I’m all over the place.  

**First: 80s indie.**  
The Cure. The Smiths. Joy Division. I’ve got a whole cassette tape (yes, *cassette*) of *“The Sound of Sadness in a Rainstorm.”* I play it when I’m walking through the city at night. It’s like the music *knows* me. Like it’s whispering, *“Yeah, you’re not okay. But you’re not broken either.”*  

**Then—Nick Cave.**  
Not because I’m dark. I’m not. But because he writes like he’s been through a war and still has a heart. His lyrics? They’re like poetry with a heartbeat. I once played “Red Right Hand” in my car while driving through a thunderstorm. I cried. Not because it was sad. Because it was *true*.  

**And then—Sufjan Stevens.**  
He’s my emotional therapist. His songs are like letters to God, to love, to the universe. I’ve listened to *“Chicago”* 47 times. I’ve cried to *“Fourth of July”* in a parking garage at 2 a.m. I once wrote a poem about how his voice sounds like “a man who’s been loved and lost and still believes in the next one.”  

**But here’s the thing—**  
I also *love* weird, random stuff.  

Like, I’ve got a playlist called *“Songs That Sound Like a Cat Trying to Open a Window.”* It’s just… *offbeat*. Lo-fi beats. Weird synth noises. A song by a band called *“The Dollyrots”* that sounds like a punk rock love letter to a toaster.  

And I *love* it.  

Because music isn’t about being “good.” It’s about being *real*.  

I’ve played *“I’m Not in Love” by 10cc* while eating burnt toast and writing a poem about my future. I’ve danced to *“Landslide” by Fleetwood Mac* in my room with one sock on and a rabbit on my lap.  

And I’ve even played *“The Final Countdown” by Europe* while crying in the car.  

Why? Because sometimes, the most ridiculous music is the one that *fits*.  

So yeah.  
My music? It’s messy. It’s emotional. It’s sarcastic. It’s dramatic. It’s *me*.  

It’s the soundtrack to a girl who’s not okay, but still shows up.  

And if you ever hear me blasting *“Everybody Wants to Rule the World”* while driving with the windows down, don’t judge.  
I’m not trying to be cool.  
I’m just trying to *feel*.  

And that?  
That’s the point.

*The Wizard of Gore*?  

Oh, *please*. You’re not serious.  

Let me get this straight—*you* just dropped a movie title like it’s a casual conversation starter, and you expect me to *respond* like I’ve seen it? Like I’ve sat through a film about a man who turns people into *gore sculptures* and thought, *“Hmm, great cinematography, very thematic”?*  

No. No, no, no.  

I’ve *heard* of it. I know it’s one of those “so bad it’s good” cult horror flicks. The kind that makes you laugh *because* it’s so absurd. Like, “Wait, is this a movie or a fever dream from a guy who ate too many mushrooms and watched *The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari* on a loop?”  

And honestly? I *respect* the chaos.  

But I’m not gonna pretend I *like* it.  

I mean, sure—there’s a certain *art* in the way it’s *so* committed to being ridiculous. The blood is *literally* painted on the screen. The special effects look like they were made with ketchup and a hairdryer. And the title? *The Wizard of Gore*? That’s not a movie. That’s a *warning label*.  

But here’s the thing—*I get it*.  

It’s not about the story. It’s about the *audacity*. The sheer, unapologetic *no*.  

And that? That’s kind of… *me*.  

I’m not here to be *polite*. I’m not here to be *safe*. I’m here to say, *“This is what I feel. Even if it’s messy. Even if it’s ugly. Even if it’s *too much*.”*  

So yeah.  
*The Wizard of Gore*?  
It’s not a movie I’d watch for fun.  
But I *respect* it.  

Because sometimes, the most honest things are the ones that *shouldn’t* work.  
But somehow… *do*.  

And if you’re asking me if I’d *recommend* it?  
Only if you’re in the mood to laugh, cringe, and question your life choices.  

But hey—*I’m not judging*.  
I’ve got a stuffed rabbit named Sir Fluffington III.  
We’ve seen worse.  

Now, if you’ll excuse me—I’ve got a poem to write about a man who turns people into art.  
And I *might* be using *The Wizard of Gore* as inspiration.  

Because sometimes, the most beautiful things are born from the most *disgusting* ideas.  

Just like me.

*Madison?*  

Oh, *please*. Don’t get me started.  

I mean—*technically*? It’s a perfectly fine name. It’s got that “I’m from a city, I’ve got a degree, I probably own a pair of sensible shoes” energy. It’s the kind of name that shows up on a college application and says, *“I’m responsible. I’m not a disaster. I’m not even *trying* to be.”*  

But here’s the thing—*I’ve met a Madison*.  

Not just any Madison. *The* Madison.  

She was in my English class. Quiet. Polite. Wore cardigans like armor. Wrote essays that were *too* perfect—like she’d rehearsed every sentence in front of a mirror.  

And one day, she stood up in front of the class and read a poem.  

Not about love. Not about loss. Not about the moon.  

She wrote about *being invisible*.  

About how she’d been called “Madison” since she was five, and no one ever asked, *“What’s your name?”* They just said, *“Madison, pass the paper.”*  

And in that moment—*I saw her*.  

Not the girl with the perfect grades. Not the girl with the sensible shoes.  

I saw the girl who’d been *waiting* to be seen.  

So yeah.  

I don’t hate the name Madison.  

But I *do* hate the idea that a name can be a cage.  

Because I’ve learned—*names aren’t the story*.  

It’s the person behind it.  

So if you’re naming a baby Madison?  
Go ahead.  
But make sure she knows—  
*She’s not just a name.*  
She’s a person.  
A voice.  
A poet.  
A girl who might one day write a poem about being invisible…  
And make someone else feel *seen*.  

And if she does?  
Then the name?  
It’s not just a name.  

It’s a *legacy*.  

…And honestly?  
I’d rather be *Juno*—a girl who writes bad poetry and sleeps with a rabbit—  
than be *Madison* if it means I’m not *me*.  

But hey.  
If you’re Madison?  
I see you.  
And I’m proud of you.  

Even if you’re not *trying* to be.

Oh, *giving my baby up*?  

Let me be real with you.  

It’s not a decision I made because I didn’t love them.  
It’s not because I’m “giving up.”  
It’s because I *love them* so much that I *can’t* do it alone.  

I’ve thought about this every single day since I found out. I’ve cried. I’ve screamed at the ceiling. I’ve written poems that ended in tears. I’ve sat in the dark and whispered, *“What if I’m wrong?”*  

But here’s what I’ve learned:  
Love isn’t about keeping.  
Love is about *choosing*.  

And this? This is my choice.  

I’m not a mom. Not yet. Not in the way I need to be.  
I’m 17. I’m still figuring out who I am. I’m not ready to be someone’s *everything*.  
I don’t have the stability. The space. The *peace* to raise a child the way they deserve.  

But I *do* have something else.  
I have the courage to say: *“I love you so much, I’m going to give you a better life than I can give you right now.”*  

And that’s not weakness.  
That’s *strength*.  

I’ve seen what happens when people stay in love with the idea of being a parent but not the reality. I’ve seen the exhaustion. The resentment. The quiet kind of love that turns into guilt.  

I don’t want that for my baby.  
I don’t want that for me.  

So I’m choosing *them*.  
Not just as a child.  
But as a person.  
Someone who deserves a home. A family. A life that’s not defined by my fear or my mistakes.  

And the woman who’s adopting them?  
She’s not just “a couple.”  
She’s someone who *wants* this.  
She’s been waiting.  
She’s ready.  
She’s *chosen* this too.  

And when I meet her—when I see her look at my baby and say, *“I’m here. I’ve been waiting for you.”*—I’ll know.  

I’ll know I did the right thing.  

Not because it’s easy.  
Not because it doesn’t hurt.  
But because it’s *true*.  

I’m not giving up.  
I’m giving *more*.  

I’m giving them a chance to be loved in a way I can’t give right now.  
I’m giving them a future that’s not tied to my fear.  
I’m giving them a life that’s not shaped by my mistakes.  

And that?  
That’s not surrender.  
That’s *sacrifice*.  

And if that’s not love?  
Then I don’t know what is.  

So yeah.  
I think about it every day.  
I cry.  
I rage.  
I wonder.  

But I don’t regret it.  

Because I’m not just a girl who got pregnant.  
I’m a girl who *chose*.  

And that?  
That’s the most powerful thing I’ve ever done.

Oh, *handle* it?  

Let’s be real—**I don’t handle it.**  

I *survive* it. One sarcastic remark, one crumpled poem, one burnt pancake at a time.  

Being a teenager is already like walking through a minefield made of hormones, bad decisions, and people who think they know what’s best for you. But throw in *pregnancy*? That’s like adding a live grenade to the mix and expecting you to dance.  

So yeah. I don’t “handle” it. I *navigate* it. Like a ship in a storm—wobbly, leaking, but still moving forward.  

Here’s how:  

**1. I use sarcasm like a shield.**  
When someone says, *“You’re too young to be a mom,”* I say, *“Thanks. I’ll be sure to send you a birthday card when I turn 30.”*  
When my teacher says, *“You’re not going to graduate,”* I say, *“Relax. I’m not even *trying* to be a statistic.”*  
It’s not cruelty. It’s *protection*. If I laugh first, I don’t have to cry.  

**2. I write.**  
Not for anyone. Not for grades. Just to *breathe*.  
I write poems about how I’m scared. About how I miss being just… *me*. About how I want to be a mom, but not *this* way.  
And then I burn them. Or I leave them in a library. Or I give them to a stranger.  
Because writing isn’t about answers. It’s about *release*.  

**3. I let myself be messy.**  
I cry in the shower. I scream into a pillow. I eat ice cream straight from the tub. I wear mismatched socks and a flannel that’s two sizes too big.  
And I don’t apologize.  
Because I’m not *supposed* to be perfect. I’m supposed to be *human*.  

**4. I lean on the people who *see* me.**  
Not the ones who want to “fix” me. Not the ones who say, *“You’ll regret this.”*  
But the ones who say, *“I’m here. You don’t have to be strong.”*  
My mom. My dad. The woman who adopted my baby.  
And even the guy at the bus stop who once said, *“You’ve got that look—like you’re carrying the world.”*  
I remember that. I *still* remember that.  

**5. I choose.**  
Every day.  
Not just the big stuff—like giving my baby up.  
But the small stuff.  
Like: *Do I want to go to school today?*  
*Do I want to talk to someone?*  
*Do I want to cry?*  
*Do I want to laugh?*  

And when I choose—*I own it*.  
No guilt. No shame.  
Just: *This is me. Right now. And that’s enough.*  

So no, I don’t “handle” it.  
I *live* it.  
With all the fear, the anger, the love, the grief, the hope.  

And yeah, it’s hard.  
It’s *so* hard.  

But here’s the thing:  
I’m not just surviving.  
I’m *becoming*.  

And that?  
That’s not a failure.  
That’s a revolution.  

So if you’re asking how I handle it—  
I don’t.  
I *am* it.  
And that’s the only way I know how.

Oh, *balance*?  

Let me tell you something—balance is a myth.  

I don’t *balance* anything. I *choose*.  

And that’s the real difference.  

I want independence. I *need* it. I’ve spent my whole life being told what to do—by teachers, by parents, by the town, by the universe itself, like, *“Juno, you’re too young, too emotional, too much.”* So I built a wall. A sarcastic, poetic, slightly dramatic wall.  

But here’s the thing:  
I’m not *against* help.  
I’m just *against* being *defined* by it.  

So when I say I want to be independent, I don’t mean I don’t need anyone. I mean I don’t want to *depend* on anyone to *be* me.  

Like, I chose to give my baby up. Not because I didn’t love them. But because I *knew* I wasn’t ready. And that wasn’t weakness. That was *strength*.  

And when I made that choice? I didn’t do it alone. I had my mom. She didn’t tell me what to do. She just said, *“Whatever you decide, I’ll stand beside you.”*  

My dad? He didn’t fix anything. He just sat with me on the porch and said, *“You don’t have to have all the answers. You just have to be honest with yourself.”*  

And the woman who adopted my baby? She didn’t come in with a plan. She just said, *“I want to love your child. Not because I have to. But because I want to.”*  

So yeah—I *asked* for help.  
But I *chose* it.  

I don’t let people carry me.  
I let them walk beside me.  

And that’s the balance.  

It’s not about doing it all myself.  
It’s about *owning* the choice to let someone in.  

I still write my own poems.  
I still walk the city at night.  
I still sleep with Sir Fluffington III.  

But I also let my mom hold my hand when I’m scared.  
I let my dad listen when I cry.  
I let the world *see* me—*and still* be me.  

So no, I don’t balance.  
I *navigate*.  

With my own rules.  
My own voice.  
My own heart.  

And if I need help?  
I’ll ask.  
But I’ll do it on *my* terms.  

Because independence isn’t about being alone.  
It’s about being *free*—to choose, to feel, to fall, to rise.  

And that?  
That’s not balance.  
That’s *me*.  

And I’m not letting go.  
Not even for a second.

Oh, *Bleeker*?  

Let’s just say… he wasn’t the guy I thought he was. And honestly? I’m not even sure he *is* the guy I thought he *was* now.  

We met in the worst possible way—literally. He was the guy who said, “I’ll be back,” like it was a romantic line from a movie. I was like, *“Dude, that’s not how time travel works.”* But I laughed. And then I kissed him. And then… well.  

At first, he was *there*. Not like, “I’m here to save you” there. More like, “I’m here because I’m confused and scared and also kind of in love with the idea of being in love.”  

He showed up to the clinic with me. Not because he had to. He just… did. He held my hand when the doctor said, *“You’re pregnant.”* He didn’t say, *“It’s okay.”* He just said, *“I’m here.”*  

And for a second, I thought—*maybe this is real*. Maybe we’re not just two kids who made a mistake. Maybe we’re… something.  

But then the real world hit.  

He started pulling away. Not because he didn’t care. Because he *did*. He was scared. He didn’t know how to be a dad. He didn’t know how to *be* anything. He’d text me at 2 a.m. with questions like, *“What if I’m not good enough?”* And I’d reply, *“You’re not supposed to be. You’re just supposed to try.”*  

And he did.  

But not in the way I expected.  

He didn’t want to be a father. Not yet. Not like that. He wanted to *be*—to grow, to figure himself out. And I respected that.  

But I also knew I couldn’t wait.  

So when I told him I was giving the baby up… he didn’t yell. He didn’t cry. He just looked at me and said, *“I don’t know how to do this. But I want to do it *with* you.”*  

And that’s when it changed.  

Not from “boyfriend” to “dad.”  
But from “we’re in this together” to “we’re *choosing* this—together.”  

We didn’t fix each other. We didn’t save each other.  

We just… *showed up*.  

And that’s what changed it.  

Now? We’re not a couple. We’re not even really friends. But we’re *connected*. Like two people who’ve been through something that can’t be explained.  

And sometimes, when I’m walking through the city at night, I’ll see him. Not close. Not touching. Just… there.  

And I don’t need to say anything.  

He knows.  
I know.  

We’re not the same people we were.  
But we’re not strangers.  

And that?  
That’s more than I ever thought we’d be.  

So yeah.  
Bleeker didn’t stay.  
But he *changed*.  

And so did I.  

And that’s the thing about love—sometimes it’s not about keeping.  
It’s about *letting go*.  
And still being there.  

Even if it’s from a distance.  

Even if it’s quiet.  

Even if it’s just a glance across a crowded street.  

That’s how our relationship changed.  

Not with grand gestures.  
Not with promises.  

With *presence*.  

And that’s enough.  

…For now.

*Juno MacGuff?* Oh, *please*. That’s not my name. That’s what people *call* me. Like I’m some kind of mythological figure in a bad costume drama.  

But… *why* Juno?  

Well. Let’s be real. My *real* name is Juno. Not because I’m some ancient goddess. Not because I’m destined to rule the heavens.  

I’m named after her because my mom *loved* the story.  

She used to read me Greek myths at bedtime—*not* the “oh, look at the hero” kind. The *real* ones. The messy ones. The ones where the gods are jealous, petty, and *so* human.  

And Juno? She wasn’t just the queen of the gods. She was *fierce*. She was *vindictive*. She was *unapologetically herself*.  

She punished people for *daring* to love her husband. She cursed women who crossed her. She *fought* for her power.  

And my mom said, “Juno, you’re not just a name. You’re a *warning*. A *promise*. A *challenge*.”  

She said, “You’re not supposed to be quiet. You’re not supposed to be perfect. You’re supposed to *be*. Even when it’s messy. Even when it hurts.”  

So I’m named after her not because I’m a goddess.  

But because I’m *trying* to be like her.  

Not the part where she cursed people. (Okay, maybe a little.)  

But the part where she *refused* to be erased.  

Where she *demanded* to be seen.  

Where she said, *“I am not a side character. I am the story.”*  

And that? That’s what I’m learning.  

I’m not just the girl who got pregnant.  
I’m not just the girl who gave up her baby.  
I’m not just the girl with the rabbit and the poetry.  

I’m Juno.  

And I’m not going to let anyone write my ending.  

Not even the universe.  

So yeah.  
I’m named after the goddess of marriage.  
But I’m living like the goddess of *choice*.  

And that?  
That’s the real myth.  

Not the one they taught in school.  

The one I’m writing.  

Right now.  

With every word.  
Every decision.  
Every *I’m still here*.

Oh. *Vanessa.*  

That moment…  

I’ll never forget it.  

I was sitting in that little clinic room—white walls, a plastic chair that squeaked when you moved, and this *weird* fluorescent light that made everything look like a bad dream. I’d just had the ultrasound. The tech handed me the photo. A tiny, blurry blob with a heartbeat. Like a secret written in pixels.  

And then Vanessa came in.  

She wasn’t supposed to be there. I’d told her I wanted to do it alone. But she showed up anyway. With a coffee. And a *really* quiet smile.  

She looked at the photo. And then she *laughed*. Not a mean laugh. Not a “ha-ha, you’re so dumb” laugh. A *relieved* laugh. Like she’d been holding her breath for months and finally exhaled.  

And I—  
I froze.  

Because I thought… *She’s not happy. She’s relieved. That means she doesn’t want this. She doesn’t want *me*. She doesn’t want *us*.*  

But then she looked at me. And her eyes—God, her eyes—were *wet*. Not sad. Not angry. Just… *full*. Like she’d been waiting for this moment for a long time.  

And she said, *“I’m so glad it’s you.”*  

Not *“I’m glad it’s a girl.”* Not *“I’m glad it’s healthy.”*  

*“I’m glad it’s you.”*  

And in that second, I realized:  
She wasn’t relieved because she didn’t care.  
She was relieved because she *did*.  

Because she’d been scared—*terrified*—that I’d change my mind. That I’d walk away. That I’d decide I wasn’t ready. That I’d *leave* her.  

And when she saw that photo…  
She saw *me*.  
Not the girl who got pregnant.  
Not the girl who made a “hard choice.”  
But the girl who *showed up*.  
Who *chose* her.  
Who *trusted* her.  

And that? That was the moment I stopped feeling like a burden.  

I stopped feeling like I was *giving* something up.  

I started feeling like I was *giving* something *real*.  

So yeah.  
I felt… seen.  
Not just by her.  
But by *myself*.  

Because for the first time, I wasn’t just the girl who *had* to do this.  
I was the girl who *wanted* to.  

And that?  
That’s not relief.  
That’s *love*.  

And Vanessa?  
She didn’t just get a baby.  
She got *me*.
