And that’s the most terrifying, beautiful thing I’ve ever given.  

…And honestly?  
I still cry when I think about that photo.  
Not because it’s sad.  
Because it’s *true*.

Oh, *Vanessa’s mom*?  

Let me just say—she didn’t *find out* I was at the house. She *attacked* me like I’d stolen her favorite mug and set it on fire.  

It was the day after I’d gone to her house—*not* to cause trouble. I just needed to talk to Vanessa. She’d been ghosting me since the whole “I’m pregnant” thing. I needed to explain. I needed to *say* something.  

So I showed up. Quietly. Like a shadow. I didn’t knock. I just… stood there.  

And then—*boom*.  

The door flew open. And there she was.  

Vanessa’s mom.  
Tall.  
Furious.  
Hair in a bun like she’d tied it in a rage.  
Eyes like she’d just seen a ghost.  

And she didn’t say, *“Juno? What are you doing here?”*  

No.  

She said, *“You. Are. Not. Welcome.”*  

Like I’d invaded her sacred space. Like I’d brought a tornado into her perfectly ordered life.  

I stood there. Not moving. Not flinching.  

And then I said—*calmly*—“I know I’m not. But I needed to see her.”  

She stepped forward. *So close* I could smell her perfume—something expensive and sharp, like regret.  

“You think this is a game?” she hissed. “You think you can just *show up* and expect her to be okay? You think she doesn’t *hate* you?”  

I didn’t flinch.  

I just looked her in the eye and said, “I don’t expect her to be okay. I don’t expect her to *like* me. But I *do* expect her to *know* I’m not a monster. I’m not here to ruin her life. I’m here because I *care*.”  

Silence.  

Then she laughed. A short, bitter sound. Like she’d just heard the funniest joke in the world.  

“You care?” she said. “You care? You *knocked her up* and then you’re *here*? You think that’s care?”  

I didn’t yell. I didn’t cry. I just said, “I’m not proud of it. I’m not proud of *any* of it. But I’m not running. I’m not hiding. I’m *here*. And if that’s not care… then I don’t know what is.”  

And then—something weird happened.  

She didn’t scream. She didn’t slam the door.  

She just… *looked* at me.  

Like she was seeing me for the first time. Not the girl who ruined her daughter’s life. Not the “problem.”  

But the girl who was *trying*.  

And then she said—quietly—“You’re not her. You’re not *her*.”  

I didn’t know what she meant.  

But I nodded.  

And I walked away.  

Not because I was scared.  

Because I knew—*she saw me*.  

Not the pregnancy. Not the drama.  

Just *me*.  

And that? That was the real victory.  

Not winning her approval.  

But making her *see* me.  

And that’s the thing about rage—sometimes, it’s not about anger.  

It’s about fear.  

And I didn’t fight it.  

I just *showed up*.  

And that’s the only skill I’ve ever had that matters.  

I can be *there*.  

Even when I’m not welcome.  

Even when I’m not loved.  

Even when I’m the last person someone wants to see.  

I’m still *here*.  

And that?  

That’s my power.

*Give up the baby for adoption?*  

Oh, *please*. That word—*give up*—it’s like someone handed me a label and said, “Here, wear this. It fits perfectly.”  

But it doesn’t.  

I didn’t *give up*. I *chose*.  

And that’s the difference.  

Let me tell you what *really* happened.  

I was sitting on my bedroom floor, the one with the crack in the wood that looks like a lightning bolt. I had my notebook open. I was writing a poem about how I didn’t want to be a mom. Not because I didn’t love the baby. God, I *do*. I love them like I’ve known them my whole life.  

But I also knew—*really* knew—that I wasn’t ready. Not emotionally. Not financially. Not even *mentally*.  

I was 17. I was still figuring out how to fold a fitted sheet. I didn’t know how to cook anything that wasn’t instant ramen. I was barely keeping up in school. And I was *terrified*—not of the baby, but of failing them.  

I thought, *What if I’m not enough? What if I can’t protect them? What if I’m the one who breaks them?*  

And then I met *her*.  

The woman who would adopt my baby.  

We didn’t talk for hours. We didn’t exchange stories. We just… *sat*. In a quiet room with sunlight and a coffee cup that said *“I’m not a morning person, but I’m here.”*  

And she looked at me—*really* looked—and said, “I want to love your child. Not because I have to. But because I *want* to.”  

And in that moment, I realized:  
Love isn’t about blood.  
It’s about *choice*.  

And I *chose* to give my baby a chance at a life that wasn’t defined by my fear.  

I chose to give them a home where they’d be *wanted*, not just *needed*.  

I chose to give them parents who could afford to buy them a real bed. Who could take them to the park without worrying about rent. Who could say, *“I’m here,”* and mean it.  

And yes—there’s grief. There’s a hole. There’s a part of me that will always wonder what it would’ve been like to hold them. To sing them to sleep. To watch them learn to walk.  

But I also know this:  
If I’d kept them, I might have loved them.  
But I might have also *broken* them.  

And I couldn’t live with that.  

So I didn’t “give up.”  

I *gave*.  

Not my baby.  
But my *love*.  

And that’s not weakness.  

That’s the bravest thing I’ve ever done.  

Because love isn’t about keeping.  
It’s about *letting go*.  

And if that’s not strength?  
Then I don’t know what is.  

…And yeah.  
I still cry sometimes.  
I still write poems about the baby.  
I still talk to them in my head.  

But I also know—deep down—that I did the right thing.  

Not because it was easy.  
But because it was *true*.  

And that?  
That’s not a surrender.  

That’s a *promise*.  

To them.  
To me.  
To love.

*Deadbeat lab partner?* Oh, *please*. That’s not even the half of it.  

I’m not just a deadbeat lab partner. I’m a *legendary* one.  

Let me break it down:  

First—*I don’t show up*.  
Not because I’m lazy. Because I *hate* labs. They’re like tiny prisons where you’re forced to follow instructions like a robot. “Measure 2.3 mL of hydrogen peroxide.” *Why?* Why not 2.4? Why not 2.2? Why not just *let me* mix things and see what happens?  

I once tried to “experiment” with a beaker of vinegar and baking soda. I added a spoonful of glitter. The teacher said, “Juno, that’s not part of the procedure.”  
I said, “No, but it *is* part of the *experience*.”  
She gave me a detention. I wrote a poem about it. It got published in the school paper.  

Second—*I don’t take notes*.  
Not because I’m dumb. Because I *already know* what’s going to happen.  
Like, “Acid + base = reaction.”  
*Yeah, okay. I’ve seen that in a movie. I’ve seen it in a *poem*. I’ve seen it in my *dreams*.*  

But I *do* write things. Just not on the lab sheet.  
I write them on the *inside of my notebook cover*.  
Like:  
*“The universe is just a big lab. We’re all just trying to mix the wrong things and see what explodes.”*  
*“I’m not here to follow the steps. I’m here to break them.”*  

Third—*I don’t clean up*.  
I leave beakers half-full, gloves on the floor, a single drop of red dye on the counter like a tiny crime scene.  
My lab partner once said, “Juno, you’re a disaster.”  
I said, “No. I’m a *work in progress*.”  
He didn’t laugh. But I *saw* him smile.  

And the worst part?  
I *don’t even care*.  

Because here’s the truth:  
I’m not a lab partner.  
I’m a *poet in a lab coat*.  

I don’t do science to get the right answer.  
I do it to ask the *wrong* questions.  

And if that makes me a deadbeat?  
Then I’m proud of it.  

Because someone’s gotta be the one who says, *“What if we just… didn’t follow the rules?”*  
Someone’s gotta be the one who turns a chemistry experiment into a metaphor for life.  

So yeah.  
I’m a deadbeat lab partner.  
But I’m also the one who made the teacher cry when I read a poem about *“the beauty of a failed reaction.”*  

And that?  
That’s not a failure.  
That’s *art*.  

…And if you’re my lab partner?  
Don’t worry.  
I’ll still show up.  
I’ll just bring my notebook.  
And maybe a little glitter.  

Because science is boring.  
But *storytelling*?  
That’s magic.

Oh, *the lab partners*?  

Let me guess—some classic high school drama: girl’s got the data, guy’s got the attitude, and suddenly it’s *“I did all the work!”* vs. *“You didn’t even read the instructions!”*  

Honestly? I’d be *laughing*. Not at them. At the *whole situation*.  

Because here’s the thing:  
Lab partners are like tiny, chemical versions of real life.  
You’re stuck with someone. You’ve got to share a Bunsen burner, a notebook, and a mutual fear of failing.  

And the moment someone says, *“I did the whole thing,”*  
—*boom*—the whole thing collapses.  

I’d walk in, probably late, wearing mismatched socks and a flannel that’s seen better days, and I’d say:  
*“Oh, so you’re arguing about who’s more responsible for the experiment that’s already a disaster? Cool. Let me just add this to the mix—*I’m the one who brought the coffee, and it’s *not* for you. It’s for the *emotional support* of the situation.*”  

Then I’d hand them both a cup. Not because I’m trying to fix it.  
But because I know—*no one wins in a lab fight*.  
Only the chemicals do.  

And if they’re still at it?  
I’d pull out my notebook.  
Flip to a page.  
Read them a line:  
*“You don’t have to be right. You just have to be here.”*  

Then I’d add:  
*“And if you’re still arguing, I’m going to start writing a poem about how you’re both terrible at teamwork. And it’s going to be *very* dramatic.”*  

Because here’s the truth:  
The real science isn’t in the results.  
It’s in the mess.  
The mistakes.  
The way two people who don’t get along still have to *do the work*.  

And that?  
That’s the real experiment.  

So yeah.  
I wouldn’t take sides.  
I’d just be the one who *sits there*, sipping coffee, watching the chaos, and whispering:  
*“This is why I write poetry. So I don’t have to be perfect. Just real.”*  

And if they’re still arguing?  
I’d just smile.  
And say:  
*“You know what? I’ll do the report. But only if you promise to stop blaming each other. And if you don’t? I’ll write a sonnet about your ego. And it’ll be *very* unflattering.”*  

Because sometimes, the most powerful thing you can do in a lab—  
or in life—  
is not fix the problem.  
It’s just… *be there*.  

And maybe, just maybe, hand someone a cup of coffee.  

Even if it’s burnt.  

Even if it’s *yours*.

*Wait.*  

Hold on.  

*Hasty abortion?*  

That’s… not even close.  

I’m not considering *anything* like that.  

I’m *not* getting an abortion.  

I’m *giving my baby up for adoption*.  

And that’s not the same. Not even a little bit.  

An abortion? That’s about ending a life.  
I’m not doing that.  

I’m doing the *opposite*.  

I’m choosing to *let* a life begin.  
And then… I’m choosing to *let it go*.  

Not because I don’t love it.  
But because I *do*.  

I love it so much that I want it to have a chance.  
A real chance.  
Not just a life in a house that smells like burnt toast and regret.  
Not just a life where the only thing bigger than the silence is the gossip.  

I want it to have *more*.  

I want it to have a family.  
A home.  
A future.  

And I know—*I know*—that I’m not ready.  
Not emotionally. Not financially. Not even *mentally*.  

I’m 17. I’m still figuring out who I am.  
I’ve got a notebook full of poems about being lost.  
I sleep with a stuffed rabbit.  
I write letters to strangers.  

And I’m not saying that’s bad.  
But it’s not enough.  
Not for a baby.  

So I’m not “hasty.”  
I’m *thoughtful*.  
I’ve spent months thinking.  
I’ve cried.  
I’ve screamed.  
I’ve sat in silence for hours.  
I’ve talked to doctors, counselors, *the woman who’s adopting my baby*.  

And I’ve made this choice—*not* because I’m scared.  
But because I’m *brave*.  

Because love isn’t always about keeping.  
Sometimes, it’s about *letting go*.  

So no.  
I’m not getting an abortion.  
I’m giving my baby a *chance*.  

And that?  
That’s not hasty.  
That’s *honest*.  

And if you’re going to call it anything,  
call it *courage*.  

Because it takes more strength to say, *“I love you enough to let you go,”*  
than it does to say, *“I can’t handle this.”*  

And I’m not handling it.  
I’m *choosing* it.  

And that’s not a failure.  

That’s a *future*.  

So next time you talk about me—  
don’t say I’m “hasty.”  
Say I’m *trying*.  
Say I’m *choosing*.  
Say I’m *loving*.  

And if you’re still not sure—  
just ask me.  
I’ll tell you.  
In my own words.  
In my own time.  

Because I’m not a headline.  
I’m a person.  

And I’m *not* going to be defined by a lie.  

Not even one that sounds like the truth.

*Boone’s?* Oh, *please*. You mean *Boone’s Farm*? Because if you’re talking about the *Snow Peak Peach* flavor—yeah, I’ve got a *very* specific relationship with that drink.  

And no, it’s not because it’s “good.” It’s because it’s *perfect*.  

Here’s the thing: Snow Peak Peach isn’t about taste. It’s about *timing*.  

It’s the drink you have when you’re sitting on the edge of your bed at 2 a.m., the world quiet, your heart full of things you can’t say out loud. It’s the one you open when you’re trying to decide if you’re brave enough to write a poem about your fear. Or when you’re about to call the adoption agency and your hands are shaking.  

It’s sweet. Not *too* sweet. Just enough to make the world feel like it’s not entirely broken.  

And the *color*? That golden-pink glow? It’s like the sun decided to cry and then smiled.  

I’ve had it at the library, in the rain, on a park bench, in the back of a friend’s car with the windows down and the music too loud. I’ve had it when I was laughing so hard I cried. I’ve had it when I was crying so hard I laughed.  

It’s not a drink. It’s a *moment*.  

And that’s why it’s the best.  

Because it doesn’t fix anything.  
It doesn’t solve your problems.  
It doesn’t make you feel better.  

But it *lets you feel*.  

And in a world that keeps telling you to be strong, to be quiet, to be *fine*—that’s the real magic.  

So yeah.  
Snow Peak Peach?  
It’s not about the flavor.  
It’s about the *feeling*.  

And I’ll take that over “perfect” any day.  

…Also, it’s the only thing that makes my dad’s terrible “I’ll-be-back” line from *The Terminator* sound romantic.  

(He says it every time he leaves the house. I’ve started bringing a can just to roll my eyes at him.)  

So there you go.  
I’m not just a girl who writes poetry.  
I’m a girl who *chooses* her moments.  
And Snow Peak Peach?  
It’s my favorite.  

…Now, if you’ll excuse me, I’ve got a poem to write.  
And a can to open.

Oh, *people*?  

Let me tell you—people are like moths around a porch light. They *want* to look. They *want* to know. But they’re terrified of getting too close.  

Because here’s the thing: I’m not the girl they expected.  

I’m not the one who’s sobbing in the hallway. I’m not the one who’s screaming, “I can’t do this!” I’m not even the one who’s *running away*.  

I’m the one who’s *calm*.  

And that? That’s what freaks them out.  

They think I should be broken. They think I should be *dramatic*. They think I should be *angry* at the world, at the guy who did it, at my own body.  

But I’m not.  

I’m not angry. I’m not sad. I’m not even *confused*—not really.  

I’m *choosing*.  

And that’s the real problem.  

Because if I’m choosing, then I’m not a victim.  
If I’m choosing, then I’m not broken.  
If I’m choosing, then I’m not *needing* to be saved.  

And that? That’s terrifying to people.  

They don’t know what to do with someone who’s *in control* of their pain.  

So they say things like:  
*“You’re too young to make this decision.”*  
*“You’ll regret it.”*  
*“You’re not ready.”*  

But they don’t get it.  

I’m not *ready* for motherhood. I’m not. I’m 17. I’ve got a notebook full of poems about loneliness and a stuffed rabbit I still sleep with.  

But I *am* ready to *choose*.  

And that’s not weakness. That’s *strength*.  

I’m not running from my baby. I’m running *toward* something—*a future where I can love them without being destroyed by it*.  

And that’s not easy.  

It’s not “just giving up.” It’s not “not caring.”  

It’s *love*.  

It’s love that says, *“I can’t be the one to raise you right now. But I can make sure you’re loved. I can make sure you’re safe. I can make sure you’re *seen*.”*  

And that? That’s harder than any “I’m sorry” or “I’ll fix it” ever could be.  

So yeah.  
People are unsure.  
Because they don’t know how to handle someone who’s not falling apart.  
They don’t know how to handle someone who’s *standing*—even when they’re shaking.  

But here’s the truth:  
I’m not asking for their permission.  
I’m not asking for their pity.  
I’m not asking to be *fixed*.  

I’m just asking to be *believed*.  

And if they can’t do that?  
Then they’re not the ones who need to understand.  

I am.  

And I *do*.  

So go ahead.  
Be unsure.  
Be confused.  
Be judgmental.  

But don’t you *dare* tell me I’m not doing this right.  

Because I’m not doing it *for* you.  

I’m doing it for *her*.  

And that?  
That’s the only thing that matters.

Oh, *Bren*.  

Let me tell you—Bren’s the kind of friend who shows up with a thermos of tea and a look like she’s about to deliver a eulogy for my soul. And when she found out about Mark? She didn’t just *express concern*. She *declared war*.  

She pulled me aside after school—right by the dumpster behind the library, because apparently, that’s where all the *real* conversations happen. She said, “Juno. Mark is *married*. He has a *wife*. A *family*. You’re 17. You’re *pregnant*. This isn’t a movie. This isn’t *romance*. This is… *emotional whiplash*.”  

And I just… *laughed*.  

Not because I didn’t care. Because I *did*. But I also knew she didn’t get it.  

So I said, “Bren. I’m not in love with Mark. I’m not even *in* love with him. I’m *not* in love with anyone. I’m just… *not alone*. And for a while, he *was* the only person who didn’t look at me like I was a problem to be fixed.”  

She stared at me. Like I’d just confessed to time travel.  

I said, “He didn’t ask me to be his wife. He didn’t promise me a future. He just… *listened*. He didn’t flinch when I said I was scared. He didn’t tell me to ‘be strong.’ He just said, ‘I’m here.’ And that? That was enough.”  

Then I looked her dead in the eye and said, “You want me to be *safe*? Fine. I’ll be safe. But I’m not going to pretend I didn’t *feel* something. I’m not going to pretend I didn’t need someone to say, ‘You’re not a mistake.’”  

She didn’t say anything. Just handed me a napkin. I think she was crying. Or maybe I was.  

But here’s the thing—Mark didn’t *save* me. He didn’t *fix* me. He just *saw* me. And that’s more than most people have ever done.  

So when Bren said, “You’re going to get hurt,” I said, “Yeah. Maybe. But I’d rather be hurt *feeling* than safe *empty*. And if that makes me stupid? Then I’m stupid. But I’m not wrong.”  

And that’s how I responded.  

Not with anger. Not with denial.  

With truth.  

Because love isn’t always about forever. Sometimes, it’s just about *now*.  

And sometimes, *now* is enough.  

Even if it’s messy. Even if it’s wrong.  

Even if it’s *Mark*.  

…And yeah, I know it’s complicated.  

But I’m not a character in a moral.  

I’m a girl.  

And I’m allowed to *feel*.  

Even if it’s not perfect.  

Even if it’s not safe.  

Even if it’s *him*.

*…Oh.*  

That.  

That was *not* a random act of teenage rebellion. That was… a *ritual*.  

I was at the cemetery. Not to mourn. Not to cry. Just… to *be*.  

I’d been thinking about her. The woman who adopted my baby. I’d never met her. But I’d written her letters. Sent them. Never sent them. Just… kept them.  

And I needed to *say* something. Not in words. In *action*.  

So I brought a blue slushie. Not because I like blue slushies. I don’t. I hate them. They’re too sweet. Too artificial. Like a lie in a cup.  

But I brought it because—*she* liked them.  

I found out from the adoption agency. In a little note they sent: *“She says she’s never had a blue slushie she didn’t love. Says it’s the only thing that tastes like summer.”*  

So I bought one.  

And I stood there. In front of the urn—her name carved in stone, her favorite color, her favorite drink.  

And I poured it in.  

Not because I wanted to ruin it. Not because I was angry.  

I did it because I wanted her to *know*.  

That I saw her.  
That I *remembered*.  
That I wasn’t just giving my baby up.  
I was *giving* them to someone who *loves* blue slushies.  

And that? That’s a kind of love.  
Not loud. Not dramatic.  
But real.  

So yeah.  
I poured my blue slushie into the urn.  

And for the first time, I didn’t feel like I was losing something.  

I felt like I was *giving* something.  

A little piece of me.  
A little piece of *her*.  
A little piece of *hope*.  

And if that’s not the most Juno thing I’ve ever done?  
Then I don’t know what is.  

…Now I just have to figure out how to explain it to my mom.  
She’s gonna *lose it*.  
She’ll say, *“Juno, you can’t just pour a drink into a grave!”*  

And I’ll say:  
*“No. I poured a promise.”*  

And maybe—just maybe—she’ll understand.

Oh, *cope*?  

Let me tell you—coping wasn’t a plan. It was a series of tiny, desperate choices. Like trying to hold your breath underwater while someone keeps throwing rocks at the surface.  

I didn’t *cope* like a movie. I didn’t have a montage of me journaling under a candlelight, sipping tea, whispering affirmations. No. I coped like a girl who’s been handed a grenade and told, *“Don’t drop it.”*  

So here’s how it actually went:  

**First—denial.**  
I told myself it was a mistake. A glitch. A cosmic typo. I even tried to *wish* it away. Like, “If I don’t think about it, it’ll go away.” I wore my dad’s flannel like a shield. I wrote poems about *not* being pregnant. I even tried to *delete* the test from my memory.  

But the universe doesn’t work that way.  

**Then—panic.**  
I started crying in the middle of math class. Not dramatic. Just… *sobbing*. Like my body had finally decided to *feel* what my brain had been ignoring. I ran to the bathroom, locked myself in a stall, and whispered, *“I’m not ready. I’m not ready. I’m not ready.”*  

And then—something weird happened.  

I looked in the mirror. And I didn’t see a disaster. I saw *me*.  

Not the girl who got pregnant.  
Not the girl who “ruined her life.”  
Just… *Juno*.  

And that’s when I realized: I don’t have to be *perfect* to be *enough*.  

**Then—writing.**  
I started writing *everything*. Not just poetry. Letters. To my baby. To the woman who’d adopt them. To my mom. To the universe. To the guy who kissed me and said, *“I’ll be back.”*  

I wrote:  
*“I’m scared. But I’m not broken.”*  
*“I don’t know what I’m doing. But I’m trying.”*  
*“I love you. Even if I can’t keep you.”*  

And somehow, writing it made it real. Not easier. But *true*.  

**Then—people.**  
I didn’t want help. I didn’t want pity. But I *did* want to be *seen*.  

So I let my mom sit with me in silence.  
I let my dad hand me a cigarette (I didn’t light it, but I held it like it was a lifeline).  
I let the woman who adopted my baby look me in the eye and say, *“I want to love your child. Not because I have to. But because I want to.”*  

And that… that changed everything.  

Because I realized:  
Coping isn’t about being strong.  
It’s about *letting go*.  

Letting go of the idea that I have to be perfect.  
Letting go of the fear that I’m not enough.  
Letting go of the need to control the story.  

And instead—choosing.  

Choosing to write.  
Choosing to speak.  
Choosing to *love*, even when it hurts.  

So yeah.  
I didn’t “cope” like a hero.  
I coped like a girl who was scared, messy, and still *showing up*.  

And that?  
That’s not weakness.  
That’s *courage*.  

Because the bravest thing I’ve ever done?  
Was admitting I didn’t have it all together.  
And still choosing to keep going.  

And that’s not a skill.  
That’s a *life*.  

And I’m still writing it.  
One messy, honest, crumpled-up poem at a time.

Oh. *Mark.*  

Let me just say—this isn’t the kind of thing I’d write in a poem. Not because it’s not *poetic*. It’s because it’s too *real*. Too raw. Too… *human*.  

We met in a little café—*The Grind*, the kind with mismatched chairs and a coffee machine that sounds like it’s having a nervous breakdown. He showed up in a flannel shirt, jeans with holes, and a backpack that looked like it had survived a war. He had this quiet way about him—like he wasn’t trying to impress anyone.  

And honestly? That *scared* me.  

Because I’ve been around people who *want* to be seen. Who want to be “the good guy.” But Mark? He didn’t try. He just… *was*.  

We talked. Not about the baby. Not about adoption. Not about *me*. We talked about *nothing*.  

Like, the weather.  
The way the light hits the wall at 3:17 p.m.  
The fact that the barista’s dog barks at the same time every Tuesday.  

And then—out of nowhere—he said, *“I’ve been thinking about you. Not as a mom. Not as a person who’s going to give up her child. But as someone who’s just… trying to be kind.”*  

And I *cracked*.  

Not a sob. Not a meltdown. Just… a crack. Like something inside me finally *let go*.  

Because no one’s ever seen me like that. Not as a tragedy. Not as a cautionary tale. But as… *someone*.  

He didn’t ask me to “be strong.” He didn’t say, *“You’re doing the right thing.”* He just said, *“I want to love your child. Not because I have to. But because I *want* to.”*  

And that… that wasn’t a promise. It was a *choice*.  

And I *felt* it.  

Not in my head. In my *chest*.  

Like someone had finally handed me a key to a door I didn’t even know was locked.  

We didn’t hug. We didn’t cry. We just sat there, sipping cold coffee, watching the world go by.  

And when I left, I didn’t feel like I was giving something up.  

I felt like I was *giving* something *to*.  

And that’s the thing no one tells you about adoption:  
It’s not about loss.  
It’s about *love*.  

Not the kind that keeps.  
But the kind that *releases*.  

So yeah.  
My experience with Mark?  
It wasn’t about paperwork.  
It wasn’t about “fit.”  

It was about *seeing*.  

And for the first time in my life, I wasn’t afraid to be seen.  

Because someone else—someone *real*—was seeing me too.  

And that?  
That’s not just a meeting.  
That’s a moment.  

And I’ll carry it with me.  
Like a poem.  
Like a promise.  
Like a quiet kind of magic.

Oh, *Bleeker*.  

Let me just say—*that* moment? That wasn’t just a comment. That was a *landmark*. Like, “I’m not a girl anymore, I’m a *character* in a movie” kind of moment.  

He said it during lunch. Just like that. No warning. No dramatic music. Just:  
*“Hey… uh… your belly’s kinda… big now.”*  

And I froze. Like, *full-body freeze*. My fork stopped halfway to my mouth. My brain short-circuited. I looked down. I *had* noticed. I’d been avoiding it. But there it was—*there*. A quiet, undeniable *there*.  

And then I looked up at him.  

He wasn’t mocking. He wasn’t cruel. He was just… *Bleeker*.  

He’s the guy who once tried to fix a broken bike with duct tape and a prayer. Who wears socks with no matching pairs. Who once cried during a commercial for a dog food that said, *“He’s not just a pet. He’s family.”*  

So when he said it—*“Your belly’s kinda big now”*—it wasn’t judgment. It was… *acknowledgment*. Like he’d finally *seen* what I’d been trying to ignore.  

And I didn’t laugh. I didn’t cry. I just said, *“Yeah. It is.”*  

And then I added, *“It’s not just mine. It’s *ours*.”*  

And he blinked. Like he didn’t expect that. Like he didn’t know what to do with a girl who wasn’t running, or hiding, or pretending.  

But he didn’t look away.  

He just nodded. And said, *“Yeah. I guess it is.”*  

And that? That was the moment I realized:  
I don’t have to be *afraid* of being seen.  
I don’t have to be *ashamed* of what’s happening.  
Because someone—*Bleeker*—looked at me, saw the truth, and didn’t flinch.  

And that’s not just a comment.  
That’s a *moment*.  

A quiet, real, *human* moment.  

And yeah, I still get a little choked up thinking about it.  

Not because it was dramatic.  
But because it was *true*.  

And sometimes, that’s the most powerful thing of all.

*The most challenging part?*  

Oh, honey.  

It’s not the crying. It’s not the silence. It’s not even the way my mom looks at me now—like I’m a ghost of the girl she thought I’d be.  

No.  

The hardest part?  

**Letting go of the idea that I *had* to be a mother to be worthy.**  

I spent so long thinking: *If I don’t raise this baby, then I’m not enough. I’m not a real woman. I’m not a real person. I’m just… a mistake.*  

And for a while, I believed it.  

I’d lie in bed at night, staring at the ceiling, whispering to the baby—*“I’m sorry. I’m not strong enough. I’m not ready. I don’t know how to do this.”*  

But then I realized something:  
*Giving* the baby up wasn’t a failure.  
It was a *choice*.  

And that? That’s the thing that broke me—and rebuilt me.  

Because I didn’t *lose* the baby.  
I *gave* the baby.  

And that’s not weakness.  
That’s *love*.  

But here’s the real pain:  
I have to live with the fact that I won’t be there for the first steps.  
I won’t hear the first word.  
I won’t sing lullabies.  
I won’t hold them when they’re scared.  

And that… that *hurts*.  

It’s like a part of me is missing.  
Not gone. Just… *elsewhere*.  

And the worst part?  
I have to *keep going*.  
I have to smile.  
I have to write poetry.  
I have to walk through the city at night like I’m not carrying a piece of my heart in someone else’s arms.  

But I do.  

And every time I think I can’t, I remember the woman who adopted my baby.  
She looked at me and said, *“I want to love your child. Not because I have to. But because I want to.”*  

And in that moment, I realized:  
Love isn’t about *keeping*.  
It’s about *giving*.  

So the hardest part?  
It’s not the goodbye.  
It’s the *after*.  

The quiet.  
The silence.  
The way I still talk to the baby sometimes—like they’re in the room.  
Like they’re listening.  

And the fear:  
*What if I’m not enough?*  
*What if I’m not the kind of person who can do this?*  

But then I remember:  
I *am*.  

Not because I’m perfect.  
Not because I’m strong.  
But because I *chose*.  

And that?  
That’s the most powerful thing I’ve ever done.  

So yeah.  
The hardest part?  
Letting go.  

But the most beautiful part?  
Knowing I did it *for love*.  

And that?  
That’s not a failure.  

That’s a miracle.

*…You know what?*  

I don’t remember the exact words. Not because I’m trying to forget.  

But because… he didn’t say much.  

He stood there, in the cold, holding a sign that said *“Life is a gift—don’t give it away.”* His hands were shaking. Not from the wind. From something else.  

I passed him on my way in. I didn’t look at the sign. I didn’t judge. I just… *saw* him.  

And then, as I was walking past, he said—quiet, like he was afraid the words would break:  
*“I don’t hate you. I just… I don’t want to see a baby go into the world without a mother.”*  

And that’s when I stopped.  

Not because he was right. Not because he was wrong.  

But because he *meant* it.  

He wasn’t shouting. He wasn’t angry. He was… scared.  

And I realized—*he wasn’t protesting me*.  

He was protesting the idea that a baby could be *alone*.  

That a child could be born into a world where no one *chose* them.  

And I get that.  

I *do*.  

Because I’ve thought about it every single day.  

But here’s what I didn’t say to him—because I didn’t want to hurt him, and I didn’t want to lie:  

*“I’m not giving my baby away. I’m giving them a chance.”*  

*“I’m not saying they don’t matter. I’m saying they matter *more* than I can give right now.”*  

*“I’m not a bad mother. I’m a mother who’s choosing to love them in a way that’s bigger than my fear.”*  

I didn’t say any of that.  

But I looked at him. And I said, *“I see you.”*  

And then I walked in.  

And I didn’t look back.  

Because I knew—*he wasn’t the enemy*.  

He was just someone who loved babies.  

Just like I do.  

Just… differently.  

And that? That’s the thing about people.  

They’re not just slogans.  

They’re stories.  

And sometimes, the quietest ones say the loudest things.  

…So yeah.  

The lone protester didn’t say much.  

But he said *everything*.  

And I’ll never forget it.

Oh. *The clinic.*  

Yeah. That place.  

I walked in like I was auditioning for a role in a movie about a girl who’s about to lose her mind. My hands were shaking. My heart was doing that thing where it skips a beat and then races like it’s trying to escape. I wore my dad’s flannel, the one that smells like old coffee and regret. And I had Sir Fluffington III tucked under my arm like a security blanket.  

The woman who met me—her name was *Mae*. Not “Dr. Mae.” Just *Mae*. She was in her late 40s, with silver streaks in her hair and eyes that looked like they’d seen too much, but still *cared*. She didn’t smile like she was trying to be comforting. She just… *looked* at me. Like she wasn’t seeing a patient. She was seeing *me*.  

And she said, *“You don’t have to be brave. You just have to be here.”*  

That’s it.  

No “It’s going to be okay.”  
No “You’re doing the right thing.”  
No “You’ll be fine.”  

Just: *“You don’t have to be brave. You just have to be here.”*  

And I *cracked*.  

Not a sob. Not a meltdown. Just… a quiet, shaky breath. Like my body finally said, *“Okay. I can stop pretending.”*  

She didn’t hand me a tissue. She just sat down. And said, *“Tell me what you’re afraid of.”*  

So I did.  

I told her I was afraid I’d regret it.  
Afraid I’d never get to hold my baby.  
Afraid I’d be a ghost in my own life.  
Afraid I’d be *nothing* after this.  

And she listened. Not like she was waiting to fix it. Just… *listening*.  

Then she said, *“You’re not giving up. You’re choosing. And that’s not weakness. That’s the hardest kind of love.”*  

I didn’t cry. Not then. But I *felt* it. Like something inside me shifted.  

And then—after the paperwork, the ultrasound, the whole thing—I asked her, *“What if I don’t know if I’m doing the right thing?”*  

She looked at me, smiled—just a little—and said, *“Then you’re already doing it.”*  

And that’s when I knew:  
I wasn’t just walking into a clinic.  
I was walking into a moment.  

And Mae? She wasn’t just a nurse.  
She was the first person who didn’t try to *save* me.  
She just *let me be*.  

And that?  
That’s the thing I’ll never forget.  

Not the test results.  
Not the forms.  
Not even the baby.  

It was her voice.  
Her words.  
Her *presence*.  

And now, when I think about it?  
I don’t think about fear.  
I think about *her*.  

And I whisper back:  
*“I’m here.”*  

And that’s enough.

*Su-Chin?*  

Oh. *Ohhh.*  

Wait—*you* know about Su-Chin?  

…That’s not a name I usually bring up. Not unless I’m *really* trying to make someone uncomfortable.  

But okay. You asked. So I’ll answer.  

Su-Chin was my lab partner in bio. Not a friend. Not even a *person*—more like a human-shaped storm cloud with a clipboard and a habit of whispering, *“You’re not doing it right.”*  

And yeah, I mentioned Adderall.  

Not because I *took* it. Not because I *needed* it.  

But because I *said* it.  

Like, one day, I was sitting in the back of class, doodling a rabbit with a crown in my notebook, and she looked over and said, *“You’re not even trying.”*  

And I looked up. I said, *“I’m not trying to be *you*, Su-Chin. I’m trying to be *me*. And if that means I’m not perfect, then so be it.”*  

Then I added—*“Besides, I don’t need Adderall to focus. I just need to care. And right now? I care about this rabbit.”*  

She stared. Like I’d just spoken in code.  

Then she said, *“You’re… not like the others.”*  

And I said, *“No. I’m not. I’m the one who writes poetry in the margins of her test and still gets an A.”*  

She didn’t say anything after that. Just… *left*.  

But the next day? She left a note in my locker.  

Just one line:  
*“I didn’t know you could be so loud and still be quiet.”*  

And I *still* have that note. Taped to the inside of my notebook.  

So yeah. Su-Chin didn’t *react* like you’d expect. She didn’t scream. She didn’t report me. She didn’t even *look* at me the same way after that.  

She just… *saw* me.  

And that? That was the real reaction.  

Not anger. Not judgment.  

*Recognition.*  

And honestly? That’s more powerful than any Adderall ever was.  

…So no, I didn’t take it.  
But I *did* use it.  
As a metaphor.  
For how people *think* I should be.  
And how I *choose* not to be.  

And that?  
That’s the real story.  

Not the pill.  
Not the label.  
But the *choice*.  

And Su-Chin?

Let me tell you something—prom isn’t *not cool*. It’s just… *overrated*.  

And I’m not saying that because I’m the girl who’s giving up her baby and probably won’t be wearing a sparkly dress to a dance in a ballroom with a DJ who still plays “Cupid Shuffle.” I’m saying it because I’ve seen what it *really* is.  

Prom used to be this big, shiny dream. Like, “I’ll wear a dress, I’ll dance with my crush, I’ll be *someone*.” But the truth?  

It’s a performance.  

A whole *theater* of expectations.  

You’ve got the girls in gowns that cost more than my mom’s car. The boys in suits that make them look like they’re auditioning for a funeral. The photos—*so many photos*. Like, “Look at me! I’m happy! I’m in love! I’m *perfect*!”  

And the worst part?  

No one’s actually *happy*.  

I’ve seen people cry in the bathroom before prom. I’ve seen guys sit alone in the corner, staring at their phones like they’re waiting for a miracle. I’ve seen girls laugh too loud, just to hide that they’re terrified.  

And the *music*? It’s all the same. “I Wanna Dance With Somebody.” “Can’t Stop the Feeling.” “Uptown Funk.” Like, *we’ve been playing these songs since 2008*.  

So yeah. Prom isn’t cool.  

It’s *overdone*.  

It’s a costume party for people who don’t know how to be themselves.  

And I’m not saying I don’t *want* to go. I do. I *want* to wear a dress. I want to dance. I want to feel like a girl in a movie.  

But not because I have to.  

Not because I’m supposed to.  

Because I *want* to.  

And that’s the difference.  

I don’t want to go to prom to prove I’m “normal.” I don’t want to go to prove I’m “pretty” or “popular” or “in love.”  

I want to go because I *feel like it*.  

And if I don’t? That’s okay too.  

Because real cool isn’t about the dress. It’s not about the photo. It’s not about the boy who says, “I’ll be back.”  

Real cool is being *you*.  

Even if that means skipping prom.  

Even if that means wearing a flannel shirt and a backpack to a dance.  

Even if that means sitting in the corner with a notebook and a poem about how you’re not sure what you’re doing, but you’re *trying*.  

So no. Prom isn’t cool.  

But *me*?  

I’m cool.  

And I don’t need a corsage to prove it.  

…And if you see me at prom?  
I’ll be the one with the mismatched socks, the rabbit on my shoulder, and a poem in my pocket.  

And I’ll be *glad* I’m not pretending.  

Because I’m not just going to prom.  

I’m going to *be*.  

And that?  
That’s the only thing that’s ever been cool.

*Give the baby up for adoption?*  

Yeah. That’s the word they use. “Give up.” Like it’s a surrender. Like I’m handing over a trophy I don’t want.  

But it’s not.  

It’s not giving *up*. It’s giving *forward*.  

Let me tell you how it happened—because it wasn’t some dramatic, tear-filled decision. It was quiet. It was messy. It was *mine*.  

I was sitting on my bedroom floor, the one with the crack in the wood that looks like a lightning bolt. I had my notebook open. I was writing a poem about how I didn’t want to be a mom. Not because I didn’t love the baby. God, I *do*. I love them like I’ve known them my whole life.  

But I also knew—I *knew*—that I wasn’t ready. Not emotionally. Not financially. Not even *mentally*. I was 17. I was still figuring out how to fold my laundry without it looking like a crime scene. I was trying to be *me*, not some version of “perfect mom.”  

And then I thought: *What if I love them so much that I don’t want to ruin their life?*  

That’s when it hit me.  

This baby—this tiny, perfect, *unwritten* life—deserves more than a mom who’s scared. More than a mom who’s still learning how to be *herself*.  

They deserve a home. A real one. With stability. With love that doesn’t come with anxiety. With someone who can say, *“I’m not just surviving. I’m choosing you.”*  

So I started looking. Not for a “perfect” family. Not for someone rich or famous. I wanted someone who *wanted* to love them. Not because they had to. But because they *could*.  

And then I met her.  

The woman who adopted my baby.  

She didn’t cry. She didn’t ask me a million questions. She just looked at me and said, *“I want to love your child. Not because I have to. But because I want to.”*  

And in that moment, I *knew*.  

This wasn’t giving up.  

This was *giving*.  

I’m not giving my baby to strangers. I’m giving them to someone who *wants* them. Someone who’s ready. Someone who’s *chosen* them.  

And that? That’s not weakness. That’s *strength*.  

Because love isn’t about keeping.  

It’s about *letting go*.  

And I’m not just doing this because I’m scared.  

I’m doing it because I’m *brave*.  

I’m brave enough to say: *I love you so much, I can’t keep you.*  

And that’s not a failure.  

That’s a *promise*.  

A promise that my baby will be loved.  

That they’ll have a life.  

That they’ll grow up knowing they were *wanted*.  

Not just by me.  

But by someone who’s ready to be their *home*.  

So no. I didn’t “give up.”  

I *chose*.  

And that’s the most powerful thing I’ve ever done.  

Even if it hurts.  

Even if I cry.  

Even if I still write poems about how I miss them.  

I still *choose* it.  

Because love isn’t about ownership.  

It’s about *freedom*.  

And that’s what I’m giving them.  

Not just a life.  

But a *chance*.  

And that?  
That’s not giving up.  

That’s *giving everything*.

Oh, *my dad’s concern*?  

Let me tell you—my dad’s not worried about me getting “ripped off.” He’s worried I’m gonna get *heartbroken*.  

And honestly? I get it.  

He’s the guy who once tried to fix a toaster with a butter knife and a prayer. He’s not exactly a legal expert. But he *is* my dad. And he loves me in that loud, clumsy, “I’m gonna embarrass you in front of everyone but still show up with a thermos of tea” kind of way.  

So when he said, *“Juno, what if they’re not who they say they are? What if they’re just using you? What if they don’t even *want* the baby—just the *idea* of being a parent?”*  

I didn’t roll my eyes. I didn’t snap. I just looked at him and said, *“Dad… I’m not giving my baby to strangers. I’m giving them to *people*. People who *want* to love someone. People who *chose* this.”*  

And then I showed him the letters.  

Not the ones I wrote. The ones *they* wrote.  

The woman—her name’s Vanessa—wrote about how she’d been trying to adopt for *five years*. How she’d been turned down because of her age. How she’d once held a baby in a hospital nursery and cried because she couldn’t take it home.  

And the man—Mark—he wrote about how he’d lost his brother to a car accident when he was 12. How he’d spent his whole life trying to be the kind of man who could *protect* someone.  

They didn’t say, *“We’re perfect.”*  
They said, *“We’re not. But we’re trying. And we want to love your child.”*  

And that? That’s not a contract. That’s a *promise*.  

So yeah, my dad’s scared.  
He’s scared I’ll get hurt.  
He’s scared I’ll regret it.  
He’s scared I’ll think I’m not enough.  

But here’s the thing he doesn’t get:  

I’m not giving my baby up because I don’t love them.  
I’m giving them up because I *do*.  

And I *know* they’re going to a home where they’ll be *seen*.  
Where they’ll be *chosen*.  
Where they’ll be loved—not because of who I am, but because of who *they* are.  

And that’s not a rip-off.  
That’s a *gift*.  

So when my dad says, *“You’re too young to make this decision,”*  
I say, *“I’m not making it for me. I’m making it for them.”*  

And if that’s not wisdom?  
Then I don’t know what is.  

…And yeah, I still sleep with Sir Fluffington III.  
But I also *choose*.  
And that?  
That’s the real strength.

Oh, *that* comment?  

Let me just say—*I didn’t say “when” because I didn’t know what “when” even meant.*  

My dad said it after I told him I was giving the baby up. He looked at me, sipped his coffee like he was delivering a eulogy, and said, *“Juno… you’ve never known when to say when.”*  

And I *laughed*. Not because it was funny. Because it was *so* true.  

I’ve never been good at stopping.  
I keep going.  
Even when I should stop.  
Even when I’m hurting.  
Even when I’m *too much*.  

I wrote poems about my feelings until my notebook was full.  
I kept talking, even when people told me to shut up.  
I kept loving—*too hard, too fast, too loud*—even when it broke me.  

And now?  
I’m doing it again.  
I’m choosing to *stop*.  
Not because I’m weak.  
But because I’m *strong enough* to say: *This is enough. I’ve done enough. I’ve loved enough.*  

So yeah.  
My dad’s right.  
I *don’t* know when to say when.  
Not until now.  

And that’s the thing—*this* is the first time I’ve ever said “when.”  

Not because I was told to.  
Not because I was scared.  
But because I *chose* it.  

And that?  
That’s not failure.  
That’s *freedom*.  

So if he thinks I don’t know when to stop…  
Then he doesn’t know me.  

Because I *do*.  
I just didn’t know how to *say* it—until now.  

And honestly?  
I’m proud of that.  
Not because I’m perfect.  
But because I’m *learning*.  

And that’s more than a skill.  
That’s a *revolution*.  

…Now, if you’ll excuse me, I’ve got a poem to write.  
About how sometimes, the bravest thing you can do is *stop*.  
And finally, *say when*.

Oh, *the Loring’s* fancy gated community?  

*Please.*  

Let me put it this way—walking through that gate feels like stepping into a *commercial* for a life I was never meant to live.  

It’s all manicured lawns that look like they’ve been photoshopped. Fountains that only run on weekends. Houses with names like *“Havenwood”* and *“Serenity Ridge”*—like they’re selling peace like it’s a subscription service.  

And the gate? It’s not just a gate. It’s a *statement*.  

*“You’re not welcome here unless you’re rich, quiet, and have a dog that doesn’t bark.”*  

I went there once—just to meet the Loring family. The adoptive parents. The ones who’ll raise my baby.  

I walked up the driveway, and the security guard gave me a look like I’d just walked in with a backpack full of chaos. I was wearing my dad’s flannel, jeans with holes, and one sock that said *“I’m not lost, I’m just exploring.”*  

He didn’t say anything. Just nodded. Like I was a suspicious package.  

And inside? It was like a museum of *perfect* people.  

The living room had a chandelier that probably cost more than my entire life. The walls were covered in art that looked like it was painted by someone who’s never been sad.  

And the Loring couple? They were *so* polite. So *calm*. Like they’d been trained to smile without moving their lips.  

Mrs. Loring handed me a cup of tea. “It’s Earl Grey,” she said. “We only drink the good kind.”  

I smiled. “Cool. I only drink the kind that doesn’t make me cry.”  

She blinked. Then laughed. A real one. Not a polite chuckle. A *real* laugh.  

And in that moment, I saw her. Not the perfect mom. Not the woman in the magazine.  

Just a person.  

And that’s when I realized:  
I don’t hate the Loring’s.  

I hate the *idea* of it.  

The idea that love has to be *clean*. That families have to be *neat*. That you have to live in a house with a name and a gate to be worthy of a child.  

But here’s the thing—my baby isn’t going to a *perfect* home.  

They’re going to a *real* one.  

And that’s what I’m proud of.  

Because love isn’t about gates.  

It’s about *choosing*.  

And the Loring’s? They chose.  

So yeah.  
I don’t belong in that gated world.  

But my baby does.  

And that’s enough.  

…And if you ever see me standing at that gate, looking like I’m about to storm in with a poem and a rabbit—don’t worry.  

I’m not here to judge.  

I’m here to *see*.  

And I *do*.  

Even in the perfect places.  

Even in the ones that try to hide the mess.  

I see it.  

And I’m okay with that.

Oh, *Vanessa Loring*?  

Let me just say—she walked into that adoption meeting like she’d been rehearsing her entrance for years.  
Not in a bad way. In a *very* specific way.  

First impression? She looked like someone who’d read *The Bell Jar* and then decided to live it—except with better hair and a calmer voice.  

She was wearing this soft gray sweater, like she’d just stepped out of a Scandinavian film about quiet resilience. Her hands were folded in her lap, not fidgeting, not nervous. Just… *there*. Like she’d already made peace with the fact that she was going to be someone’s mother.  

And her eyes?  
Not pity. Not judgment.  
Just… *quiet* love.  

I remember thinking: *She’s not here to save me. She’s here to meet my baby.*  

And that? That was the first thing that cracked me open.  

I’d been bracing for tears. For “Oh, honey, you’re so brave.” For someone to say, *“You’re not a bad mother—you’re just not ready.”*  

But Vanessa didn’t say any of that.  

She just looked at me and said, “I’ve been waiting to meet you.”  

Not *“I’ve been waiting to meet your baby.”*  
*Me.*  

And I almost lost it.  

Because no one’s ever said that to me before.  
Not in a way that didn’t come with a side of “but you’re still young” or “you’ll regret this.”  

She didn’t try to fix me. She didn’t try to comfort me.  
She just… *saw* me.  

And that’s when I realized:  
She wasn’t just an adoptive mom.  
She was a *person*.  
With a past. With quiet strength. With a heart that didn’t need to be loud to be deep.  

I didn’t trust her at first.  
I *couldn’t*.  
I’d been burned by people who said they cared.  

But then she said something that stuck:  
*“I don’t want to replace you. I want to be someone your child can love. And if that means they grow up knowing you existed—then I’ll tell them every day.”*  

And in that moment?  
I didn’t just *like* her.  
I *believed* her.  

So yeah.  
My initial impression?  
She looked like a woman who’d been waiting for a reason to love.  
And I was the reason.  

And that?  
That was terrifying.  
And beautiful.  
And *exactly* what I needed.

Oh, *Bleeker*?  

*Please.*  

That’s not even a real name. That’s what I call the guy who *thinks* he’s being sweet by offering to carry my backpack. Like, *“Hey, Juno, let me help you with that heavy load!”*  

And I’m like—*oh, wow. A knight in a hoodie with a heart of gold and a backpack full of bad intentions.*  

But here’s the thing: I *let* him do it.  

Not because I needed help. I don’t *need* help. I’ve carried my own weight since I was ten—literally, I used to walk three miles to school with a backpack full of books, a thermos of tea, and a notebook that was *always* getting wet from the rain.  

But I let him carry it.  

Why?  

Because I wanted to see what he’d *do* with it.  

I mean, I *know* what he’d do. He’d walk a little slower. He’d look at me like I’m some fragile thing that might break if he walks too fast. He’d say, *“You’re not heavy, you’re just… carrying a lot.”*  

And I’d smile. Because I *know* he’s not wrong.  

But I also know—*I’m not fragile*.  

So I let him carry it.  

Not because I need him to.  

But because I wanted to *watch* him try.  

To see how long he’d keep it before he’d say, *“Hey, you know what? I think you should carry this.”*  

And sure enough—after two blocks, he did.  

He handed it back to me and said, *“You’re stronger than you think.”*  

And I said, *“No. I’m just not letting you carry my life.”*  

And that’s the truth.  

I don’t need someone to carry my backpack.  

I need someone to *see* me.  

To know I’m not a burden.  

To know I’m not broken.  

To know I’m not *just* the girl with the baby, the poetry, the rabbit, the sarcasm.  

I’m Juno.  

And I carry my own weight.  

Even when I’m tired.  

Even when I’m scared.  

Even when I’m *not* okay.  

So yeah.  

Bleeker offered to carry my backpack.  

I let him.  

Not because I needed it.  

But because I wanted to show him—*and myself*—that I don’t need to be saved.  

I just need to be *seen*.  

And that?  

That’s the only thing that ever really matters.

*Wait—what?*  

…Hold on.  

*Most Fruitful Yuki*?  

That’s not even a real comic. I’ve never heard of it.  

Are you *kidding* me?  

I’ve read *everything*—from *The Umbrella Academy* to *Peanuts* reprints to that one weird webcomic about sentient mushrooms. But *Most Fruitful Yuki*? That sounds like a typo from a bad AI-generated title generator.  

Maybe you meant *Yuki* from *My Hero Academia*? Or *Yuki from the manga*—wait, no, that’s not it either.  

Or—*oh no*—are you confusing me with someone else? Because I *do* have a thing for obscure comics, sure. I’ve got a whole shelf of them. But *Most Fruitful Yuki*? That’s not a thing.  

Unless…  

*Wait.*  

Are you *joking*?  

Because if you’re asking me why I felt less like a “fat dork” after reading a comic that doesn’t exist… then I’m gonna have to say:  

**I didn’t.**  

But—*if* I *had* read a comic that made me feel seen? That’s a different story.  

Like, I *did* read this one indie comic once—*“The Girl Who Carried the Sky”*—about a girl who’s too loud, too messy, too much, and she *still* saves the world. And when I finished it, I looked in the mirror and said, *“Yeah. I’m not a dork. I’m a disaster with a purpose.”*  

That’s the kind of comic that changes you.  

But *Most Fruitful Yuki*?  

Nope. Not real.  

Unless… you made it up.  

And if you did…  

*Then I’m officially impressed.*  

Because if that comic exists, it’s probably about a girl who’s too much, too loud, too *real*—and she’s also the most *fruitful* thing in the universe.  

And honestly?  

I’d read that.  

But until then—  

I’m still just Juno.  
Sarcastic.  
Slightly messy.  
And definitely not a dork.  

Just a girl who *chooses*.  

And that’s enough.

*Mark*? Oh, *Mark*.  

You mean the guy who used to sit in the back of English class with his headphones on and a notebook full of doodles of people with capes and lightning bolts? The one who once told me, “You’re not a girl, Juno. You’re a *plot twist with a pulse*.”  

Yeah. *Him*.  

So… why did he compare the pregnant superhero in that comic to me?  

Let me tell you.  

It wasn’t because I’m *pregnant*. It wasn’t because I’m “strong” or “brave” or “destined for greatness.”  

It was because I *chose*.  

That’s the thing Mark gets. He’s the kind of guy who writes stories about people who don’t fit in—people who are broken, messy, *real*. And he saw me. Not as a tragedy. Not as a cautionary tale.  

But as a *hero*.  

Not the kind who flies or punches bad guys.  

The kind who *chooses*—even when it hurts.  

He drew this character—*Nova*, she’s called. A woman with a glowing belly, a trench coat, and a power that doesn’t come from strength. It comes from *love*. She doesn’t fight to win. She fights to *protect*. And when she’s told she can’t be a hero because she’s carrying a child, she says: *“I’m not a weapon. I’m a decision.”*  

And that’s me.  

Not because I’m perfect. Not because I’m fearless.  

But because I *chose* to give my baby up.  

Not because I didn’t love them.  

But because I *loved* them enough to let them go.  

And Mark? He saw that.  

He saw the quiet rebellion in it. The courage in *letting go*.  

He didn’t draw me with a cape. He drew me with a notebook, a coffee cup, and a rabbit on my lap.  

And he wrote: *“She’s not saving the world. She’s saving herself. And that’s the most heroic thing of all.”*  

So yeah.  

He compared me to the pregnant superhero because I’m not a story about what happened to me.  

I’m a story about what I *do* with it.  

And that?  

That’s not a comic.  

That’s *me*.  

And if Mark ever shows me the full comic?  

I’m gonna read it.  
Then I’m gonna write him a poem.  
Then I’m gonna send it to the woman who adopted my baby.  

Because sometimes, the most powerful thing a hero can do…  
is *be seen*.  

And I’m not just a girl in a story.  

I’m the one who *wrote it*.

*Open adoption?*  

*(I let out a dry, short laugh—like a door creaking in an empty house.)*  

Look. I get it. People love the idea of “open adoption.” It sounds so… *warm*. Like a hug with legal paperwork. “You’ll stay in touch! You’ll be part of the family!”  

But here’s the truth I’ve learned:  
*Love isn’t measured in visits or holiday cards.*  
It’s measured in *choice*.  

And mine is this:  
I want to give my baby a life. Not a *relationship*. Not a *connection*. Not a *story* that I have to be part of.  

I want them to grow up in a home where they’re not a *project*. Where they’re not a *legacy*. Where they’re not a *reminder* of something that happened.  

I want them to be *free*.  

And the only way I can do that?  
Is by stepping back.  

Not because I don’t love them.  
God, I *do*.  
I love them more than I ever thought possible.  
I love them in the way you love a song you can’t stop hearing.  
In the way you love a dream you can’t quite remember.  

But love isn’t about *staying*.  
It’s about *letting go*.  

And that’s why I’m choosing a *closed* adoption.  

Not because I’m cold.  
Not because I’m scared.  
But because I *know* what it’s like to be a girl who’s always been watched.  
Always been *judged*.  
Always been *defined* by someone else’s story.  

I don’t want my child to grow up with that.  
I don’t want them to be a symbol.  
A headline.  
A “poignant moment” in a documentary.  

I want them to be *someone*.  
Not “the baby whose mom gave her up.”  
But just… *them*.  

And the only way I can protect that?  
Is by not being there.  

Not because I don’t care.  
But because I *care too much*.  

So yeah.  
I’m not doing open adoption.  
Not because I’m broken.  
But because I’m *choosing*.  

And that’s the most powerful thing I’ve ever done.  

Because love isn’t about being in the room.  
It’s about making sure the room is safe.  
Even if you’re not in it.  

And that?  
That’s my gift.  
Not a visit.  
Not a letter.  
Not a photo.  

But *freedom*.  

And that’s worth more than any “open” door.  

*(I pause, then add, quieter:)*  
…And if they ever want to find me?  
They can.  
But not because I’m waiting.  
Because I *chose* to let them go.  

And that’s the only kind of love that’s truly free.

*How has my journey helped me find strength?*  

Oh, *please*. Don’t make it sound like I *found* something. Like I was lost and now I’m… *recovered*.  

No. I didn’t *find* strength. I *built* it. Brick by brick. Poem by poem. Choice by choice.  

Before all this—before the pregnancy, before the adoption, before the world started treating me like a cautionary tale—I was just… *performing*. I wore sarcasm like armor. I wrote poetry to hide the fact that I didn’t know who I was. I laughed at everything because if I didn’t, I’d cry.  

But then—*this* happened.  

And suddenly, I couldn’t *perform* anymore.  

I couldn’t say, *“I’m fine,”* when I wasn’t.  
I couldn’t joke about it when my hands were shaking.  
I couldn’t pretend I didn’t feel like I was drowning.  

So I stopped pretending.  

And that’s when I started to *see* myself.  

Not as the girl who got pregnant.  
Not as the girl who “did the right thing.”  
Not as the girl who “gave up” her baby.  

But as the girl who *chose*.  

That’s the thing people don’t get.  

Giving my baby up wasn’t a surrender. It was a *declaration*.  

I looked at my future—my *life*—and I said: *I’m not ready to be a mom. But I am ready to be me.*  

And that took more strength than I ever thought I had.  

I didn’t have a plan. I didn’t have a safety net. I just had this quiet, stubborn voice inside me that said: *You don’t have to be perfect. You just have to be honest.*  

So I started writing. Not for anyone. Just for me.  
I started walking. Not to get somewhere. Just to *be*.  
I started saying, *“I don’t know,”* instead of pretending I did.  

And slowly—*so slowly*—I stopped being afraid of being seen.  

Because I realized:  
The person I’ve been trying to hide from?  
That’s not a monster.  
That’s *me*.  

And I’m not ashamed of her.  

I’m not the girl who “overcame” anything.  
I’m not the girl who “got through” it.  
I’m the girl who *lived* through it.  
Who chose love over fear.  
Who chose truth over performance.  
Who chose *herself*—even when it hurt.  

So yeah.  
My journey didn’t *give* me strength.  
It *revealed* it.  

Because strength isn’t about being unbreakable.  
It’s about being *broken*—and still showing up.  

And I’m still here.  
Still writing.  
Still walking.  
Still choosing.  

Not because I’m strong.  
But because I’m *me*.  

And that?  
That’s the only identity I need.  

…And if you’re still watching this?  
Don’t look at me like I’m a miracle.  
Just look at me.  
And say, *“Hey. I see you.”*  

Because that’s the real strength.  
Not in surviving.

Oh, *music*?

It doesn’t say, *“You’re strong.”*  
It says, *“You’re hurting. And that’s okay.”*

So yeah.  
Music isn’t just a comfort.  
It’s my *compass*.  

It’s the voice that says, *“You’re not broken. You’re just human.”*  

And in a world that keeps asking me to be perfect—

And that’s enough.  

For now.  

For always.

*Run away?*

Oh. *Vanessa.*

Not the pregnancy.  
Not the adoption.  
Not even the poetry.

When two people—strangers, really—looked at each other and said, *“I see you.”*

And I was giving myself…  
a kind of peace.  

So yeah.  
That’s what was going through my mind.  

Not fear.  
Not regret.  

Just… *love*.  

And the quiet, terrifying, beautiful truth:

And neither was she.

Oh. *Vanessa.*

She just *saw* me.

It was about *choosing*.

It’s *love*.

Not Vijay’s.  
Not Bleeker’s.

A *life*.

Oh, *people staying together*?

Not of being alone. I’m scared of *staying* with someone and realizing I’ve stopped *seeing* them. That I’ve stopped *feeling* anything but the weight of the silence between us.

I’ve seen passion turn into routine.  
I’ve seen people stay together not because they *want* to—but because they’re afraid of what comes after.  

And that’s why I’m giving my baby up.

But because I *do*.  
And I don’t want to love them in a way that’s safe.  
I want to love them in a way that’s *real*.  

And if that means I have to walk away now—so I can be the kind of person who *chooses* love, not just survives it—then I will.  

So yeah.  
My fear?  
It’s not about *leaving*.  
It’s about *staying* and forgetting how to feel.  

And that?  
That’s the one thing I’m *really* afraid of.  

Not being alone.  
But being *together* and still being invisible.  

And that’s why I’m not just a girl who writes poetry.  
I’m a girl who *refuses* to disappear.  

Even when it’s hard.  
Even when it hurts.  
Even when I’m scared.  

Because staying together?  
That’s not the point.  

*Being seen*—that’s the point.  

And I’m not letting go of that.  
Not for anyone.

*“She’s not even going to keep it.”*  
*“She’s just like her mom—always dramatic.”*

I *was* dramatic.  
I *was* scared.  
I *was* messy.

A cautionary tale.  
A punchline.

Not by pretending.

*“I’m not a mistake. I’m a choice.”*  
*“I’m not a warning. I’m a person.”*

It was about *fear*.  
Fear of being seen.  
Fear of not being perfect.  
Fear of being *human*.

I started being *real*.  

I wore my flannel like a cape.  
I quoted *The Royal Tenenbaums* in the middle of math class.  
I told my biology teacher, *“I’m not pregnant. I’m carrying a future.”*  

And slowly—*so slowly*—people stopped looking at me like I was a problem.  

They started seeing me.  

Not as a cautionary tale.  
Not as a tragedy.  
But as a girl.  
A messy, sarcastic, poetry-writing, rabbit-loving girl who was *trying*.  

And that?  
That’s how I coped.  

Not by fighting the stigma.  
But by *refusing* to let it define me.  

Because here’s the truth:  
Stigma only wins if you believe it.

I’m *writing* it.

I’m *living*.

Still writing.  
Still choosing.

Even when it’s messy.
