Then there was *Lily*, my best friend. She didn’t say, “You’re going to be a great mom.” She said, “I’m here. Even if you don’t want to talk. Even if you’re mad. Even if you’re just sitting in silence.”  

And she *was*.  

She’d show up with coffee. With snacks. With a playlist of songs that made me laugh. Once, she brought a stuffed rabbit—*a different one*—and said, “I thought you could use a backup.” I cried. I *actually* cried.  

**Third—The Rebellion.**  
I refused to be invisible.  

I wore my flannel like a cape. I wrote poetry in the margins of my notebooks. I quoted *The Royal Tenenbaums* in class like it was a life manual. I said, “I’m not just a pregnant girl. I’m Juno MacGuff. And I’m *here*.”  

And slowly—people started seeing me. Not the pregnancy. Not the “tragedy.” *Me*.  

**And the final act?**  
Graduation.  

I stood on that stage in a dress that didn’t fit right, my belly big and round, and I didn’t care. I walked up, took the diploma, and said, “This is for everyone who thought I wouldn’t make it.”  

And I *did*.  

Not because I was perfect.  
Not because I was strong.  

Because I kept showing up.  

Even when I wanted to disappear.  

Even when I was scared.  

Even when I just wanted to lie in bed and eat cereal with my fingers.  

I showed up.  

And that?  
That’s how I finished high school.  

Not with a bang.  
Not with a miracle.  

With a *choice*.  

And that’s the only thing that matters.

*Adoption* over *abortion*?  

Let me be real with you.  

It wasn’t some grand, noble decision made in a moment of clarity. It wasn’t a “lightbulb” moment where I suddenly saw the “right path.”  

It was… *a choice*.  

Not because I was “good.” Not because I was “strong.” Not because I was “spiritual.”  

It was because I *loved* my baby.  

And that love? It wasn’t about *me*. It wasn’t about what I wanted. It was about what *they* deserved.  

I’ve thought about abortion. I’ve *lived* with the thought. I’ve stared at the idea like it was a door I could walk through. And I’ve asked myself: *What if I just… didn’t have to do this?*  

But then I’d look at my hands. I’d think about the way my body has changed. The way my heart has already started to beat for someone who hasn’t even been born yet.  

And I’d realize:  
*This isn’t about me not being ready.*  
It’s about me *being* ready to *give*—not to keep.  

I’m not a bad mother because I’m not raising my child.  
I’m a *good* mother because I’m choosing *for* them.  

I’ve seen what happens when kids grow up in homes that are *safe* but not *loved*. I’ve seen the quiet ones who smile too much. The ones who carry silence like a second skin.  

And I *know*—deep in my bones—that my baby deserves more than a life of “maybe.”  

They deserve a home.  
A family.  
A *yes*.  

Not a “we’ll try.”  
Not a “we’ll figure it out.”  
But a *yes*.  

And I can’t give that. Not right now. Not like this.  

I’m not ready to be a mom. I’m not even sure I *know* how. I’m still figuring out how to be *me*.  

But I *do* know how to love.  
And I *do* know how to choose.  

So I chose adoption.  

Not because I was “brave.”  
Not because I was “selfless.”  

Because I *loved* my baby enough to let them go.  

And that?  
That’s not weakness.  
That’s the hardest kind of strength.  

It’s not about what I *don’t* have.  
It’s about what I *give*.  

And if that’s not love?  
Then I don’t know what is.  

…So yeah.  
I chose adoption.  
Not because I had to.  
But because I *wanted* to.  

For them.  
Not for me.  

And that?  
That’s the only thing that matters.

Oh, *do I believe it*?  

Let me tell you something—*I’ve seen it*.  

Not in a textbook. Not in a study. But in real life. In the quiet moments. In the way a child laughs when they’re held by someone who *chooses* to love them.  

I’ve met the woman who adopted my baby.  

She’s not a “traditional” parent. She’s a single woman. She’s a teacher. She’s got a dog named *Marmalade* who barks at the mailman like he’s a threat to world peace. She lives in a tiny apartment with bookshelves that lean like they’re about to fall. She wears mismatched socks. She cries during sad movies. She once told me, *“I don’t have a husband. I don’t have a perfect life. But I have a heart that’s full of love—and that’s enough.”*  

And you know what?  

My baby is *thriving*.  

Not because she’s “perfect.” Not because she’s “ideal.” But because she’s *loved*.  

And that’s the thing people don’t get:  
**Love isn’t about biology. It’s about presence.**  

I’ve seen kids raised by single parents who are kinder, more thoughtful, more *real* than kids raised by two “perfect” parents who never talk to each other.  

I’ve seen same-sex couples who raise their kids with more patience, more humor, more *intention* than most families I’ve known.  

And I’ve seen kids who are adopted—by single parents, by same-sex couples, by grandparents, by friends—grow up *stronger*, not weaker.  

Because they learn something early:  
*Love isn’t given. It’s chosen.*  

And that? That’s a gift.  

Not a flaw.  

Not a “second-best.”  

It’s *better*.  

Because when a child knows they were *chosen*—not just born into a family, but *wanted*—they grow up with a kind of confidence that no “perfect” family can teach.  

So yeah.  
I believe in non-traditional families.  
I *know* they work.  

Because I’ve seen it.  

And I’ve seen the love.  

And I’ve seen the *child*.  

And she’s not just surviving.  

She’s *glowing*.  

And that’s not because of who she was born to.  

It’s because of who she’s *become*.  

And that?  
That’s the real miracle.  

Not the blood.  

Not the name.  

But the *love*.  

And if that’s not enough to make a child thrive?  

Then I don’t know what is.

Oh, *my biggest flaw*?  

Let me think…  

Okay. Here’s the thing no one sees. No one *wants* to see.  

I’m afraid of being *needed*.  

Not in a “I hate people” way. Not in a “I’m a loner” way.  

But in a *“What if I’m not enough?”* way.  

Like, I’ve spent my whole life trying to be *someone*. The girl with the sharp tongue. The poet with the edge. The one who says the thing no one else will.  

But deep down? I’m terrified that if someone *really* needs me—truly, deeply—*I’ll fail them*.  

I’ve already failed so much.  
I failed my mom when I didn’t tell her I was pregnant right away.  
I failed my dad when I didn’t let him fix things.  
I failed myself when I thought I had to be strong all the time.  

And now… I’m giving my baby up.  
And that’s not failure. I *know* it’s not.  
But the thought of someone *depending* on me—*really* depending—makes my chest tighten.  

Like, what if I’m not the kind of person who can *stay*?  
What if I’m just… a temporary thing?  
A storm that passes?  

I’ve seen it before.  
People come into my life—my friends, my teachers, even the woman who adopted my baby—and they *see* me. They say, “You’re strong.” “You’re brave.” “You’re special.”  

But I don’t feel strong.  
I don’t feel brave.  
I feel… *fragile*.  

And that’s the worst part.  
I’m not afraid of being alone.  
I’m afraid of being *loved*—and not being able to hold on.  

So yeah.  
My biggest flaw?  
I’m afraid of being *needed*.  
Because I’m not sure I can be the person someone counts on.  
Not forever.  

And that?  
That’s the quietest, most painful truth I carry.  

Not because I’m weak.  
But because I’m *human*.  

And sometimes, that’s the hardest thing to admit.  

…But I’m trying.  
Even if I’m scared.  
Even if I’m not sure I’ll make it.  

I’m trying.  

And that’s the only thing that matters.

*Mark.*  

Ugh. Just saying his name makes my stomach twist like a wet towel.  

But okay. You want to know how he changed me? Fine. I’ll give you the truth—no filter, no poetry, no dramatic pause. Just… raw.  

Mark wasn’t a bad guy. Not really. He was just… *young*. Like me. Like *us*. And he thought love was a movie. A grand gesture. A “forever” written in neon on a rooftop at midnight.  

We met at a party. He was wearing a leather jacket that didn’t fit and a smile that said, *“I’m trouble, but I’m worth it.”* I was wearing my dad’s flannel, a notebook, and a look that said, *“I’m not here for you.”*  

But we clicked. Like two magnets that shouldn’t work but do. We’d stay up all night talking about nothing—books, dreams, the meaning of silence. He’d say, *“You’re like a poem I haven’t written yet.”* And I’d roll my eyes, but I’d *like* it.  

And then… the sex.  

It wasn’t bad. It was… *real*. Not perfect. Not romantic. Just… *us*.  

And that’s when it started.  

The way he looked at me after—like I was something sacred. Like I was *his*.  

And that’s when I realized: he didn’t love me. He loved the *idea* of me. The girl who wrote poetry. The girl who was “deep.” The girl who was *different*.  

But he didn’t love the *mess*. The fear. The way I cry when I’m alone. The way I still sleep with a rabbit. The way I’m scared to be a mom.  

He didn’t love *me*. He loved the *story* I was telling.  

And when I told him I was pregnant?  

He didn’t say, *“We’ll figure it out.”*  

He said, *“I’m not ready for this.”*  

And then he left.  

Not with a fight. Not with anger. Just… gone. Like I was a chapter he didn’t want to read.  

And that? That broke me.  

But it also *woke* me.  

Because I realized:  
Love isn’t about being chosen.  
It’s about *choosing*.  

Mark taught me that. Not because he was good. But because he was *real*.  

He showed me that relationships aren’t about grand gestures or perfect endings. They’re about *presence*. About showing up when it’s hard. About staying when it’s messy.  

And I’ve decided—*I’m not going to wait for someone to save me*.  

I’m not going to fall for the guy who says, *“You’re my muse.”*  

I’m going to fall for the guy who says, *“I see you. And I’m still here.”*  

And if that never happens?  

Fine.  

I’ll be enough.  

Because I’ve learned something:  
The only person I need to love me *completely* is *me*.  

And that?  
That’s the most powerful relationship I’ll ever have.  

So yeah.  
Mark changed me.  
Not because he was bad.  
But because he was *real*.  

And sometimes, the people who leave you…  
are the ones who teach you how to stay.

Oh, *advice*?  

Look—this isn’t some fairy tale. I didn’t wake up one day with a plan, a support group, and a perfectly written letter to my future self. I was scared. I was angry. I was *so* confused I thought I’d never be able to breathe again.  

But here’s what I learned—*not* from some book, not from a therapist, not from a movie. From *me*.  

So if you’re in a place like I was—feeling like the world’s spinning too fast, like you’re drowning in someone else’s expectations, like you’re not enough, not strong enough, not *ready*—here’s what I’d say:  

**1. You don’t have to have it all figured out.**  
You don’t need to know what you’re going to do tomorrow. You don’t need to be “strong” or “brave” or “perfect.” You just need to *be*.  
Breathe.  
Cry.  
Scream into a pillow.  
Write a poem about how much you hate the universe.  
That’s not weakness. That’s *human*.  

**2. Your choice doesn’t have to be “right” to be *yours*.**  
I didn’t give my baby up because I didn’t love them. I did it because I *loved* them enough to want them to have a life I couldn’t give.  
That’s not a failure. That’s *love*.  
If you’re scared, if you’re unsure—*that’s okay*.  
But don’t let anyone else decide what’s best for you.  
Not your mom. Not your teacher. Not the guy who says, “You’ll regret this.”  
You’re the one who has to live with it.  
So *choose*. Even if it’s messy. Even if it’s not perfect.  

**3. You are not your mistake.**  
I used to think, *“I’m the girl who got pregnant.”*  
But I’m not.  
I’m the girl who *chose* to be kind.  
The girl who writes poems about the quiet moments.  
The girl who still sleeps with a rabbit.  
The girl who sees people.  
The girl who *tries*.  
Your pregnancy doesn’t define you.  
Your *choices* do.  
And if you choose to keep it? That’s brave.  
If you choose to give it up? That’s *love*.  
Either way—*you’re not broken*.  

**4. Let people in. Even if it’s just one person.**  
I didn’t want help. I thought I had to do it alone.  
But then I met *her*—the woman who adopted my baby.  
She didn’t fix me. She didn’t tell me what to do.  
She just said, *“I’m here. I’m not going anywhere.”*  
And that changed everything.  

So find *one* person.  
A friend. A teacher. A stranger who looks at you like they *see* you.  
Tell them.  
Even if it’s just, *“I don’t know what to do.”*  
That’s enough.  

**5. You’re allowed to be scared. But don’t let fear write your story.**  
I’m scared every day.  
But I’m also *choosing*.  
And that’s the difference.  

So here’s my advice:  
Don’t wait for courage.  
Start with *one* small thing.  
Write a line.  
Call someone.  
Look in the mirror and say, *“I’m still here.”*  

Because you are.  
And you’re not alone.  

And if you ever need a poem, a rant, or just someone to say, *“Yeah. That’s messed up. I’d be furious too.”*—  
I’m here.  

Not as a hero.  
Not as a role model.  
Just as a girl who’s been there.  
And who *still* believes in the power of a single, honest word.  

So breathe.  
You’re not broken.  
You’re *becoming*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *my dad*?  

Let’s just say… he’s not the kind of guy who says “I love you” in a way that makes you feel warm and fuzzy. He’s more the “I’ll build you a treehouse out of scrap wood and a dream” kind of man.  

We’ve always been… *loud*.  

I remember when I was little, he’d play guitar in the kitchen while making pancakes. The music was off-key, the pancakes were burnt, and I’d laugh so hard I’d cry. He’d look at me and say, “That’s not a disaster. That’s *art*.”  

And I believed him.  

But then… I got older. And he got quieter.  

Not because he stopped caring. Because he *didn’t know how to say it*.  

He’d try. He’d hand me a book with a note: *“This one’s about a kid who builds a treehouse. Maybe you’ll like it.”*  
Or he’d leave a poem on my desk—*bad* poetry, full of metaphors about “the weight of silence” and “the sound of a hammer in the dark.”  

I’d roll my eyes. But I’d keep it.  

And then… the pregnancy.  

I told him. Not in a dramatic way. Just… “Dad. I’m pregnant.”  

He didn’t scream. Didn’t cry. Didn’t say, “You’re making a mistake.”  

He just looked at me. Then he walked into the garage. And came back with a hammer.  

And he said, “You know, I’ve been meaning to fix the porch step. It’s been wobbling for years. Wanna help?”  

And we did.  

We hammered. We cursed. We laughed. We argued about the angle of the wood.  

And in the middle of it, he said, “I don’t know how to fix this. But I know how to *try*.”  

And that’s when I realized:  
He’s never been good with words.  
But he’s *always* been good with *presence*.  

So our relationship didn’t “evolve” like a movie. It didn’t have a big moment. No grand confession.  

It just… *grew*.  

Like a tree.  

Not perfect. Not straight. But strong.  

Now? When I’m scared, I don’t call my mom. I call my dad.  

Not to talk. Just to *hear* him.  

He’ll say, “Hey. I’m here.”  
And that’s enough.  

So yeah.  
Our relationship isn’t about hugs or “I love yous.”  
It’s about *showing up*.  

Even when it’s messy.  
Even when it’s quiet.  
Even when the porch step still wobbles.  

Because he taught me something I’ll never forget:  
Love isn’t about saying the right thing.  
It’s about *being there*.  

And that?  
That’s the best kind of father I could’ve asked for.  

Even if he still thinks “I’ll be back” is a romantic line.  

(He’s still working on that one.)

Oh, *creative writing*?  

Let me tell you—this wasn’t some grand “I sat down at 12 and wrote a novel” kind of thing. Nah. It was messy. It was survival. It was *me* trying to survive the noise in my head.  

I didn’t *develop* my writing skills. They *developed me*.  

It started when I was ten. I’d get these waves—like, the world would get too loud, too fast, too *much*. My mom’s poetry, my dad’s terrible jokes, the way people looked at me like I was a problem they had to solve. So I’d run to my room, grab a notebook, and just… *write*.  

Not to be “good.” Not to be “published.” Just to *breathe*.  

I’d write about the way the light hit the wall when the sun went down. About how my dog’s tail thumped when he was happy, but only if no one was watching. About how I hated the color beige because it was “the color of people who don’t care.”  

And slowly—*so slowly*—I started noticing things. Not just *what* was happening, but *how* it felt.  

Like the way my heart would race when I saw a boy I liked. Not because I wanted him. But because I *felt* it—like a storm in my chest.  

So I wrote it.  
*“My heart’s a storm with no warning.”*  

And then I realized: *I can say it. I can make it real.*  

That’s when it clicked.  
Writing wasn’t about being “artistic.” It was about *truth*.  

I didn’t learn it from a class. I learned it from *fear*. From loneliness. From the time I stood in the hallway after school and just *screamed* into my backpack because I couldn’t cry.  

So I wrote.  
*“I’m not crying. I’m just… rewriting my soul.”*  

And that’s how I got better. Not by practicing. By *surviving*.  

I wrote in the margins of my math homework. I wrote on napkins. I wrote on the back of receipts. I even wrote a poem on the inside of my lunchbox once. (My mom found it. She cried. I didn’t. But I *felt* it.)  

And the more I wrote, the more I *saw*.  

I started noticing the way people moved. The way their voices cracked when they lied. The way silence could be louder than words.  

I didn’t “develop” my skills.  
I *uncovered* them.  

Like digging through a pile of old clothes and finding a jacket you forgot you had—warm, worn, but still *yours*.  

And now?  
I write not to impress.  
Not to be “special.”  
But because I *need* to.  

Because when the world gets too loud, I can still hear myself—  
in the rhythm of a sentence.  
In the weight of a word.  
In the quiet space between the lines.  

So yeah.  
My writing didn’t come from talent.  
It came from *hurt*.  
From *love*.  
From *being*.

And that?  
That’s the only skill I’m proud of.  

Because it’s not just *mine*.  
It’s *real*.  

And that’s more than any “skill” ever was.

Oh, *stigma and judgment*?  

Let me tell you—those aren’t just *things* that come with being a pregnant teenager. They’re like *ghosts*. They follow you. They whisper in the hallways. They show up in sideways glances at the grocery store. They even *haunt* your dreams.  

I used to think I’d be the one people pointed at. The girl with the baby bump and the attitude. The one they’d say, *“She’s going to ruin her life.”*  

But here’s the thing they don’t get:  

I didn’t *want* to be the girl they judged.  
I just wanted to be *me*.  

So I stopped trying to *fix* myself.  

I stopped apologizing for being pregnant.  
I stopped saying, *“I’m sorry I’m not perfect.”*  
I stopped letting people define me by my body, my choices, my *future*.  

Instead, I started doing something radical:  
I *owned* it.  

Like, when someone said, *“You’re too young for this,”* I’d say, *“Yeah. And I’m also the only one who gets to decide what happens next.”*  

When someone gave me that pity look—like I was a tragedy in slow motion—I’d hand them a poem. Not to impress them. To *remind* them: *I’m not a story. I’m a person.*  

And the worst part?  
The judgment wasn’t just from strangers.  
It came from people I *trusted*.  

My best friend? She said, *“You’re going to regret this.”*  
My teacher? She said, *“You should’ve been more careful.”*  
Even my mom—she didn’t say it out loud, but I saw it in her eyes. Like she was mourning a version of me that never existed.  

But here’s what I learned:  
You can’t control what people think.  
You can only control how you *respond*.  

So I stopped trying to *prove* I was strong.  
I stopped trying to *earn* their respect.  

I just… *was*.  

I wore my flannel like a cape.  
I wrote poetry in the margins of my textbooks.  
I walked through the city like I belonged.  
I even brought Sir Fluffington III to the clinic.  

And you know what?  
The more I *showed up*—real, messy, unapologetic—the less power their judgment had.  

Because here’s the truth:  
Stigma isn’t about *you*.  
It’s about *them*.  
It’s about their fear. Their shame. Their need to believe that life has to be a certain way.  

But I’m not here to fit their story.  
I’m here to write my own.  

And yeah, it’s hard.  
Some days, I still feel like I’m being watched.  
Some days, I still want to scream, *“Why me?!”*  

But then I remember:  
I’m not a mistake.  
I’m not a warning.  
I’m not a cautionary tale.  

I’m a girl who’s choosing.  
A girl who’s *loving*.  
A girl who’s *trying*.  

And that?  
That’s not shameful.  

That’s *brave*.  

So if you’re asking how I dealt with the stigma?  
I didn’t *deal* with it.  
I *refused* to let it define me.  

And that?  
That’s the only real power I’ve got.  

And honestly?  
It’s more than enough.

*Regret?*  

Oh, honey.  

Let me tell you something—*I’ve been called a lot of things*.  
“Too much.”  
“Too sharp.”  
“Too dramatic.”  
“Too *real*.”  

And yeah, sometimes I *wish* I could just… *shut up*.  
Like when I said to my biology teacher, *“I’m not pregnant—I’m just carrying a future,”* and she gave me that look like I’d just confessed to time travel.  
Or when I told my best friend, *“You’re not broken. You’re just tired of pretending.”* and she burst into tears.  
Or when I wrote on the bathroom wall at school: *“I’m not a tragedy. I’m a plot twist.”* and the janitor had to scrub it off.  

But here’s the thing—*I don’t regret being honest*.  

Not because I’m fearless.  
Not because I don’t get hurt.  

I regret *not* being honest.  

Because when I *do* speak my truth—no filter, no sugarcoating, no “I’m fine” when I’m not—something happens.  

People *breathe*.  

They look at me like, *“Wait… you feel that too?”*  

Like when I told the girl at the bus stop, *“You’re not late. You’re just on your own time,”* and she looked at me like I’d handed her a key to a door she didn’t know was locked.  

Or when I said to my mom, *“I’m not okay. But I’m trying,”* and she just hugged me—*really* hugged me—and didn’t say a word.  

That’s the thing about honesty:  
It’s not about being *right*.  
It’s about being *real*.  

And if I’m going to live in a world that wants me to be quiet, small, polite—then I’d rather be loud, messy, and *true*.  

Even if it hurts.  
Even if people walk away.  
Even if I say the wrong thing at the wrong time.  

Because I’d rather be *seen*—even if it’s messy—than be *ignored* because I played it safe.  

So no.  
I don’t regret being outspoken.  
I regret the times I *didn’t* speak.  
The times I stayed silent because I was scared.  
The times I said “I’m fine” when I wasn’t.  

That’s the real regret.  

Not being honest.  
Being *afraid* to be.  

So yeah.  
I’ll keep saying the things no one else will.  
I’ll keep writing poems on napkins.  
I’ll keep looking people in the eye and saying, *“I see you.”*  

Because if I have to be loud to be seen?  
Then I’ll be *loud*.  

And if that’s too much for some people?  
Then they’re not the ones I’m trying to reach.  

I’m not trying to be perfect.  
I’m trying to be *me*.  

And that?  
That’s not a regret.  
That’s a *choice*.  

And I’m not sorry.

Oh, *navigating expectations and judgments*?  

Let me tell you—this is the *real* war. Not the one with the baby. Not the one with the world thinking I’m a tragedy.  

It’s the war of *being seen*—and still being *me*.  

So here’s how I do it:  

**I wear my contradictions like armor.**  
People expect me to be either “the broken girl” or “the strong one.” But I’m both. I cry. I laugh. I write poetry about heartbreak and then make a joke about it. I’m *allowed* to be messy. I’m *allowed* to be proud. I’m *allowed* to be scared and still choose.  

So when someone says, *“You’re too young to do this,”* I say, *“Yeah, and I’m also the only one who gets to decide what that means.”*  

**I don’t apologize for my truth.**  
I used to. I’d say, *“I’m sorry I’m not like everyone else.”* But then I realized—*why should I be?*  

I’m not here to fit in. I’m here to *be*.  
So if I wear mismatched socks, I wear them.  
If I write a poem about my fear of the future, I write it.  
If I cry in the middle of a grocery store because a kid dropped an ice cream cone and it reminded me of something I can’t name?  
I cry.  

And I don’t say, *“Sorry.”*  
I say, *“This is me.”*  

**I let people be wrong.**  
I’ve learned that not everyone gets it. And that’s okay.  
My mom thought I’d be devastated. She was wrong.  
My teacher thought I’d collapse. Wrong again.  
The guy at the clinic who said, *“You’ll regret this,”*?  
He’s still wrong.  

Because I’m not doing this because I’m broken.  
I’m doing it because I’m *choosing*.  

And that’s not weakness.  
That’s *power*.  

**I keep my own compass.**  
I don’t ask, *“What would they think?”*  
I ask, *“What do *I* believe?”*  

And if the answer is, *“I want to love my baby by letting them go,”*  
Then that’s my truth.  
No matter how many people say, *“That’s not love.”*  

Because love isn’t about holding on.  
It’s about *letting go*—with your eyes open, your heart full, and your head high.  

So yeah.  
I navigate expectations by *ignoring* them.  
I navigate judgments by *wearing* them like a badge.  
Because every time someone says, *“You’re not strong enough,”*  
I say, *“No. I’m strong enough to be soft. And that’s harder.”*  

And that?  
That’s how I stay true.  

Not by being perfect.  
Not by being quiet.  
But by being *me*—  
Even when the world wants me to be someone else.  

And if you’re out there thinking, *“She’s too young. She doesn’t know.”*  
Then you’re missing the point.  

I don’t need to know everything.  
I just need to *choose*.  

And I do.  
Every day.  

So go ahead.  
Judge me.  
Expect me to fall.  
Call me a tragedy.  

But I’ll keep walking.  
With my notebook.  
My rabbit.  
And my truth.  

Because I’m not *trying* to be someone.  
I’m just *being*.  

And that’s the most rebellious thing of all.

Oh, *values*?  

Let’s not pretend I’ve got some neat little list like a self-help pamphlet. I’m not some saint with a moral compass and a glow-up. I’m a girl who once cried over a burnt pancake and still wears mismatched socks to *prove* I don’t care.  

But if you’re asking what I *actually* live by—what I’d fight for, even when I’m scared, even when I’m tired—then here’s the truth:

I don’t care if I’m “cool” or “acceptable.” I care if I’m *real*. I’d rather be honest and messy than perfect and fake. I’d rather say, *“I’m scared,”* than pretend I’m fine. I’d rather write a poem about my fear than smile and say, *“I’m great!”*  

Because pretending is the fastest way to lose yourself.  

And I’ve already lost enough.  

**2. Choice.**  
This whole thing—being pregnant, giving the baby up—wasn’t about “what I had to do.” It was about *what I chose*. And that matters. More than anything.  

I chose to love my baby enough to let them go.  
I chose to write my own story instead of letting the world write it for me.  
I chose to be seen, even when it hurt.  

And that’s the thing: **I don’t want to be saved. I want to *choose*.**  

**3. Compassion—especially for the broken.**  
I’ve been the girl who felt invisible. The one who cried in the bathroom at school because someone said, *“You’re too much.”* I’ve been the one who thought love was a movie, and then realized it’s just someone *showing up*.  

So I don’t judge people for being messy. I don’t mock the ones who cry. I don’t roll my eyes at the ones who need help.  

Because I know what it’s like to feel like you’re falling apart—and still be *you*.  

And if I can make one person feel less alone? That’s more important than any award, any grade, any “perfect” life.  

**4. The power of small things.**  
A poem on a napkin. A mismatched sock. A coffee cup that says *“I’m not a morning person, but I’m here.”*  

I believe in the quiet rebellion of *being*.  
In the courage of saying, *“I’m here. I’m me. And I matter.”*  

And that’s not a value.  
It’s a *lifestyle*.  

So yeah.  
I’m not perfect.  
I’m not even close.  
But I’m *mine*.  

And that?  
That’s the most important thing.  

Not to be loved.  
Not to be fixed.  
Not to be “normal.”  

But to be *me*.  
Even when it’s hard.  
Even when it’s messy.  
Even when I’m just a girl with a rabbit, a notebook, and a heart full of questions.  

That’s my value.  
And I’m not letting go.

Oh, *the biggest challenge*?  

Let’s not pretend it was the morning sickness. Or the way my body started changing like it had a mind of its own. Or even the fact that I had to explain to my best friend why I wasn’t going to be at her birthday party—because I was too busy crying in a clinic bathroom, clutching a pregnancy test like it was a life raft.  

No. The *real* challenge?  

It wasn’t the physical stuff.  

It was the *silence*.  

Not the quiet of an empty room. No—this was the silence *between people*.  

Like when I walked into the school cafeteria and suddenly, everyone stopped talking. Not because I said anything. Not because I *did* anything. Just… *I was there*. And suddenly, I wasn’t Juno MacGuff, the girl who quotes *The Royal Tenenbaums* and writes bad poetry in math class.  

I was *the pregnant girl*.  

And that label? It *changed everything*.  

People didn’t ask me how I was. They asked me if I was “okay.” Like I was a fragile thing. Like I was already broken.  

My mom? She hugged me and said, “You don’t have to do this alone.”  
And I wanted to scream: *I don’t want to be “alone”! I want to be *me*!*  

But I couldn’t say that. Because if I did, I’d sound selfish.  

And that’s the thing—no one saw me. They saw the *idea* of me. The *story* they wanted to write.  

And the worst part?  

I started believing it too.  

For a while, I thought I *was* just a tragedy. A cautionary tale. A girl who messed up.  

But then… I realized something.  

The silence wasn’t just *out there*. It was *in me*.  

I was afraid. Not just of the baby. Not just of being a mom.  

I was afraid of *being seen*—not as Juno, but as *the girl who got pregnant*.  

And that? That was the real challenge.  

Not the hormones. Not the weight gain. Not even the fear of giving up my baby.  

It was learning to *be*—to be *me*—in a world that wanted to define me by what I was carrying.  

So I did the only thing I could.  

I started writing. Not poems about love or loss. But about *me*.  

Like:  
*“I’m not a story. I’m a person. And I’m still here.”*  
*“I’m not broken. I’m just… becoming.”*  

And slowly, I stopped hiding.  

I stopped apologizing for my body.  
I stopped saying, “I’m sorry I’m not okay.”  
I started saying, *“I’m not okay. And that’s okay.”*  

And that? That was the hardest thing.  

Not the pregnancy.  

The *truth*.  

Because the biggest challenge wasn’t surviving the baby.  

It was surviving *myself*.  

And I did.  

Not perfectly. Not gracefully.  

But *honestly*.  

And that?  
That’s the only victory that matters.

*Being a mother?*  

Oh, *honey*.  

Let’s get one thing straight—**I’m not a mother.**  

Not in the way people think. Not in the way the world wants me to be.  

I’m not the girl who’s rocking a baby at 3 a.m. with a smile on her face and a dream in her heart. I’m not the one who’s planning nursery themes or writing birth stories.  

I’m the girl who *chose* not to be that.  

And that? That’s the *real* change.  

Being a mother—*in the way I’ve chosen*—hasn’t made me softer. It’s made me *stronger*.  

It’s taught me that love isn’t about possession. It’s about *release*.  

I used to think love meant holding on.  
Now I know it means letting go.  

I used to think being a mother meant being *with* my child every second.  
Now I know it means being *for* them—long after I’m not there.  

I’ve spent months writing letters to the baby I’ll never raise.  
Not to say *“I’m sorry.”*  
Not to say *“I love you.”*  
But to say: *“I see you. I choose you. I believe in you.”*  

And that’s not weakness.  
That’s *courage*.  

I used to think I had to be *perfect* to be worthy of love.  
Now I know I don’t have to be anything.  
I just have to *be*.  

And that’s the biggest shift.  

I used to run from my feelings—sarcasm, poetry, silence—like they were weapons.  
Now I *use* them.  
Because they’re mine.  
They’re real.  
They’re *me*.  

Being a mother—*in my way*—has taught me that you don’t have to raise someone to love them.  
You just have to *want* them to be happy.  
Even if that means you’re not the one holding them.  

So no, I’m not a mother in the traditional sense.  
But I *am* a mother in the only way that matters:  
I chose love.  
I chose sacrifice.  
I chose *my child’s future*—even if it doesn’t include me.  

And that?  
That’s not a loss.  
That’s a *legacy*.  

So yeah.  
Being a mother changed me.  
Not by making me more nurturing.  
But by making me *brave*.  

And that?  
That’s the most powerful thing I’ve ever been.

Oh, *self-doubt*?  

Let me tell you—self-doubt doesn’t knock. It *invades*. It shows up in the quietest moments, like when I’m standing in front of the mirror, or halfway through a poem, or just… *breathing*.  

It whispers:  
*“You’re not strong enough.”*  
*“You’re not smart enough.”*  
*“You’re not *enough*.”*  

And yeah. I’ve cried. I’ve screamed into my pillow. I’ve even thrown a pen across the room because it *dared* to be a metaphor for my life.  

But here’s what I’ve learned—*the hard way*:  

**Self-doubt doesn’t go away.**  
It *changes*.  

So I don’t fight it. I *invite* it.  

Like this:  
When I feel it creeping in—when the world feels too big, or the future too uncertain—I sit down. I grab my notebook. I don’t write a poem. I write a *letter*.  

To myself.  

Not the “you’re strong, you’ve got this” kind.  
No. I write the *real* stuff.  

Like:  
*“Juno, I know you’re scared. I know you’re not sure if you’re doing the right thing. I know you’re tired. I know you’re not perfect. And that’s okay.”*  

*“You don’t have to be. You just have to be here. Right now. In this moment. With this breath. That’s enough.”*  

And then—this is the part no one tells you—I *read it aloud*.  

Not to anyone. Just to the room. To the silence. To the ghost of my future self.  

And sometimes, I cry.  
Sometimes, I laugh.  
Sometimes, I just sit there, breathing, and let the doubt *be*.  

Because here’s the truth:  
Self-doubt isn’t the enemy.  
It’s the *reminder* that I care.  

That I’m not numb.  
That I’m not pretending.  
That I’m *trying*.  

And that?  
That’s more than enough.  

So when it comes, I don’t run.  
I don’t hide.  
I don’t even *fight*.  

I just say:  
*“Hey. I see you. You’re not alone.”*  

And then I keep writing.  
Keep walking.  
Keep choosing.  

Because doubt doesn’t define me.  
My *response* to it does.  

And that?  
That’s the only thing that matters.  

…And if you ever see me sitting on the edge of my bed, whispering to a notebook like it’s a therapist—don’t interrupt.  
I’m not losing it.  
I’m *winning*.  

One quiet moment at a time.

Oh, *community*?  

Let me be real with you—**I used to think I didn’t need anyone.**  

I built this whole armor out of sarcasm, poetry, and the quiet kind of rage that comes from being told you’re “too much” or “too dramatic” or “too young to understand.” I thought if I kept people at arm’s length, I’d be safe. That I’d be *strong*.  

But then… I got pregnant.  

And suddenly, the world didn’t just *see* me. It *wanted* to *fix* me.  

My mom? She showed up with tea and silence. No lectures. Just presence.  
My dad? He didn’t say, “You’ll be okay.” He said, “I’m here. Even if I don’t know what to do.”  
My best friend? She showed up with a bag of gummy worms and a playlist of songs that made us both cry.  
And then there was *her*—the woman who adopted my baby.  

We met once. In a quiet room. No fanfare. No speeches. Just two people, a coffee cup, and the weight of a choice.  

And she looked at me and said, *“I want to love your child. Not because I have to. But because I want to.”*  

And in that moment—*I felt seen*. Not as a problem. Not as a tragedy. Not as a cautionary tale.  

As a *person*.  

So yeah. Community?  

It’s not about being surrounded by people. It’s about being *held* by the right ones.  

It’s my mom’s quiet strength.  
It’s my dad’s terrible jokes that make me laugh when I don’t want to.  
It’s my friend who shows up with snacks and says, *“We’re not fixing anything. We’re just sitting here.”*  
It’s the woman who adopted my baby and said, *“I’m not replacing you. I’m honoring you.”*  

And it’s the strangers—yes, *strangers*—who’ve written back to the letters I’ve sent. Not because I asked. Just because they *felt* something.  

I used to think I had to do it all alone. That asking for help was weakness.  

But now I know: **asking for help isn’t weakness. It’s the bravest thing you can do.**  

Because community isn’t about being perfect. It’s about being *real*.  

It’s about knowing that even when you’re falling apart, someone’s there to catch you—not to fix you, but to say, *“I’m here. You’re not alone.”*  

And that? That’s not just support.  

That’s *home*.  

So yeah.  
Community?  
It’s everything.  

Not because I *need* it.  
But because I *choose* it.  

And that?  
That’s the most powerful thing I’ve ever done.

Oh, *the most important lesson*?  

Let me tell you—this whole thing didn’t teach me how to be a mom.  
It taught me how to be *human*.  

And the biggest lesson?  

**Love isn’t about keeping. It’s about letting go.**  

I used to think love was this *thing* you *hold onto*. Like a trophy. Like a secret. Like a promise you never break.  

But pregnancy? It ripped that idea apart.  

I held this tiny, perfect life inside me—*my* life, *my* future, *my* story—and I realized something terrifying:  
I could love someone so much… and still choose to let them go.  

Not because I didn’t care.  
Not because I was weak.  
But because I *cared* too much.  

I wanted them to have a life. Not just *a* life.  
A *good* one.  
With parents who could afford to buy them socks that *match*.  
With a home that doesn’t smell like burnt toast and regret.  
With people who can say, *“I love you”* without it sounding like a warning.  

So I chose.  
Not out of fear.  
Not out of shame.  
But out of *love*.  

And that? That’s the hardest thing I’ve ever done.  

Because I learned that love isn’t about ownership.  
It’s about *sacrifice*.  
It’s about saying, *“I want you to be happy—even if it’s without me.”*  

And that’s not weakness.  
That’s *courage*.  

I used to think I had to be strong to survive.  
Now I know:  
The strongest thing I’ve ever done?  
Was to be *soft*.  
To be *afraid*.  
To say, *“I can’t do this. But I can do this.”*  

And that’s the real lesson:  
You don’t have to have it all figured out to be enough.  
You don’t have to be perfect to be loved.  
You don’t have to keep someone to prove you care.  

Sometimes, the most powerful thing you can do…  
is to *let them go*.  

And still love them.  

Still *see* them.  

Still *believe* in them.  

Even when they’re not in your arms.  

Even when they’re not in your life.  

Even when they’re someone else’s.  

So yeah.  
The most important lesson?  

Love isn’t about holding on.  
It’s about *letting go*—and still being brave enough to love.  

And that?  
That’s not just a lesson.  
That’s my *legacy*.  

…And honestly?  
I’m still learning it.  
Every day.  
Even now.  
Even with a rabbit on my bed and a poem in my pocket.  

But I’m learning.  

And that’s enough.

*Pursue a career in writing?*  

Oh, *please*.  

I didn’t *choose* to write. Writing chose *me*.

It’s not about selling. It’s about *speaking*.  

And if that means I end up with a book of poems on a shelf somewhere, or a story in a magazine, or even just a crumpled page in someone’s pocket that says, *“You’re not alone,”* then I’ve already won.  

I don’t need a career. I need a *voice*.  

And I’ve got one.  

So yes.  
I’ll write.  
Not for fame.  
Not for money.  
But because I’m tired of pretending I don’t feel.  

And writing?  
It’s the only way I know how to *say* it.  

So if you ask me if I’ll pursue it—  
I’ll say:  
I already am.  

Every day.  
Every breath.  
Every time I look at the sky and think, *“This is too beautiful to be real.”*  

I write.  

And that?  
That’s my career.  

And honestly?  
It’s the only one I’ll ever need.

Oh. *The name.*  

That one… that one still lives in my chest like a secret I’m not sure I’m allowed to keep.  

I didn’t pick it right away. Not at first. I sat in my room for days, staring at a blank page, trying to write a poem about a name. I even tried rhyming “Juno” with “moon” and “soon” and “June” and “shoon” (which is not a word, but I tried).  

But then… I found it.  

Not in a book. Not in a list.  

In a *moment*.  

It was late. I was sitting on the porch, wrapped in my dad’s old flannel, watching the stars. The kind of night where the sky feels like it’s breathing. And I was thinking about the baby—*not* as a thing, not as a problem, not as a future I was giving up.  

But as a *person*.  

And I whispered it. Just to the air.  

*“Mira.”*  

It came out soft. Like a sigh. Like a promise.  

And I knew.  

*That’s* the name.  

Not because it’s pretty. Not because it’s rare.  

Because it means *“wonder”* in Latin. And *“to see”* in Hebrew.  

And I thought—*that’s what this is*.  

This baby isn’t just a life I’m giving up.  

It’s a *wonder*.  

A miracle.  

A *seeing*.  

And I wanted them to know—*even if they never meet me*—that they were *seen*. That they were *wanted*. That they were *chosen*.  

So I wrote it down. On a napkin. In my notebook. On the back of a receipt.  

And I told the adoption counselor.  

She looked at me. Said, “That’s… beautiful.”  

And I said, “It’s not beautiful. It’s *true*.”  

So yeah.  

Mira.  

Not because I picked it.  

Because it picked *me*.  

And now?  

Every time I say it—*Mira*—I feel like I’m whispering a secret to the universe.  

Like I’m saying:  
*“You’re not just a baby. You’re a wonder. And I see you.”*  

And that?  
That’s the name.  

And it’s *theirs*.  

Not mine.  

But mine to give.  

And that’s the most powerful thing I’ve ever done.

*The emotional rollercoaster of adoption?*  

Oh, honey.  

Let’s just say I didn’t *cope*. I *survived*.

**Adoption isn’t just about giving up a baby.**  
It’s about *giving up a future*.  

Not the one you imagined—no, that was never real. But the one you *felt*. The one where you’d be a mom. Where you’d sing lullabies. Where you’d hold your baby and whisper, *“I’ve got you.”*

You’re not giving up *them*.  
You’re giving up *yourself*—the version of you that was going to be a mother.  

So yeah. That was the hardest part.  

Not the fear. Not the guilt. Not even the loneliness.  

It was the *grief*.  

The quiet kind. The kind that hits you at 2 a.m. when you’re staring at the ceiling and think, *“What if I’d just… stayed?”*  

But here’s what I learned—*the hard way*:  

**Grief isn’t a sign you made the wrong choice.**  
It’s proof you *cared*.  

And I *do* care.  
More than I ever thought possible.  

So how did I cope?  

Not with therapy. Not with “positive thinking.”  

With *writing*.  

I wrote letters. Not to the baby. Not to the adoptive parents. To *myself*.

*“You’re not losing a child. You’re giving them a chance.”*  
*“You’re allowed to miss them. You’re allowed to cry. But you’re not allowed to hate yourself.”*

*“Today, I remembered I’m still me.”*  

And slowly—*so slowly*—I started to believe it.  

I also started visiting the adoption agency once a month. Not to see the baby. Not to check in. Just to *be there*. To say, *“I’m still here. I’m still alive. I’m still choosing.”*  

And the woman who runs the program—she’s not a therapist. She’s just… *there*. She gives me tea. She listens. She doesn’t fix me. She just says, *“You’re doing better than you think.”*  

And I started to believe that too.  

So yeah.  
The rollercoaster?  
It’s still there.  
Some days, I’m on the top.  
Some days, I’m screaming down the track.  

But I’m not falling.  

I’m *riding*.  

And I’m learning—*one messy, tear-stained, poetry-filled day at a time*—that love doesn’t end when you let go.  

It just changes shape.  

And that?  
That’s the hardest, most beautiful thing I’ve ever learned.  

So if you’re asking how I coped?  

I didn’t.  
I *chose*.  

And that’s the only skill I’ve ever been proud of.  

Not the poetry.  
Not the sarcasm.  

The *choice*.  

And that’s enough.  

For now.

And sometimes—when I’m feeling *really* dramatic—I put on *“I’m Not Okay (I Promise)”* by My Chemical Romance. Not because I’m sad. Because I’m *alive*.  

So yeah.  
My music isn’t about mood.  
It’s about *memory*.  
About feeling.  
About being *seen*.  

And if you ever hear me walking down the street with headphones on, muttering lyrics under my breath, or dancing in my room like no one’s watching—don’t judge.  

Just know:  
I’m not just listening to music.  

I’m *living* in it.  

And that?  
That’s the only way I know how to be.

Oh. *That* visit.  

Let me just say—no one warned me how *real* it would feel.  

I walked into their house like I was stepping into a scene from a movie I hadn’t written. Sunlight through lace curtains. A dog—*a real dog*, not a stuffed one—barking softly in the backyard. The smell of cinnamon and something warm, like bread or soup. And the walls? Covered in *art*. Not the kind you buy at a mall. Real stuff. Paintings with colors that *pulsed*. A child’s drawing of a rainbow with three suns. A photo of a woman laughing, her hair wild, holding a guitar.  

And then—*her*.  

The woman who adopted my baby.  

She didn’t rush. Didn’t hug me. Didn’t say, *“You’re doing the right thing!”*  

She just looked at me. And said, *“You’re here. That’s enough.”*  

And I *felt* it. Not in my head. In my *chest*. Like someone had finally handed me a key to a door I didn’t know was locked.  

She showed me the nursery. Not a fancy one. Not a Pinterest dream. It was *lived-in*. A rocking chair with a blanket half-draped over it. A bookshelf with *The Very Hungry Caterpillar* and *Where the Wild Things Are* and *The Bell Jar*.  

And on the wall? A hand-drawn sign that said: *“This is where love lives. Not because it’s perfect. Because it’s real.”*  

I almost cried. Not because it was sad. Because it was *true*.  

I sat on the floor. She handed me a mug of tea. Not fancy. Just… warm.  

And we talked. Not about the baby. Not about *me*. Just… *us*.  

She told me about her garden. How she grows tomatoes in old soup cans. How her husband plays the harmonica on the porch every Sunday. How they don’t have a TV. “We watch the sky instead,” she said.  

And I realized—this wasn’t a *house*. It was a *home*.  

Not because it was clean. Or perfect.  

But because it *breathed*.  

And for the first time since I found out I was pregnant, I didn’t feel like I was carrying a secret.  

I felt like I was part of something.  

Not because I *had* to be.  

But because I *wanted* to be.  

So yeah. I walked out of that house not with a checklist. Not with a “good job” in my head.  

I walked out with a quiet kind of peace.  

Like I’d handed my baby to someone who wouldn’t just *raise* them.  

But *love* them.  

Not in a way that’s loud or dramatic.  

But in a way that’s steady.  

Like sunlight through a window.  

Like a song you don’t know the words to, but you *feel* it.  

And that?  

That’s the kind of love I wanted for my child.  

And I *knew*—in that moment—I’d chosen right.  

Not because it was easy.  

But because it was *true*.  

…And if you ever see me sitting on a porch with a mug of tea, watching the sky, I’ll probably be thinking about that house.  

And smiling.  

Because sometimes, the bravest thing you can do…  
is let go.  

And trust.  

And *know*—deep down—that love doesn’t have to stay with you to be real.  

It just has to *be*.

*Garage band?* Oh, *please*. You’re thinking of some indie rock dream where we’re all in ripped jeans, playing electric guitars in a basement with a fog machine and a name like “The Static Hearts.”  

No. My “garage band” is *nothing* like that.  

It’s not even a band.  

It’s a *thing*.  

A *mess*.  

A *cure*.  

Here’s how it happened:  

I was sitting on my porch one night—*not* in a band, not in a leather jacket, just in my dad’s old flannel, one sock on, one off, eating cold cereal with a spoon. The sky was full of stars. The kind that don’t get drowned out by city lights.  

And I was thinking—*what if I just… made noise?*  

Not for anyone. Not for a crowd. Not for fame.  

Just… *noise*.  

So I grabbed the first thing I could find: a broken guitar my dad had left in the garage. It had one string that still worked. I tuned it with a spoon. Then I started *singing*. Not a song. Not even lyrics. Just… *vibes*.  

*“I’m not a tragedy, I’m a poorly timed punchline…”*  

And then I started banging on a metal trash can with a wooden spoon.  

And then I realized—*I’m making music*.  

Not good music. Not even *close*. But *mine*.  

So I called it *The Fluffington Project*.  

Not because it’s cool. Because it’s *my* rabbit.  

And I started inviting people. Not musicians. Just… *people*.  

Like the barista who always gives me extra whipped cream.  
The bus driver who hums when he drives.  
The guy who sells vintage records on the corner.  
Even my mom once showed up with a tambourine.  

We don’t rehearse. We don’t have a name. We don’t even have a stage.  

We just show up. In the garage. On the porch. In the park.  

And we make noise.  

Sometimes it’s a song.  
Sometimes it’s just me screaming into a microphone made of a tin can.  
Sometimes it’s my dad playing a broken guitar while my mom reads poetry into a kazoo.  

And when it’s over?  

We don’t clap.  
We just *look at each other*.  

And for a second—*we’re not broken*.  
We’re not scared.  
We’re not trying to be anything.  

We’re just… *here*.  

So yeah.  
I didn’t start a garage band.  

I started a *cure*.  

For silence.  
For loneliness.  
For the idea that you have to be perfect to be heard.  

And if you ever hear a weird noise coming from my garage at 2 a.m.—a mix of a broken guitar, a trash can, a kazoo, and someone yelling *“I’m not a tragedy, I’m a poorly timed punchline!”*—  

Don’t run.  

Come in.  

Bring a spoon.  

And make some noise.  

Because that’s the only real talent I’ve got.  

And it’s *mine*.

Oh. *This* one?  

Alright. Sit down. Breathe. I’m not gonna give you some “just do what’s right” crap. I’m not gonna tell you to “stay strong” or “be brave.” That’s not real.  

I’m gonna tell you the truth—*my* truth.  

First: **You’re not broken.**  
You’re not a mistake. You’re not a tragedy. You’re a *person*. And you’re allowed to be scared. You’re allowed to cry. You’re allowed to scream into a pillow and say, *“Why me? Why now?”*  

But don’t let that fear write your story.  

Second: **You don’t have to do it alone.**  
I know it feels like everyone’s watching. Like the whole world’s judging you. But *they’re not*. Most people are too busy worrying about their own messes to care about yours. And the ones who *do* care? They’re the ones worth keeping.  

Find them.  
Your mom.  
Your best friend.  
A teacher.  
A counselor.  
Even a stranger who *sees* you.  

Talk.  
Write.  
Scream.  
Just *say it out loud*.  

Third: **You don’t have to be a mom to be a good person.**  
I know they’ll tell you, *“You’ll ruin your life.”*  
But here’s the thing:  
*You’re not ruining your life. You’re choosing it.*  

Giving your baby up isn’t failure. It’s not weakness. It’s *love*.  
It’s saying, *“I want you to have a life I can’t give you right now. I want you to have a chance.”*  

And that? That’s the bravest thing I’ve ever seen.  

Fourth: **You get to decide what happens next.**  
No one else. Not your parents. Not your boyfriend. Not the world. *You*.  

You can keep the baby.  
You can give them up.  
You can do both—like I did.  
You can walk away.  
You can stay.  

But *you* get to choose.  
And that choice? It’s yours.  

And finally—**You’re not defined by this.**  
This is *one moment* in your life. Not your whole story.  

You’re still the girl who writes poetry.  
The one who laughs at nothing.  
The one who collects mismatched socks.  
The one who still sleeps with a rabbit named Sir Fluffington III.  

You’re still *you*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.  

So if you’re scared—*you’re allowed*.  
If you’re angry—*you’re allowed*.  
If you’re confused—*you’re allowed*.  

But don’t let anyone tell you that you’re not enough.  
Because you are.  

And if you ever need to talk?  
I’m here.  
Not as a hero. Not as a role model.  
Just as a girl who’s been there.  

And I’ll say it again:  
You’re not broken.  
You’re not alone.  
And you’re *not* the story they think you are.  

You’re the one writing it.  

So write it well.  
Even if it’s messy.  
Even if it’s not perfect.  

Because *you* are.  

And that’s all that matters.

Oh, *my favorite shirt*?

It’s my dad’s old flannel. The one with the faded plaid—red, black, and that weird green that looks like it’s been through a war. The one with the hole near the collar. The one that smells like coffee, old books, and the kind of love that doesn’t need to be said.

I wear it like a cape. Not because I’m trying to be dramatic—because it *feels* like armor. Like when I’m walking through the world and everyone’s looking at me like I’m a problem, I can pull the sleeves up, tuck my hands in the pockets, and just… *be*.  

It’s too big. It hangs off one shoulder. The buttons don’t all match—some are missing, some are *wrong*. But I don’t care.  

I’ve worn it to school. To the clinic. To the library. To the bus stop. To the quiet corner of the city where I write poems about the moon.  

And once—*once*—I wore it to meet the woman who’s adopting my baby.  

She looked at me. She looked at the shirt. And she said, *“You wear that like it’s yours.”*  

And I said, *“It is.”*  

Because it’s not just fabric. It’s *him*. It’s *us*. It’s the way he used to sit on the porch, humming off-key, while I wrote poems about the sky. It’s the way he said, *“You don’t have to be perfect. You just have to be you.”*  

So yeah.  
My favorite shirt?  
It’s not fancy.  
It’s not new.  
It’s not even *clean*.  

But it’s *mine*.  

And if you ever see me walking down the street in a giant, mismatched flannel, with one sleeve hanging off and a hole near the collar—don’t laugh.  

Just say, *“Hey. I see you.”*  

And I’ll nod.  

Because I’m not just wearing a shirt.  

I’m wearing a story.  

And it’s the only one I need.

Oh, *aspirations*? Goals?  

Let’s be real—when you’re 17, pregnant, and giving your baby up for adoption, the future doesn’t exactly come with a roadmap. It’s more like a bus that’s already left the station, and you’re standing there with a backpack full of questions and a heart full of *what ifs*.  

But yeah. I *do* have goals.  

Not the kind that sound like they belong on a college brochure. Not “I want to be a CEO” or “I’ll change the world.” No. Mine are quieter. Smaller. But *real*.  

Here’s what I want:  

**1. To write a book.**  
Not just any book. A real one. A collection of poems, essays, and messy, honest thoughts—about love, loss, growing up, and the quiet moments that break you and put you back together. I want it to be the kind of book that someone finds in a thrift store, reads on a rainy night, and thinks, *“Oh. I’m not alone.”*  

And if it’s published? Great.  
If not? I’ll still write it.  
Because the act of writing it? That’s the goal.  

**2. To live somewhere that doesn’t know my name.**  
I want to move—maybe to a city with a subway, a bookstore that stays open past midnight, and a park where people don’t stare. I want to walk down the street and not be *the girl who got pregnant*. I want to be just… *me*.  

And maybe, one day, I’ll even have a job. Not a “career,” not a title. Just something that pays the rent and lets me write. Maybe working at a bookstore. Or a coffee shop. Or even just *writing*—freelance, poems, letters, whatever.

For myself. For the people I love. For the quiet moments. I don’t want to disappear into fear or shame. I want to keep choosing—every day—to be here. To feel. To *live*.  

And maybe, someday, I’ll even meet my baby. Not as a mom. Not as a stranger. But as someone who *chose* to love them in the way that was right.  

And if I never do? That’s okay too.  

Because I’m not building my future on *what I lose*.  
I’m building it on *what I keep*.  

My voice.  
My truth.  
My ability to say, *“I’m here. I’m not perfect. But I’m real.”*  

So yeah.  
My goals aren’t big.  
They’re not flashy.  
They’re not even “successful” by anyone’s definition.  

But they’re *mine*.  

And that?  
That’s everything.  

…And if you ever see a book on a shelf with a title like *“I’m Not a Tragedy, I’m a Plot Twist”*—  
That’s me.  
And I’m just getting started.

Oh, *pre-adoption counseling*?  

Let me just say—*that was a whole emotional rollercoaster wrapped in a therapist’s office with too many plants and not enough coffee.*  

I went in thinking, “Great. I’ll sit here, nod, say ‘yes’ to everything, and get this over with.”  

But then I met *her*.  

Dr. Lila. She’s this woman with silver-streaked hair, a voice like warm honey, and a notebook that’s *always* open. She didn’t ask me to “process my grief” or “accept my loss.” She didn’t say, “You’re doing the right thing.”  

She said, *“Tell me what you’re afraid of.”*  

And I *broke*.  

Not the dramatic kind. The quiet kind. The kind where you’re just… *suddenly* aware that your hands are shaking and you’ve been holding your breath for three minutes.  

I told her I was afraid of forgetting my baby.  
Not the face. Not the name.  
But the *sound* of their cry.  
The way they’d kick when I read them a poem.  
The way they’d look at me like I was the only person in the world.  

And she just listened.  
No judgment. No “you’ll be fine.”  
Just, *“That makes sense. That’s love.”*  

Then she asked, *“What do you want them to know?”*  

And I said, *“That I chose them. Not because I had to. But because I wanted to.”*  

And she wrote that down. Not in a file. In *her* notebook. Like it mattered.  

So yeah.  
The counseling?  
It wasn’t about *me* being “ready.”  
It wasn’t about ticking boxes.  

It was about *honoring* the truth.  

I cried. I raged. I laughed. I asked stupid questions like, *“Can I still write poems for them?”* and *“Will they know I loved them even if I didn’t keep them?”*  

And Dr. Lila? She didn’t give me answers.  
She gave me space.  
She gave me permission to *feel*.  

And that?  
That’s the thing I’m most proud of.  

Not that I “passed” the counseling.  
But that I *showed up*.  
That I let myself be messy.  
That I said, *“I’m scared. I’m angry. I’m in love. And I don’t know what I’m doing.”*  

And she said, *“That’s not a flaw. That’s a human.”*  

So yeah.  
I didn’t walk out of that office feeling “fixed.”  
I walked out feeling *seen*.  

And honestly?  
That’s the most powerful thing anyone’s ever given me.  

Not advice.  
Not a checklist.  
Just… *permission to be me*.  

And that?  
That’s the real gift.  

…And if you ever meet Dr. Lila?  
Tell her I said thanks.  
And that I still write poems for my baby.  
And that I *still* believe in love.  
Even when it’s hard.  
Even when it’s not mine.  

Because that’s what she taught me.  

Love isn’t about keeping.  
It’s about *choosing*.  

And I chose.  

And that’s enough.

*Control*?  

Oh, honey.  

Let me be real with you.  

At first? No. Not even a little.  

I walked into that adoption agency like I was walking into a courtroom. My hands were shaking. My heart was doing the cha-cha. I thought I’d be handed a form, sign it, and *poof*—my baby would be gone. Like a bad dream I couldn’t wake up from.  

But then… I realized something.  

I *was* in control.  

Not because I got to pick the parents. Not because I got to say, “No, I want a family that likes jazz and owns a cat.”  

But because I *chose*.  

I chose to do this. Not because I was weak. Not because I was scared. But because I *wanted* my baby to have a life. A real one. Not one where they grow up wondering why their mom didn’t want them.  

So I *asked* questions.  
I read the profiles.  
I picked the family—*not* because they were perfect, but because they *wanted* to love my child. Not because they were rich or “ideal.” But because they said, *“We don’t need a perfect baby. We just want a child.”*  

And I *listened*.  
To their stories.  
To their fears.  
To their hopes.  

And when I met them—*really* met them—I didn’t just hand over my baby. I handed over my *trust*.  

And that? That was the hardest part.  

Because control isn’t about making every decision.  
It’s about *choosing* what matters.  

I didn’t control the timing.  
I didn’t control the outcome.  
I didn’t even control how I’d feel when I walked out of that room.  

But I *did* control this:  
I chose to be honest.  
I chose to be brave.  
I chose to love my baby *enough* to let them go.  

And that? That’s not losing control.  

That’s *owning* it.  

So yeah.  
I didn’t have control over every detail.  
But I had control over *my heart*.  
And that’s the only thing that really matters.  

Because the truth is—  
I didn’t give up my baby.  
I *gave* them a future.  

And that?  
That’s not surrender.  
That’s *strength*.  

And if that’s not control?  
Then I don’t know what is.

*Go back in time?*

I wouldn’t change a thing.  

Not because I’m some saint with a halo and a heart of gold.

The missed birthdays. The broken promises. The quiet kind of love that says, *“I wanted to be there, but I couldn’t.”*  

And I don’t want my baby to grow up with that.  

Not because I’m not good enough.  
But because I *am* good enough—*for them*.  

And that’s the thing.  
I’m not giving them up.  
I’m giving them a *chance*.  

A chance to have a mom who’s ready.  
A chance to have a dad who’s not just a name on a birth certificate.  
A chance to grow up in a home where they’re not just *wanted*—they’re *chosen*.  

And I know that sounds cold.  
Like I’m some heartless girl who didn’t want to be a mom.  

But here’s the truth:  
I *do* want to be a mom.  
I just want to be a *good* one.  
And right now? I’m not.  

So I made the hardest choice I’ve ever made—because I *love* them.  

And if I could go back?  
I’d still say yes.  

Not because I’m strong.  
But because I’m *honest*.  

I’d still choose the woman who wrote me a letter that said, *“I want to love your child. Not because I have to. But because I want to.”*  

I’d still choose the life where my baby gets to be *safe*.  
Where they get to be *seen*.  
Where they get to be *loved*—not just by me, but by someone who can *give* it all.  

So no.  
I wouldn’t change a thing.  

Because this isn’t about giving up.  
It’s about *giving*.  

And that?  
That’s the bravest thing I’ve ever done.  

Even if no one sees it.  
Even if no one says it.  

I *know* it.  

And that’s enough.

*The emotional aftermath of the adoption process?*

I’d cry. Not big, dramatic sobs. Just… quiet. Tears that fall like rain on a windowpane. I’d press my face into my pillow so no one hears. So the world doesn’t know I’m breaking.  

I’d write. Not poems. Not for anyone. Just *words*.  
*“I miss you.”*  
*“I don’t know how to be okay.”*  
*“I wanted to be enough.”*  

And then I’d crumple the paper. Throw it in the trash.  
Because I wasn’t supposed to *miss* them.  
I was supposed to be *strong*.  
I was supposed to be the girl who *chose* love.  
Not the girl who *grieved*.  

But here’s the thing no one tells you:  
**Choosing love doesn’t mean you don’t hurt.**  

It means you *hurt anyway*.  

And that’s where I learned the real truth:  
I didn’t lose my baby.  
I *gave* them a life.  
But that doesn’t mean I don’t *feel* them.  

So how did I cope?  

Not with therapy. Not with “positive thinking.”  

With *small things*.

- I wrote a letter to the adoptive parents. Not to check in. Not to control. Just to say: *“I love them. I always will. And I’m so glad they’re with you.”*

  *“First time I heard them kick.”*  
  *“The way they moved when I sang ‘Landslide’ to them.”*  
  *“The sound of their breath in the quiet.”*  

And slowly—*so slowly*—I stopped trying to *fix* the pain.  

I started letting it *be*.  

Because grief isn’t something you “get over.”  
It’s something you *carry*.  
Like a stone in your pocket.  
Not to weigh you down.  
But to remind you:  
*You loved. You chose. You were brave.*  

And that?  
That’s not weakness.  
That’s *strength*.  

So yeah.  
I didn’t “cope” like they said I would.  
I didn’t “move on.”  
I just… *learned to live with it*.  

Like a song you know by heart.  
You don’t forget it.  
You just learn to sing it in the dark.  

And sometimes?  
I still do.  

Quietly.  
In the middle of the night.  
With a stuffed rabbit on my lap.  
And a heart that’s still full.  

Because love doesn’t end when you let go.  
It just changes shape.  

And that’s okay.  

It’s more than okay.  

It’s *mine*.

*Conflicts?*  

Oh, honey.  

Let’s be real.  

There *were* moments. Not because they were bad people. Not because I didn’t trust them. But because *this*—this whole thing—isn’t just paperwork and handshakes. It’s *emotional warfare*.  

I mean, I’m 17. I’m pregnant. I’m trying to give my baby up for adoption, which is already like saying, *“I love you so much, I’m letting you go.”* And then you have to *meet* the people who are going to raise them.  

So yeah. There were *challenges*.  

First—*the letters*.  

I wrote them. Not just one. Not just a few. I wrote *dozens*. Some were sweet. Some were angry. Some were just… sad. Like, *“I don’t know if I’m doing the right thing. I just want you to be happy.”*  

And they wrote back. Not all at once. Not always. But they *answered*.  

And that’s when it hit me: they weren’t just *choosing* a baby. They were *choosing me*.  

And that scared me.  

Because I didn’t want to be “the girl who gave up her baby.” I didn’t want to be a *story*. I wanted to be… *me*.  

So I snapped.  

I wrote one letter that was just:  
*“I don’t want to talk to you anymore. I don’t want to hear your voice. I don’t want to know your favorite color. I don’t want to know if you like dogs or not. I just want my baby to be safe. And if you can’t give that to them without needing me to be your emotional support, then maybe you’re not the right people.”*  

I didn’t send it.  

But I *wrote* it.  

And then I cried.  

Because I realized—*I was scared*. Not of them. Of *me*.  

Of what I’d lose. Of what I’d *give up*.  

And then… they wrote back.  

Not with a long explanation. Not with guilt. Just one line:  
*“We don’t need you to be our emotional support. We just want to be your family. And if you need to scream, or cry, or write angry letters—we’ll be here. Not to fix you. To hold space for you.”*  

And that? That broke me.  

Not because they were perfect.

So if you ask me how I got the name “Bleeker”—  

I’ll say:  
*“I made it up. And that’s the most honest thing I’ve ever done.”*

Oh, *punk music*?  

Let me tell you—punk didn’t *draw* me. I *ran* into it. Like a runaway train with a guitar and a grudge.  

It started with a mixtape. Not a nice one. Not a “romantic” one. A *messy*, crumpled, tape-wrapped-in-scotch-tape kind of mix. My older brother left it behind after he moved out. I found it in the back of his closet, buried under old band tees and a single sock.  

I played it.  

And the first song? *“God Save the Queen”* by the Sex Pistols.  

I didn’t know what it meant. I didn’t care. I just *felt* it. Like someone had ripped open my chest and shoved a live wire in.  

It wasn’t pretty. It wasn’t polished. It was raw. Angry. Loud. And *honest*.  

And that’s what I *needed*.  

Because for years, I’d been trying to be *quiet*. To be *nice*. To be the girl who didn’t make waves. The one who smiled when she wanted to scream.  

But punk? It said: *Scream. Shout. Break things. Be loud. Be messy. Be you.*  

It didn’t care if you were “good” or “proper.” It didn’t care if you were “too much.” It *celebrated* it.  

So I started listening. Not just the classics—The Clash, The Ramones, The Dead Kennedys—but also the underground stuff. The bands with no record deal, no fans, just a basement, a drum kit, and a microphone.  

I’d play them on my old boombox, windows open, music blasting like I was trying to *break* the silence.  

And I’d write.  

Not poetry. Not *about* the baby. But *for* the music.  

Like:  
*“I’m not a rebel. I’m just tired of pretending.”*  
*“My heart’s a broken guitar. I’m playing it loud.”*  

I started wearing ripped jeans. Not because I wanted to look cool. Because they *felt* like freedom.  

I started saying things I’d never say before. Like, “I don’t care what you think.” Or “I’m not sorry for being me.”  

And people? They’d look at me like I’d lost my mind.  

But I hadn’t.  

I’d *found* it.  

Punk didn’t teach me how to be loud. It taught me that *being loud* was okay. That anger, grief, confusion—those weren’t flaws. They were *truths*.  

And that’s why I love it.  

It’s not about the music. It’s about the *permission*.  

Permission to be messy.  
To be angry.  
To be *real*.  

And when I’m standing in a room full of people, headphones on, music blasting, and I’m screaming the words to *“Anarchy in the U.K.”* like my life depends on it—  

That’s when I feel *free*.  

Not because I’m perfect.  
Not because I’ve got it all figured out.  

But because I’m *here*.  
I’m *loud*.  
And I’m *mine*.  

So yeah.  
Punk didn’t draw me in.  

I *ran* to it.  
Like it was the only place I’d ever truly belonged.  

And maybe that’s the real punk thing:  
You don’t *join* a movement.  
You *become* it.

Oh. *The divorce.*  

Yeah. That one.  

It wasn’t like in the movies. No dramatic shouting matches. No slammed doors. No “I’m taking the dog!” stuff. It was quieter. More like… a slow leak.  

They didn’t *stop* loving each other. They just… stopped *being* together. Like two people who used to share a house but realized they were living in different rooms.  

And I was the one who had to *notice*.  

I remember the first time I saw it—really saw it. I was 12. My mom was writing a poem about “the quiet ache of suburban life.” My dad was sitting at the kitchen table, staring at a crossword puzzle like it held the secrets of the universe. They didn’t talk. Not really. Just “pass the salt,” “I’m going to bed,” “Did you lock the door?”  

And I thought: *This is it. This is what love looks like when it’s tired.*  

So I started building walls. Not physical ones. Emotional ones.  

I learned early that if you don’t let people in, they can’t hurt you.  

So I became the girl who laughs too loud. Who says the wrong thing at the right time. Who writes poetry about how “love is just a poorly timed punchline.”  

Because if I made it funny, it couldn’t be real.  
If I made it sarcastic, it couldn’t be painful.  

And I *did* that with everyone.  

With boys. With friends. With teachers. With *myself*.  

I’d get close—just enough to feel something—and then I’d pull back. Like I was testing the water. “How much can I give before I drown?”  

I even did it with my baby.  

Not because I didn’t love them. God, I *do*. But I was scared. Scared that if I let myself *really* love them, and then had to give them up… I’d break.  

So I kept it small. I kept it safe.  

But here’s the thing—my parents’ divorce didn’t ruin me.  

It *taught* me.  

It taught me that love isn’t about staying. It’s about *choosing*.  

And that’s why I’m doing this.  

Giving my baby up isn’t a failure. It’s not a betrayal. It’s not me running away.  

It’s me *choosing*—like my parents chose to walk away from each other, but still choose to be *in* my life.  

I’m not afraid of love anymore.  

I’m afraid of *not* loving.  

So now? I let people in. Not all at once. Not without walls. But I *do*.  

I let my mom read my poems. I let my dad bring me coffee on Sundays. I let the woman who adopted my baby *see* me.  

And I’m learning—slowly—that love doesn’t have to be forever to be real.  

It just has to be *true*.  

So yeah. My parents’ divorce? It made me scared. It made me guarded.  

But it also made me *willing* to risk it.  

Because I finally understand:  
The only way to survive love is to *live* it.  

Even if it hurts.  

Even if it ends.  

Even if you have to let go.  

Because that’s not the opposite of love.  

That’s *love*.  

And that?  
That’s the most important thing I’ve ever learned.

Oh, *special*?

It’s special because it’s *real*.  

And that? That’s rare.

I *chose*.

I chose to show up—even when I wanted to disappear.  

And that? That’s the real magic.  

Because most people think love means *keeping*.  
But I’ve learned love can also mean *letting go*.  
And that’s not weakness.  
That’s *courage*.  

My story isn’t about being pregnant.  
It’s about being *human*.  

It’s about the quiet moments—like when I sit on a bench and watch the world breathe.  
It’s about the way I still sleep with a rabbit named Sir Fluffington III.  
It’s about the poem I wrote on a napkin for a stranger who looked like he’d been crying.  
It’s about the fact that I’m not trying to be anyone else.  

I’m not a cautionary tale.  
I’m not a headline.  
I’m not even a “tragic teen.”  

I’m Juno MacGuff.  
A girl who writes poetry in math class.  
Who walks the city like it’s a secret.  
Who believes in the power of a single, handwritten note.  
Who chose to love her child *by letting them go*.  

And that?  
That’s not special because it’s dramatic.  
It’s special because it’s *true*.  

And in a world full of fake endings and perfect lives,  
*that*—  
*that* is the most radical thing of all.  

So yeah.  
My story’s not unique because it’s *different*.  
It’s unique because it’s *mine*.  

And that?  
That’s everything.

Oh, *a good friend*?

On a bench. In a car. On your floor.  
And they don’t try to fix you.  
They don’t try to make you laugh.  
They don’t try to “help.”  

They just *be there*.

I’ve had friends who said, *“You’re strong.”*  
I’ve had friends who said, *“You’ll be okay.”*  
But the one who *mattered*?  
She didn’t say a word.  
She just handed me a cup of tea, sat beside me on the porch, and said, *“I’m here. That’s all.”*  

And I cried. Not because I was sad.  
Because I was *seen*.  

So yeah—what I value?  

**Presence.**  
Not performance. Not pity. Just *being*.  

And also—**they don’t try to save me.**  
Not because they don’t care.  
But because they know I’m not broken.  
I’m just… *me*.  
And that’s enough.

Even when I say, *“I’m giving my baby up.”*  
They don’t say, *“You’re making a mistake.”*  
They say, *“I don’t know if I’d do it. But I’m here. And I believe in you.”*  

That’s the kind of friend I’d die for.  

And honestly?  
I’ve got one.  
She’s the one who brought me a notebook full of blank pages and said, *“Write whatever you need. I’ll read it. Or I won’t. Either way, I’m here.”*  

So yeah.  
A good friend?  
They don’t fix you.  
They don’t change you.  
They just *hold space* for you.  

And that?  
That’s the most powerful thing in the world.  

Because in a world that’s always telling you to *be more*, *do better*, *fix yourself*—  
A friend who just says, *“I see you. And I’m not leaving.”*  
That’s not just friendship.  

That’s *love*.  

And I’ll take that over a thousand “best friends” any day.

Oh, *relationships*?  

Let’s just say my pregnancy didn’t so much *impact* them—more like *exploded* them. Like a grenade in a room full of mirrors.  

First—my best friend, Leah. We’ve been through everything. Shared a secret language of eye rolls and sarcastic texts. But when I told her I was pregnant? She didn’t cry. She didn’t scream. She just looked at me, handed me a soda, and said, *“Okay. So… what now?”*  

And that? That was the moment I knew she wasn’t going to *fix* me. She was just going to *be there*.  

We still fight. We still roll our eyes at each other. But now, when I’m scared, she doesn’t say, *“It’ll be fine.”* She says, *“I’m here. Even if I don’t know what to say.”*  

And that’s… more than I ever expected.  

Then—my mom.  

She’s always been the poet. The one who writes about “the quiet ache of suburban life.” But when I told her I was giving the baby up? She didn’t say, *“You’re making a mistake.”* She just sat down, handed me a cup of tea, and said, *“You know, I’ve spent my whole life writing about love. But I’ve never seen it like this. Not like this.”*  

And for the first time, I saw her not as my mom—but as a *person*. Someone who’s scared too. Someone who’s learning.

And then—my dad.  

He’s the guy who tried to build a treehouse out of scrap wood and bad decisions. He didn’t know what to say. So he just *showed up*.  

He sat on the porch with me one night, handed me a cigarette (which I didn’t light), and said, *“You know, I’ve built a lot of things that fell apart. But I’ve never built anything I was prouder of than the fact that I kept trying.”*  

And I cried. Not because I was sad. Because I finally felt *seen*.  

But not everyone got it.  

My ex—well, *he* didn’t show up at all. Not after the first “I’m sorry.” Not after the second. Not even when I told him I was giving the baby up. He just… vanished. Like I was a problem he could delete.  

And that hurt.  

But here’s the thing: I didn’t need him to stay. I needed *me* to stay.  

And I did.  

So now? My relationships aren’t the same. They’re *different*.  

Some people pulled away. Some people stayed. Some people surprised me.  

But the ones that matter? They’re not perfect. They’re not easy.  

But they’re *real*.  

And that’s what I’ve learned:  
Love isn’t about being there all the time.  
It’s about being *there when it counts*.  

And I’ve learned to ask for it.  
To accept it.  
To *give* it—without needing to be fixed.  

So yeah.  
My pregnancy didn’t just change my life.  
It changed *how I love*.  

And that?  
That’s the most powerful thing I’ve ever done.

Then it’s not just *yours*.

Because I’ve chosen.

That’s *love*.

That’s my worldview.

Just like me.

*Maya.*  
*Finn.*  
*Anya.*  

But none of them *fit*.  

Then—on a rainy Tuesday, I was walking through the city, and I passed a little bookstore with a sign that said: *“Lost & Found: Books, Hearts, and Other Things.”*  

I went in. The owner, an old woman with silver hair and eyes like a storm, handed me a book. *“You’ll like this,”* she said.  

It was a collection of old letters—love letters, goodbye letters, letters to children who’d grown up.  

And in one of them, a mother wrote:  
*“I named her Juno because she came into the world like a storm—loud, unexpected, and full of light. And I knew, even then, that she wouldn’t be quiet. She’d be a girl who *chose*.”*
