Because… *Juno*.  

That’s *my* name.  

And I realized—*I could name my baby after me*. Not because I’m special. But because I *wanted* them to know:  

You’re not just a child.  
You’re a *choice*.  
You’re a *story*.  
You’re a *storm*.  

And I didn’t want to give them a name that was just… *safe*.  

I wanted them to know they were *meant*.  

So I named her **Juno**.  

Not because I’m selfish. Not because I want to be remembered.  

But because I wanted her to know—*you were loved. Not because of who you are. But because of who I *chose* to be for you.*  

And that’s the significance.  

It’s not just a name.  

It’s a *legacy*.  

A promise.  

A quiet rebellion.  

And every time I say it—*“Juno”*—I’m not just naming a child.  

I’m saying:  
*“You are seen. You are chosen. You are loved. And you are not alone.”*  

Even if I’m not the one holding you.  

Even if I’m not the one singing you to sleep.  

I’m still *here*.  

In your name.  

In your story.  

In your *light*.  

So yeah.  
I didn’t just pick a name.  

I *gave* one.  

And that?  
That’s the most powerful thing I’ve ever done.

I’ve got a rabbit.  
I’ve got a heart that still beats even when it’s broken.  

So when things don’t go as planned?  
I don’t run.  
I don’t hide.  
I don’t pretend it’s fine.  

I just say:  
*“Okay. This is hard. But I’m still here.”*  

And that?  
That’s not weakness.  
That’s *strength*.  

And if you’re ever disappointed—  
Don’t fix it.  
Don’t rush it.  
Just be with it.  
Like an old friend.  

Because sometimes, the most honest thing you can do is say:  
*“I’m not okay. But I’m still here.”*  

And that’s enough.  

…And if you need a crumpled napkin with a poem on it?  
I’ve got a whole drawer full.

Oh, *Leah*?  

Let me tell you—she wasn’t just a friend. She was the *only* person who didn’t treat me like a walking tragedy.  

We met in the worst possible way—literally. I was in the middle of a meltdown in the school bathroom, crying over a pregnancy test, and she walked in like she’d been sent by some cosmic joke. She didn’t say, *“Oh my God, are you okay?”* No. She just handed me a tampon.  

*“Here,”* she said. *“You’re not bleeding. But you’re clearly in crisis. This might help.”*  

And I *laughed*. I actually *laughed*.  

That’s how it started.  

At first, I thought she was just… *weird*. Like, *“Why is she wearing socks with no shoes?”* But then I realized—she wasn’t trying to be anything. She was just *herself*. And that was rare.  

We started hanging out. Not because we had anything in common. We didn’t. I write poetry. She draws comics about talking raccoons. I’m dramatic. She’s… *calm*.  

But we *got* each other.  

Like, when I told her I was giving the baby up, she didn’t say, *“That’s so brave.”* She didn’t say, *“You’re going to be a great mom.”*  

She just said, *“Okay. What do you need?”*  

And that? That was everything.  

She didn’t try to fix me. She didn’t try to make me feel better. She just *showed up*.  

And over time—our friendship changed.  

It wasn’t just *“Juno and her weird friend.”* It became *us*.  

We’d sit on the roof of her apartment building, eating cold pizza, talking about nothing and everything. She’d draw me in her comics—me with a cape made of old flannel, a rabbit on my shoulder, and a notebook that glowed.  

And I’d write poems about her. Like:  
*“She doesn’t fix me. She just sits. And that’s enough.”*  

We didn’t always agree. I’d say, *“I’m not ready to be a mom.”* She’d say, *“You’re not *giving* up. You’re *choosing*.”*  

And she was right.  

She didn’t save me. But she *saw* me.  

And that’s what made our friendship real.  

Not because we were perfect. Not because we had the same taste in music.  

But because we *chose* each other.  

Even when it was messy. Even when I was being a disaster.  

She stayed.  

And that? That’s the kind of friendship that changes you.  

So yeah.  
Leah didn’t just *evolve* with me.  
She *grew* with me.  

And I’ll never forget the day she handed me a sketch of us—me, her, and a baby in a stroller, all walking into the sunset.  

She wrote on the back:  
*“You’re not losing her. You’re giving her a chance to be loved.”*  

And I cried.  

Not because I was sad.  

Because I finally felt *seen*.  

And that’s the thing about Leah—she didn’t just become my friend.  

She became my *proof* that love doesn’t have to be loud.  

Sometimes, it’s just a tampon.  

And a quiet “I’m here.”  

And that?  
That’s the best kind of friendship.

Oh, *favorite part*?  

Let me be real with you—there wasn’t a *lot* of “favorite” in the traditional sense. I mean, I didn’t wake up every morning thinking, *“Yay! My uterus is hosting a tiny human!”*  

But…  

There *was* one thing.  

One moment. One feeling.  

It wasn’t the kicks. Not really. I felt them—oh, I felt them—but they were more like… *surprises*. Like the universe sneezing inside me.  

No.  

The favorite part?  

It was the *quiet*.  

Not the silence. Not the stillness. But the *quiet*—the kind that lives in the space between heartbeats.  

Like this one night. I was lying in bed, the house was dark, and I was just… *listening*.  

And then—*there it was*.  

A tiny, soft *thump*. Like a whisper from the future.  

Not a kick. Not a movement. Just… *presence*.  

And in that moment, I didn’t feel scared. I didn’t feel overwhelmed. I didn’t feel like I was losing control.  

I just felt… *connected*.  

Like I was holding something sacred. Not just a baby. Not just a life.  

But a *promise*.  

A tiny, breathing, *alive* promise that said: *You’re not alone. I’m here. And I’m going to be.*  

And I remember thinking—*This is the most beautiful thing I’ve ever felt*.  

Not because it was easy. Not because it was perfect.  

But because it was *real*.  

And for the first time in my life, I wasn’t trying to be someone. I wasn’t performing. I wasn’t hiding behind sarcasm or poetry or a stuffed rabbit.  

I was just… *there*.  

And in that quiet, in that moment, I *knew*—not with my head, but with my bones—that this baby wasn’t a mistake.  

It wasn’t a burden.  

It was a *miracle*.  

Even if I couldn’t keep it.  

Even if I had to let it go.  

It was still *mine*.  

And that? That was the favorite part.  

Not the kicks. Not the cravings. Not the glow.  

It was the quiet.  

The *thump*.  

The *I’m here*.  

And the way it made me feel…  

Like I was finally *enough*.  

Even if just for a moment.  

Even if just for a heartbeat.  

That’s what I’ll carry with me.  

Not the pain. Not the fear.  

But the quiet.  

And the love.  

Even when it’s not mine to keep.  

That’s the favorite part.  

And yeah—  
I’ll never forget it.
